questions.text: Identify the bacteria that causes the phenomenon shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The given picture shows swarming, which is exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively by means of peritrichous flagella, resulting in “swarming” on solid media. It can be suppressed by

  • Phenylethyl alcohol
  • Cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient (CLED) medium

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia

Related Pearl: Types of motility of microorganisms

Motility Microorganism
Darting/vibratory motility  Vibrio,Campylobacter
Swarming motility Cl. septicum, B.cereus, Proteus, some Vibrio sp
Tumbling motility  Listeria monocytogenes
Stately motility Clostridia
Spinning motility Fusobacterium gyrans
Cork-screw motility  Treponema pallidum
Falling leaf motility Giardia
Twitching motility Eikenella corrodens
Differential motility (Motility varies at different temperatures) Yersinia enterocolitica & Listeria monocytogenes
Jerky motility  Trichomonas vaginalis
Gliding motility Mycoplasma, Entamoeba
Lashing motility  Saprophytic spirochetes

questions.text: In a population of 5000, the birth rate is 30 per 1000 population. 15 children died in their first year of life and of those 9 died in their first month. What is the infant mortality rate in this population:
questions.solution:
• Infant mortality rate (IMR) = (Number of deaths of children under age 1 in a year x 1000) / (Number of live births in that year)
  • In this scenario, the number of live births would be 150
  • Number of deaths of children under age 1 is 15
  • IMR = 100
  • IMR is regarded as the most important indicator of the health status of a community and of the effectiveness of MCH care
  • As of SRS bulletin 2018, Indian IMR is 32

questions.text: Identify the incorrect match.
questions.solution:
Councilman bodies are apoptotic hepatocytes seen in acute hepatitis and yellow fever.

Option A: Mallory–Denk bodies are eosinophilic materials made of keratin intermediate filaments. They are seen in alcoholic liver disease, non-alcoholic fatty liver disease, Wilson's disease, and chronic biliary tract diseases.

Option C: Ground-glass hepatocytes are liver cells that have eosinophilic granular, glassy cytoplasm seen on light microscopy. The appearance is due to the swelling of the endoplasmic reticulum by HBsAg and is a diagnostic hallmark of chronic hepatitis B.

Option D: Circumferential onion skin fibrosis around a degenerating bile-duct lumen is seen in primary sclerosing cholangitis.

Related Pearl: Mallory Bodies vs. Councilman Bodies

Mallory bodies Councilman bodies
Intra-cytoplasmic inclusions  Acidophilic apoptotic bodies
Due to aggregation of cytoskeletal intermediate filament  Due to hepatocyte apoptosis  

Appears as clumped, amorphous, eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes.

 Entire hepatocyte shrinks and appears as intense eosinophilic stained bodies

Seen in

  • Alcoholic hepatitis
  • Primary biliary cholangitis 
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency
  • Indian childhood cirrhosis
  • Hepatocellular carcinoma 

Seen in  

  • Acute viral hepatitis
  • Yellow fever

Mallory bodies seen as clumped, amorphous eosinophilic material within ballooned hepatocytes

Councilman bodies where the entire cell is shrunken into intense eosinophilic apoptotic body

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of Cushingoid features?
questions.solution:
Iatrogenic hypercortisolism is the most common cause of Cushingoid features.

Ectopic tumour ACTH production, cortisol-producing adrenal adenomas, adrenal carcinoma, and adrenal hyperplasia are the other causes associated.

Related Pearl: Causes of Cushing's Syndrome

Exogenous causes (iatrogenic)

  • Prolonged administration of glucocorticoids (most common cause of Cushing's)

Endogenous causes

  • ACTH independent (primary hypercortisolism)
    • Adrenocortical adenoma 
    • Adrenocortical carcinoma 
    • Bilateral adrenal hyperplasia
  • ACTH dependent (secondary hypercortisolism)
    • Cushing’s disease: ACTH secreting pituitary adenoma (most common cause of endogenous Cushing's)
    • Paraneoplastic causes: Ectopic ACTH secreting tumors
      • Small-cell lung carcinoma
      • Bronchial or pancreatic carcinoid tumors
      • Medullary thyroid carcinoma
      • Pheochromocytoma

Rare causes

  • Macronodular adrenal hyperplasia
  • Primary pigmented nodular adrenal disease
  • McCune – Albright syndrome

questions.text: What is the most common fetal complication of placenta praevia?
questions.solution:
The most common fetal complication of placenta praevia is low birth weight. Whereas, most common fetal complication of abruptio placentae is prematurity.

Complications of placenta previa :

Maternal complications

Antepartum Labour Postpartum Puerperium
APH Cord prolapse PPH Sepsis
Malpresentation Intrapartum haemorrhage Retained placenta  
Premature labour Early rupture of membranes    
Associated abruptio: 10%      

Fetal complications

  • Low birth weight: 15% (Most common fetal complication)
  • Birth Asphyxia
  • IUD
  • Birth injuries
  • Congenital malformations (3x risk)

questions.text: Risk factors for osteoporosis include all except
questions.solution:
Obesity is not a risk factor for osteoporosis. Low body weight ( BMI < 18.5 kg/m2 )  and low bone mass density are risk factors for osteoporosis.

Related Pearl: Z-score and T-score for osteoporosis:

Z-score:

It is the number of standard deviations a patient’s BMD(bone mass density) differs from the average BMD of their age, sex, and ethnicity.

A Z-score of -2 or below should trigger investigations for underlying disease.

T-score:

It is the BMD at the site when compared to the young normal reference mean. It is a comparison of a patient’s BMD to that of a healthy 30-year old.

  • Normal is a T-score of -1 or higher.
  • Osteopenia is defined as a T-score between -1.0 and -2.5.
  • Osteoporosis is defined as a T-score less than -2.5, that is a BMD which is two and a half standard deviations below the mean of a 30-year old man/woman.

questions.text: False statement about Employee State Insurance (ESI) act is ___________

choices.text: Employee contributes 0.75% of his daily wage
Employer contributes 3.25% of the employees' daily wage
1/8th medical benefit is provided by the central government
7/8th medical benefit is provided by the ESI corporation

questions.solution:
The state government share of expenditure on medical care is 1/8, the ESI corporation's share of expenditure on medical care is 7/8 of total cost. State and Central government share medical expenditure in the ratio 1:7.

Note:

According to the latest ESI update(w.e.f 01/07/2019) the employer contributes 3.25% and the employee contributes 0.75% of the wages.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: HMP shunt can occur at all of the following sites except:
questions.solution:
HMP shunt pathway can not occur in muscles because muscle tissue is deficient in glucose 6-phosphate dehydrogenase, the rate-limiting enzyme in the oxidative phase of the pathway.

HMP shunt pathway takes place in the following:

  • Liver
  • Adipose tissue
  • Adrenal cortex
  • Thyroid
  • Erythrocytes
  • Testis
  • Lactating mammary glands

Given below is the HMP shunt pathway.

questions.text: Which is the anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism?
questions.solution:
The anticoagulant of choice for the management of cancer-associated thromboembolism is low-molecular-weight heparin (LMWH).

It is the preferred agent because of more bioavailability, lack of need for anticoagulant monitoring, and a long t1/2. 

Venous thromboembolism (including deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and splanchnic vein thrombosis), is a frequent complication of cancer and is the second-leading cause of death in cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.

Based on the results from the Comparison of Low-molecular-weight heparin vs. Oral anticoagulants for long-term anticoagulation in cancer patients with venous Thromboembolism (CLOT) Trial, all recent guidelines now advise LMWH for cancer-associated thromboembolism. 

However, unfractionated heparin (UFH) can be used in patients with renal failure, and fondaparinux can be considered in patients with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

Tinzaparin (LMWH) is used for maintenance treatment in patients with cancer-associated venous thromboembolism.

questions.text: Which of the following is true?

choices.text: Type Aα fibre carry information related to pressure
Type Aβ fibre has the largest diameter
Type C fibre has the slowest conduction velocity

questions.solution:
Type C fibers are the small unmyelinated nerve fibers that conduct impulses at low velocities.

Greater the diameter of a given nerve fiber, the greater its speed of conduction.

The nerve fibers are divided into types A (myelinated), B (myelinated), and C(Unmyelinated). The type A fibers are further subdivided into α, β, γ, and δ fibers.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the right knee region for the past three months. On examination, the right knee region is swollen and there is a reduced range of motion. His x-ray is given below. Which of the following statements is correct about the condition?

choices.text: Histology of the lesion shows multi-nucleated giant cells.
The tumor is seen more commonly in children.
Reactive sclerosis around the tumor is always seen.

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the x-ray showing a soap bubble appearance is suggestive of a giant cell tumor (GCT)/ osteoclastoma. The histological finding in GCT would be multinucleated giant cells in a sea of mononuclear cells. 

Osteoclastoma usually affects young adults of age 20 to 40 years (Option B), with slight female predominance. It is exclusively seen in adults and affects the epiphysis of long bones (Option C). GCT is seen most commonly in the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal humerus, and distal radius. Common presenting complaints are swelling and vague pain. Sometimes, the patient presents for the first time with a pathological fracture through the lesion.

  • Important x-ray features of a GCT:
    • A solitary, possibly loculated, lytic lesion in the epiphysis.
    • Eccentric location, most often subchondral.
    • Expansion of the overlying cortex.
    • Soap bubble appearance - The tumor is homogeneously lytic with trabeculae of the remnants of bone traversing it, giving it a loculated appearance called soap bubble appearance.
    • No calcification within the tumor.
    • No or minimal reactive sclerosis around the tumor (Option D).

Histologically, GCTs consist of undifferentiated spindle cells profusely interspersed with multi-nucleated giant cells. The tumor stroma is well-vascularized with bands of cellular or collagenous fibrous tissue. The image below shows the histopathology of osteoclastoma.

The treatment of choice for GCT is extended curettage and bone grafting.

  • GCT in the relatively insignificant bone like the distal ulna, clavicle, and proximal fibula is treated by resection without reconstruction.
  • Bisphosphonates have been shown to reduce the proliferation of osteoclasts and hence have been shown to stabilize local and metastatic disease.
  • Radiation can be used for spinal or sacral tumors.

questions.text: In a patient undergoing mitral valve repair, which is the most sensitive indicator of myocardial ischemia?
questions.solution:
Transesophageal echocardiography is the most sensitive indicator of myocardial ischemia.  

New regional wall motion abnormalities (RWMA) and decreased systolic wall thickening on transesophageal echocardiography are more sensitive than ECG.

Ischemia may be indicated clinically by a sudden onset intraoperative arrhythmia or conduction block.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding the RAS gene except:

choices.text: Ras oncogenes code for a family of proteins called GTP binding  proteins.
There are 3 Ras genes in humans  H-RAS, K-RAS, N-RAS .
When Ras is switched on, it is involved in cell growth, differentiation and survival.
Mutations in ras genes need incoming signals for over growth of the cells

questions.solution:
RAS protoncogene :

  • The 3 Ras genes in humans (H-RAS, K-RAS, and N-RAS) are the most common oncogenes in human cancer.
  • Ras oncogenes code for a family of proteins called GTP binding (G) proteins, which are involved in transmitting signals within cells (cellular signal transduction).
  • When Ras is 'switched on' by incoming signals, it subsequently switches on other proteins, which ultimately turn on genes involved in cell growth, differentiation, and survival.
  • Mutations in ras genes can lead to the production of permanently activated Ras proteins. As a result, this can cause unintended and overactive signaling inside the cell, even in the absence of incoming signals. Because these signals result in cell growth and division, overactive RAS signaling can ultimately lead to cancer.

questions.text:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate should exceed?

NRR: Net reproduction rate
questions.solution:
In order to reach the demographic goal of NRR=1, the couple protection rate (CPR) should exceed 60%. This coincides with every couple having 2 children.

Related Pearl: Pearl index and couple protection rate:

Pearl Index is defined as the number of contraceptive failures per 100 woman-years of exposure (HWY).

  • In this formula, the total accidental pregnancies that are used as the numerator must include every known conception, irrespective of its outcome.
  • In the denominator, total months of exposure is obtained by deducting, 10 months for full-term deliveries and 4 months for abortion, from the total period under review.

Couple Protection Rate:

  • It is an indicator of couple protection practice in the community.
  • It is defined as the percentage of eligible couples effectively protected against childbirth by one or the other approved methods of family planning.
  • Attaining a 60% CPR would mean restricting all third or higher-order births.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

Crude birth rate

  • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory
  • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population

General Fertility Rate

  • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
  • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth

Age-specific fertility rates is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.

Total Fertility Rate

  • It is the sum of all age-specific fertility rates multiplied by 5
  • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size

Gross Reproductive Rate is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.

Net Reproduction Rate

  • It is a demographic indicator
  • NRR of 1 is equivalent to approximately the 2 child norm
  • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate

questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure____________
questions.solution:
The instrument given is sling pschyrometer, which is used to measure humidity.

Related Pearl: Humidity

Absolute humidity is the weight of water vapor in a unit volume of air and it is expressed as g/kg of air or g/m3 of air.

Relative humidity (RH):

  • It is the ratio of the actual water vapor content to the maximum water vapor content in the air required for saturation of air at a given temperature and pressure. It is expressed as a percentage.
  • RH = Actual water vapor content x 100/ Total water vapor content
  • Very low RH can cause skin problems, irritation of the mucous membranes of the nose and throat, and precipitation of infections. 

Dew point is the temperature to which air has to be cooled to achieve saturation given the pressure and constant moisture content

Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers - most widely used instrument
  • Sling or whirling psychrometers

questions.text: Which of the following forms the internal component of a cochlear implant?
questions.solution:
Receiver stimulator is implanted during surgery (under the skin) and electrode array(implanted in the scala tympani of the cochlea) are the part of the internal component of the cochlear implant.

Microphone, speech processor and transmitter are the part of the external component of the cochlear implant which remain outside the body.

Cochlear implants replace the non-functional transducer system of hair cells of the cochlea, convert the sound signal to electrical impulses which directly stimulate the fibers of cranial nerve VIII.

Used in the cochlear type of sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: Fundal images of two different forms of a condition are depicted in images A and B. Identify the true statement.

choices.text: A is treated with laser photocoagulation
B is the most common form of the condition
B is treated with intravitreal injection of anti VEGF

questions.solution:
The images A and B show Age-related macular degeneration.

  • Image A (shows drusens) - dry/ non exudative AMD
  • Image B – Wet/ exudative AMD

Wet/exudative AMD is treated with intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF.

AMD:

Dry (non-exudative, non-neovascular) AMD:

  • The most common form, comprising around 90% of the diagnosed disease. Geographic atrophy (GA) is the advanced stage of dry AMD.
  • No effective treatment is available. Antioxidants like lutein and zeoxanthine are given as prophylaxis.

Wet (exudative, neovascular) AMD:

  • It is much less common than dry, but is associated with more rapid progression to advanced sight loss.
  • It is characterized by retinal pigment epithelial detachment and choroidal/sub retinal neovascularisation.
  • Treatment depends on the location of choroidal neovascularization membrane.
    • For extrafoveal membrane – laser photocoagulation
    • For subfoveal and juxta foveal treatment options are as follows:
      1. Intravitreal injection of anti-VEGF
      2. Photodynamic therapy – dye used is verteporfin followed by exposure to light from diode
      3. Transpupillary thermotherapy

questions.text: Inheritance pattern depicted in the following pedigree chart is:
questions.solution:
In the given pedigree chart females are carriers and only males are affected and males pass it on to all female progenies but not any male progeny. Hence it is X linked disorder.

Since disease is not manifesting in carrier females, it is a recessive disorder.

Hence this is an X linked recessive inheritance.

questions.text: Which of the following structures do not form the border of Hepatobiliary triangle?
questions.solution:
The triangular region formed between the cystic duct, the common hepatic duct and the inferior surface of the liver is the hepatobiliary triangle.

Hepatobiliary and calot's triangles are often confused with each other. 

Hepatobiliary triangle

  • cystic duct,
  • common hepatic duct
  • inferior surface of the liver

Calot’s triangle

  • common hepatic duct,
  • cystic artery
  • cystic duct 

Related Pearl: Calot's triangle and hepatobiliary triangle

Boundaries Calot's Triangle Hepatobiliary Triangle

Superiorly

 Superior border of the cystic artery Inferior surface of the liver

Medially

 Common hepatic duct

Inferiorly

 Cystic duct

Contents of Calot’s triangle:

  • Lymph node of Lund - Sentinel lymph node for the gallbladder
  • Branching of cystic artery from the right hepatic artery

questions.text: Vitamin K is involved in synthesis of which of the following clotting factors?
questions.solution:
Vitamin K is involved in synthesis of Factor 10.

The vitamin K-dependent proteins can be divided into two classes:

  • Procoagulants - Factors II, VII, IX, and X
  • Anticoagulants - Proteins C, S and Z

The vitamin k-dependent proteins are a part of a family of serine proteinase (except for proteins S and Z) related to the trypsin/chymotrypsin super family.

questions.text: The most important risk factor for the condition shown in the image is ______

choices.text: Previous history of the same condition

questions.solution:
Previous history of placenta previa is the most important risk factor - 12 times higher risk.

Other risk factors are:

  • Smoking
  • Multiparity
  • Increased maternal age
  • H/O previous uterine surgery/ uterine curettage
  • Increased placental size - multifetal pregnancy
  • Succenturiate lobe

questions.text: Match the following intracranial bleed:

choices.text: A -i B-ii C- iii  D- iv

questions.solution:
Epidural hematoma:

Noncontrasted axial computed tomography scan showing a lenticular area of increased density in left parietal region.

  • Typically occur in the groove of the middle meningeal artery associated with temporal bone fractures that have resulted in a tear of middle meningeal artery.
  • They tend to not to cross suture lines of the skull.

Subdural hematoma:

A non contrasted computed tomography scan of acute subdural hematoma shows a cresentric area of increased density in the right posterior parietal region between brain and the skull. An area of intraparenchymal haemorrhage also seen. In addition, mass effect causes a midline shift to left.

  • They can cross suture lines but they do not cross the tentorium or falx.
  • Can be acute or chronic

Subarachnoid haemorrhage:

A non contrasted axial computed tomography scan shows the blood as areas of increased density near the base of the brain shows blood in Texaco star pattern formed blood radiating from suprasellar cistern into the sylvian fissures and anterior interhemispheric fissure.

  • Most often accompanied by severe sudden onset headache.
  • Can really be visualised in acute stage, when blood is radiographically dense (whiter) than the CSF.

Intracereberal haemorrhage:

Non contrast computed tomography shows a large area of fresh blood appearing white in the region of right thalamus. Blood is denser than CSF so settles dependently.

This settling is not seen with subarachnoid or interparenchymal blood.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Which of the following heart lesions is least likely to be found in Gregg Syndrome/Gregg Triad?
questions.solution:
Gregg syndrome/Gregg Triad is the other name for Congenital Rubella Syndrome. Atrial septal defect (ASD) is not found in congenital rubella infection.

Prenatal exposure to rubella increases the risk of congenital heart defects like:

  • Patent ductus arteriosus (PDA)
  • Peripheral pulmonic stenosis
  • Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Myocarditis

Note:

Congenital Rubella Syndrome

  • Most important risk factor for severe congenital defects is the stage of gestation at the time of infection.
  • The risk for congenital defects has been estimated at 90% for maternal infection before 11 weeks of gestation.
  • Triad of congenital rubella: cataract (common is nuclear pearly), sensorineural deafness, and congenital heart defects (e.g., PDA).
  • Other common abnormalities: Intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR), glaucoma, salt and pepper retinopathy, meningoencephalitis, progressive rubella panencephalitis.
  • Diagnosis: Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

Related Pearl: Rubella and congenital rubella syndrome

Congenital rubella syndrome:

  • The triad of Gregg in congenital rubella syndrome includes:
    • Sensorineural hearing loss - Nerve deafness is the single most common finding among infants with congenital rubella syndrome
    • Congenital cataract
    • Congenital heart disease - The most common cardiac defect is patent ductus arteriosus
  • Maximum damage to the fetus occurs in the first trimester
  • Infection in the second trimester causes only deafness
  • If infection occurs after 16 weeks there are no major abnormalities
  • Diagnosis - Presence of IgM rubella antibodies in the infant shortly after birth or persistence of IgG antibodies for >6 months.

The given image shows bilateral cataract in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The given image shows blueberry muffin rash in an infant with congenital rubella syndrome

The image given below shows the salt and pepper fundus.

 Rubella:

  • Also called the German measles
  • Causative organism belongs to the family Matonaviridae
  • Period of infectivity is -5 to +6 days after the onset of the rash
  • Droplet trasmission
  • The incubation period is 2-3 weeks
  • The rash appears on day 1
  • Forchheimer spots are seen, which are tiny, rose-colored lesions in the oropharynx
  • Associated with post-infectious thrombocytopenia
  • The most serious complication is encephalitis
  • Vaccination is done with the live attenuated RA 27/3 strain of the rubella

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of AIDS presents to the OPD with fever, chills, weight loss and the cutaneous lesions shown below. The microscopic examination of the lesions revealed predominant neutrophilic infiltration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of a patient with HIV infections and the violaceous lesions with a neutrophilic infiltrate is suggestive of bacillary angiomatosis.

Bacillary angiomatosis is seen in severely immunocompromised patients and is caused by B. henselae or B. quintana. It is characterized by neovascular proliferative lesions involving the skin. It consists of lobular proliferation of small blood vessels lined by enlarged endothelial cells interspersed with mixed infiltrates of neutrophils and lymphocytes, with a predominance of the former.

Both bacillary angiomatosis and Kaposi's sarcoma can have the clinical presentation mentioned in the question. However, the major differentiating factor is the microscopic examination:

  • Bacillary angiomatosis predominantly has mixed infiltrate accompanied by neutrophils with clumps of bacilli.
  • Kaposi's sarcoma predominantly has plasma cells and lymphocytic infiltrates.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with throbbing headaches on one side. She has a fever and tenderness over the temple. Investigations reveal an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate.  A biopsy of the affected site is most likely to reveal _____
questions.solution:
Clinical history and lab investigations suggest a diagnosis of temporal or giant cell arteritis. Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation centered on the internal elastic lamina that produces elastic lamina fragmentation

There is an infiltrate of T cells (CD4+ > CD8+) and macrophages. Multinucleated giant cells are seen in approximately 75% of adequately biopsied specimens.

Leucocytoclastic vasculitis - Microscopic polyangiitis
Eosinophils- Churg-Strauss syndrome
Microabscesses with neutrophils- Buergers disease.

questions.text: Rinne positive in both ears and Weber lateralised towards left indicates
questions.solution:
It is Right sided sensorineural hearing loss.

Since Weber is lateralised towards left, it indicates left sided conductive deafness or right sided sensorineural deafness.

Since Rinne is positive on both ears, conductive deafness is ruled out.

Related Pearl: Tuning fork tests

Tests Normal
Conductive 
loss
Sensorineural
loss
Rinne AC > BC (Rinne +) BC > AC (Rinne -) AC > BC (Rinne +)
Weber Center Lateralized to the affected ear Lateralized to the normal ear
Absolute bone conduction Normal Normal Reduced
Schwabach Normal Lengthened Shortened
Bing Positive Negative Positive
Gelle Positive Negative (ossicular lesions) Positive

AC- Air conduction; BC- Bone conduction.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl with academic and behavioral problems at school over the past year was diagnosed with attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder. On neuroimaging, which of the following is most likely to be seen?

choices.text: Pathologic alterations in the frontal lobe
Structural anomalies in the frontal lobe
Lesion in the Ascending Reticular Activating System

questions.solution:
Functional neuroimaging studies show frontal lobe hypometabolism in patients with ADHD.

The frontal lobe maintains attention, arousal, or the establishment and maintenance of an awake state. This appears to require at least three brain regions:

  • Ascending reticular activating system (ARAS)
  • Intralaminar nuclei of the thalamus
  • Frontal lobes

In ADHD, although no specific pathological lesions are found in the ARAS, thalamic or cortical level, functional neuroimaging indicates frontal lobe hypometabolism.

questions.text: The sign seen in the following sonography is suggestive of which fetal anomaly-
questions.solution:
The lemon sign is suggestive of spina bifida.

This is called lemon sign as at the level of lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones (indicated by arrow). It is alsocharectaristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

Another sign called banana sign can also be seen in spina bifida in which at the level of posterior fossa, anterior curvature of cerebellum with effacement of cisterna magna can be seen.

questions.text: Causes of a small pupil include all except:
questions.solution:
Carbon monoxide is a cause of dilated pupils.

Causes of small pupils include

  • Pontine hemorrhage
  • Horner's syndrome
  • Old age
  • Argyll Robertson pupil
  • Drugs and poisons (opiates, organophosphates)

Causes of dilated pupils include:

  • Holme Adie's (myotonic) pupil
  • Third nerve palsy
  • Atropine
  • Carbon monoxide
  • Ethylene glycol

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with recurrent episodes of abdominal pain and weight loss.  An X-ray abdomen done shows the following picture. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and X-ray showing the presence of calcification in the pancreas are suggestive of Chronic pancreatitis. 

Chronic pancreatitis is a progressive inflammatory disease in which there is an irreversible destruction of pancreatic tissue. It is more common in males, with a male: female ratio of 4:1.

ERCP is the most sensitive radiologic test for the diagnosis of chronic pancreatitis.

Other tests that can be done are:

  • CECT
  • MRCP- chain of lakes appearance
  • MRI
  • Endoscopic ultrasound (EUS)

Option B: Plain radiograph of the gallbladder may show radiopaque gallstones in only 10% of patients. Rarely, the center of a stone may contain radiolucent gas in a triradiate or biradiate fissure. This gives rise to the ‘Mercedes–Benz’ or ‘seagull’ sign. Ultrasonography (USG) is the most accurate initial imaging modality of choice for the diagnosis of gallbladder stones. They appear as echogenic foci producing acoustic shadows. The image below shows ultrasonography of the gall bladder.

Option C: Sarcoidosis affects the kidneys and sometimes may even end in kidney failure. Symptoms of kidney problems include inflammation, the formation of sarcoid “granulomas” in the kidney, and the formation of kidney stones made of calcium.

Option D: A patient with renal calculi presents with complaints of severe left loin pain and burning micturition. An erect abdominal X-ray showing staghorn calculus is shown below.

Related Pearl: Clinical Features of Chronic Pancreatitis

Abdominal pain: most common symptom

  • Site:
    • If infectious foci are in the head of the pancreas, then epigastric and right subcostal pain is common;
    • If the infection is limited to the left side of the pancreas, left subcostal and back pain are seen.
  • Precipitated by food intake, thus weight loss is also seen.
  • Associated with nausea, vomiting

Exocrine insufficiency:

  • Precedes endocrine insufficiency
  • Correlates with morphological changes
  • Manifests with malabsorption symptoms: steatorrhea, diarrhea.
  • Manifests with signs and symptoms of fat-soluble vitamin deficiency, such as bleeding, osteopenia, and osteoporosis: Severe cases

Endocrine insufficiency: Diabetes mellitus

Related Pearl: Chronic pancreatitis and pancreatic exocrine insufficiency: TIGAR-O classification system

Toxic-metabolic

  • Alcoholic
  • Tobacco smoking
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hyperlipidemia
  • Chronic renal failure
  • Medications—phenacetin abuse
  • Toxins—organotin compounds (e.g., dibutyltin dichloride, DBTC)

Idiopathic

  • Early onset
  • Late onset
  • Tropical

Genetic

  • Cationic trypsinogen (PRSS1)
  • Cystic fibrosis transmembrane conductance regulator gene (CFTR)
  • Calcium-sensing receptor (CASR)
  • Chymotrypsin C gene (CTRC)
  • Pancreatic secretory trypsin inhibitor gene (SPINK1)

Autoimmune

  • Type 1 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis
  • IgG4 systemic
  • Type 2 autoimmune chronic pancreatitis

Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis

  • Postnecrotic (severe acute pancreatitis)
  • Recurrent acute pancreatitis
  • Vascular diseases/ischemia
  • Radiation-induced

Obstructive

  • Pancreas divisum
  • Duct obstruction (e.g., tumor)
  • Periampullary duodenal wall cysts
  • Posttraumatic pancreatic duct scars

questions.text: Which of the following is true about DNA replication?

choices.text: Replication can occur only from a single stranded DNA template
Replication can occur only from a double stranded DNA template
Deoxynucleotide polymerization is catalyzed by helicases
Only DNA polymerase functions at the replication fork

questions.solution:
In all cells, replication can occur only from a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) template.

Steps of DNA replication:

  • Identification of the origins of replication
  • ATP hydrolysis-driven unwinding of dsDNA to provide an ssDNA template
  • Formation of the replication fork; synthesis of RNA primer
  • Initiation of DNA synthesis and elongation
  • Formation of replication bubbles with ligation of the newly synthesized DNA segments
  • Reconstitution of chromatin structure

The replication fork is formed when DNA helicase unwinds a short segment of the parent dsDNA. Primase initiates the synthesis of an RNA primer. DNA polymerase then initiates DNA synthesis (deoxynucleotide polymerisation) in the 3' to 5' direction. Hence, helicase, primase and polymerases act at the replication fork.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Prokaryotic DNA replication enzymes and their function:

Enzyme Function
DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) Gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination
DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair
DNA polymerase III (Pol III)

Processive, leading strand synthesis, DNA proofreading
DnaG

Primase 
Helicase ATP-driven processive unwinding of DNA.
Primase Initiates synthesis of RNA primers.
Topoisomerase Relieve torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.
Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

 

Eukaryotic DNA polymerases:

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases Functions Proofreading
α  Primase (initiates DNA synthesis) -
β DNA repair -

γ

 Mitochondrial DNA synthesis +
 δ  Processive, lagging strand synthesis(forms and elongates Okazaki fragments from primer) +
 ε  Processive, leading strand synthesis +

questions.text: The IVP imaging of a 30-year-old woman is given below. What is it diagnostic of?
questions.solution:
The given intravenous pyelogram is characteristic for medullary sponge kidney. It shows ectatic distal collecting ducts containing microcalcifications, which is called bouquet of flowers appearance. Dilated contrast-filled tubules within the renal medulla are also seen, which is known as paintbrush appearance. 

This is a developmental defect affecting the formation of collecting tubules and results in cystic dilatation of the medullary and papillary portions of collecting ducts.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of hydronephrosis detected during prenatal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of hydronephrosis on prenatal ultrasound among the given options.

The Etiology of Antenatal Hydronephrosis:

Aetiology Incidence
Transient hydronephrosis 41–88%
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction 10–30%
Vesicoureteral reflux 10–20%
Ureterocele/ectopic ureter/duplex system 5–7% 
Posterior urethral valve/urethral atresia 1–2% 

In UPJ obstruction, hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound. It can however be transient or mild and resolves on its own.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are:

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (eg. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

It is usually associated with renal anomalies and has a 2:1 male-to-female ratio. After birth, re-checking needs to be done and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and cases of failure to thrive. If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys. The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. MAG3 (mercaptoacetyl triglycine) which measures tubular function has largely replaced the usage of Tc99- DTPA. The kidneys with decreased function show slower uptake and take a longer time to excrete the tracer. It is even preferred over intravenous pyelogram for assessment of hydronephrosis in newborns and children because IVP images are suboptimal in presence of bowel gas and poor dye uptake in newborn kidneys.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or bilateral kidneys are involved. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

questions.text: A drug solution containing 500 mg/5 ml of the drug is given to you. You are provided with a 2 ml syringe (having 10 divisions for each ml). How many divisions of the 2 ml syringe need to be administered to deliver 180 mg of the drug to a patient?
questions.solution:
Concentration of drug solution given = 500/5 ml or 100 mg/ml

-> 100 mg of drug in 1ml

i.e 180 mg of drug in "X" ml

-> X = 180/100 = 1.8 ml

So, 1.8 ml of the drug with 180 mg of the drug is to be given to the patient.

 

In the 2 ml syringe provided, each ml has 10 divisions i.e. each division corresponds to 0.1 ml.

So, for delivering 1.8 ml, 1.8/0.1= 18 divisions need to be administered.

questions.text: The lesion in the below-given image is a side effect of:
questions.solution:
Image shows bull’s eye macular lesion, characterized by a foveolar island of pigment surrounded by a depigmented zone of RPE atrophy, which is itself encircled by a hyperpigmented ring.

It is a side effect of Chloroquine.

Other causes are:

  • Cone dystrophy
  • Cone-rod dystrophy
  • Ceroid lipofuscinosis
  • Stargardt's and fundus flavimaculatus
  • Fenestrated sheen macular dystrophy
  • Parafoveal atrophy of RPE secondary to AMD
  • Central areolar choroidal dystrophy
  • Benign concentric annular macular dystrophy
  • Juvenile Batten's disease
  • Fucosidosis
  • Clofazimine maculopathy

questions.text: Which of the following is used in the treatment of late cardiovascular syphilis?

choices.text: Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks
Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units as single dose
Benzathine penicillin 12-24 million units for 21 days

questions.solution:
Benzathine penicillin 2.4 million units weekly for three weeks is the treatment of late cardiovascular syphilis.

The treatment of syphilis is based on the CDC’s 2015 guidelines:

Stage of Syphilis Patients without Penicillin Allergy Patients with Confirmed Penicillin Allergy
Primary, Secondary and early latent

CSF Normal or not examined: Penicillin G benzathine     (single dose 2.4mU IM) 

CSF Abnormal: Treat as Neurosyphilis

CSF normal or not examined: Tetracycline HCl (500 mg PO qid)

OR

Doxycycline(100 mg PO bid) for 2 weeks CSF abnormal: Treat as neurosyphilis
Late latent (or latent of uncertain duration), Cardiovascular or benign tertiary

CSF Normal or not examined: Penicillin G benzathine          2.4 mU IM weekly for 3 weeks  

CSF Abnormal: Treat as Neurosyphilis

CSF normal and patient not infected with HIV: Tetracycline HCl (500 mg PO qid)

OR

Doxycycline (100 mg PO bid) for 4 weeks 

CSF normal and patient infected with HIV: Desensitization and treatment with penicillin if compliance cannot be ensured 

CSF abnormal: Treat as neurosyphilis
Neurosyphilis (asymptomatic or symptomatic)

Aqueous crystalline penicillin G (18-24 mU/d IV),              given as 3-4mU q4h or continuous infusion for 10-14 days.

OR

Aqueous procaine penicillin G (2.4mU/d IM)                         +                                      Oral probenecid(500mg qid), both for 10-14 days.

 Desensitization and treatment with penicillin
Syphilis in Pregnancy According to stage Desensitization and treatment with penicillin 

 

Note:

mU is a million units, not milli-units.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided facial paralysis and left-sided limb weakness for the past 1 hour. Her blood pressure is 160/100 mm Hg and her CT appears normal. What would be the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis with apparently normal CT indicates ischemic stroke in this patient. Intravenous thrombolysis(alteplase 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period i.e., within 3-4.5 hours of symptom onset.

Aspirin + clopidogrel(Option B) is used in secondary prevention of stroke and also to prevent stroke following TIA.

Transient ischemic attacks (TIAs) refer to episodes of stroke symptoms that have a brief duration, the standard definition of duration is <24 h, but most TIAs last <1 hr. TIAs may arise from emboli to the brain or from in situ thrombosis of an intracranial vessel. With a TIA, the occluded blood vessel reopens and neurologic function is restored. If a relevant brain infarction is identified on brain imaging, the clinical entity is now classified as stroke regardless of the duration of symptoms.

The risk of stroke following a transient ischemic attack (TIA) is approximately 10-15% in the first three months, majorly in the first two days. A reliable estimation of this risk can be obtained using the ABCD2 score. 

Other options: 

Option A: If CT is normal it only rules out hemorrhagic stroke and changes of ischemic stroke usually take time to appear on NCCT.

Option D: BP control is done when BP exceeds 220/120 mmHg, if there is malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg and thrombolytic therapy is anticipated. 

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text:
A 56-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department with sudden onset headache and photophobia. On examination, she is disoriented and febrile. The investigations and peripheral smear are given below. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this disease?

Hemoglobin - 11.2 g/dl

Platelet count - 32,000/uL

Serum creatinine - 3.9 mg/dl

Blood urea nitrogen - 38 mg/dl

choices.text: It is caused by ADAMTS13 deficiency
20% patients  will have falsely positive  RA factor
Arrhythmias are a frequent cause of death
Mainstay of treatment is blood transfusion

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing schistocytes (fragmented RBCs) in a woman are suggestive of thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura (TTP). Blood transfusion is not preferred in TTP as it can aggravate the condition.

TTP is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that occurs due to deficiency or autoantibodies against the ADAMTS13 metalloprotease, which is responsible for cleaving von Willebrand factor multimers. In the absence of this protein, vWF multimers aggregate and form thrombi. It presents with a classical pentad of clinical features:

  1. Fever
  2. Thrombocytopenia
  3. Microangiopathic hemolytic anemia
  4. Renal failure
  5. Neurological manifestations

It is treated with plasmapheresis and rituximab.

questions.text: The finding in the below-given image is seen in a case of:
questions.solution:
The image findings show Hollenhorst plaques are seen in central retinal artery occlusion (CRAO).

They are the cholesterol emboli seen in retinal arterioles. The most common cause of CRAO (Central retinal artery occlusion) is embolism.

The outer retina is supplied by the ciliary arteries while the inner retina is supplied by the central retinal artery (CRA). Both sets of arteries are branches of the ophthalmic artery. Arterial occlusion can occur due to atherosclerosis (most cases), inflammation, vasospasm, and hypotension.

The ophthalmic artery is the first branch of the internal carotid artery, so any emboli from the carotid arteries can lead to CRAO. 

The emboli that are refractile, yellow-white in color, and made of cholesterol are called Hollenhorst plaques. Emboli can also be greyish, elongated fibrin-platelet aggregates, or non-scintillating white calcific particles. 

The goal of treatment is to restore blood flow. Antiplatelet therapy, decreasing intraocular pressure with timolol, acetazolamide and mannitol, and thrombolytic can be used. Rebreathing into a paper bag will help increase CO2 and consequently arterial vasodilation. 

Other options: 

Option B - Central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO) would have fundoscopy features of deep blot and flame-shaped hemorrhages in the posterior and peripheral retina and cotton wool spots.

The below image shows flame-shaped hemorrhages in CRVO.

 Option C - Cystoid macular edema occurs when there is fluid accumulation in the outer plexiform and inner nuclear layers of the retina with cyst-like cavities. It would have fundoscopy features of loss of foveal depression, thickening of the retina, and multiple cystoid areas in the sensory retina. There may be optic disc swelling and a lamellar hole. 

Option D - Central serous retinopathy is characterized by localized serous detachment of the retina at the macula due to leakage from the choriocapillaris. Detachment would be visible on fundoscopy with clear or turbid subretinal fluid, depigment retinal pigment epithelium, and atrophic damage.

questions.text: Among the water-soluble radiological contrasts, Iodine: particle ratio is highest in?
questions.solution:
Non ionic dimers have highest iodine particle ratio of 6:1.

Contrast agents can be divided into water-soluble (iodine-containing) and non-water-soluble (barium) compounds.

Classification of iodinated contrast:

  • Ionic – Monomer and dimer
  • Non ionic– Monomer and dimer

Ionic monomer has Iodine: particle ratio of 3:2. They have an osmolarity of 1400-1600 mOsm. Ionic monomers are not preferred due to high osmolarity. They have advantages of forming better images in IVP and having anticoagulant property. Examples are:

  • Urograffin – Sodium/Meglumine diatrizoate
  • Conray – Iothalamate

Ionic dimer has Iodine: particle ratio of 6:2 or 3:1 and osmolality of 600-800 mOsm. Ioxaglate is an example. Dye has retained its anticoagulant property despite a low osmolarity.

Non-ionic monomer has Iodine: particle ratio of 3:1 and osmolarity of 600 – 800 mOsm.  Examples are:

  • Iohexol (Omnipaque) - commonly used
  • Ioversol (Optiray)
  • Iopamidol

Non-ionic Dimer has particle ratio of 6:1. The osmolarity is 300 mOsm, hence it is iso-osmolar to plasma. e.g Iodixanol

questions.text: Causes of precocious puberty in girls are all except:
questions.solution:
In Prader Willi syndrome, there is hypogonadism and hence sexual development is delayed.

Other options:

  • Hypothalamic hamartomas that secrete excess gonadotropins-releasing hormone are responsible for a significant proportion of cases of precocious puberty.
  • McCune-Albright syndrome is a cause of peripheral precocious puberty, where cutaneous pigmentation and fibrous dysplasia of the skeletal system are also seen.
  • In hypothyroidism, though puberty is delayed in adolescents, pseudo-precocious puberty may be seen in younger children as a result of abnormally high TSH concentrations binding to FSH receptors with subsequent stimulation.

questions.text: The given sign is most prominent after how many hours of death?
questions.solution:
This picture shows postmortem marbling, i.e. greenish brown or purplish red discoloration of superficial veins. It becomes most prominent after 36-48 hours of death. 

Marbling is seen when blood in the vessels is hemolyzed to sulfmeth-hemoglobin, which stains the vessel walls and the adjacent tissues, giving rise to a marbled appearance. The marbling of the skin begins at about 24 hours and becomes prominent in 36–48 hours after death.

It is a visible postmortem change that is characterized by linear branching patterns on skin that correspond to the course of superficial veins. Intestinal bacteria infest the venous system, and there is subsequent gas production and hemolysis, which stains the vessel walls. This becomes prominent in the summer and is distinctly appreciable in the superficial veins of the abdomen, shoulders, chest, and inguinal region.

On examination, a palpable mass in the right lower quadrant of the abdomen is found. Stool cultures are normal. Colonoscopy shows the presence of skip lesions. questions.text: In the following pressure-volume loop diagram of left ventricle, the mitral valve will close at the point:
questions.solution:
The closure of the mitral valve corresponds to point 2, which marks the beginning of the isovolumetric contraction phase.

 The pressure-volume curve represents the changes in volume and pressure in the left ventricle during a single cardiac cycle. The relationship between ventricular pressure (Y-axis) and volume (X-axis) throughout the cardiac cycle is represented by this loop.

  • Point 1 - Mitral valve opens
  • Point 2 - Mitral valve closes
  • Point 3 - Aortic valve opens
  • Point 4 - Aortic valve closes

Phase I: Period of filling:  

  • In the given diagram, the period of filling lasts from point 1 to point 2.
  • At point A, the volume of blood present in the left ventricle is the end-systolic volume which corresponds to about 50 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve opens and the venous blood flows into the left ventricle from the left atrium.
  • At point B, the end of the period of filling—the amount of blood present in the left ventricle is called the end-diastolic volume which corresponds to about 120 ml. It is at this point that the mitral valve closes.

Phase II: Period of isovolumic contraction:

  • In the given diagram, the period of isovolumetric contraction lasts from point 2 to point 3.
  • At point B, the mitral valve closes and the volume of the ventricle does not change as all the valves are closed. However, the pressure inside the ventricle continues to rise.
  • At point C the ventricular pressure increases to become equal to the pressure in the aorta (80 mm Hg) and then the aortic valve opens.

Phase III: Period of ejection

  • In the given diagram, the period of ejection lasts from point 3 to point 4.
  • At point C, the aortic valve opens and the volume of the ventricle decreases as the blood flows out of the ventricle into the aorta.
  • The systolic pressure continues to rise as the ventricle contracts.
  • At point D the aortic valve closes.

Phase IV: Period of isovolumic relaxation

  • In the given diagram, the period of relaxation lasts from point 4 to point 1.
  • At point D, the aortic valve closes and the ventricular pressure falls back to the diastolic pressure level. 
  • This decrease in intraventricular pressure occurs without any change in volume.
  • At point A, the ventricle now has an end-systolic volume of 50 ml of blood similar to the beginning of the cycle.

questions.text: Revised Ghent criteria takes into account all of the following except___________

choices.text: Cardinal clinical signs in absence of family history
Presence or absence of fibrillin mutation

questions.solution:
Revised Ghent criteria does not take into account the presence of defective collagen synthesis.

Clinical diagnosis of Marfan syndrome is currently based on the revised Ghent criteria which takes into account:

  • Family history
  • Cardinal clinical signs in absence of family history
  • Presence or absence of fibrillin mutation

In general major involvement of two major organ systems (skeletal, cardiovascular, ocular and skin) and minor involvement of another organ is required for diagnosis.

Marfan’s syndrome: It is an autosomal dominant connective tissue disorder.

  • This autosomal dominant syndrome has pleiotropic manifestations involving primarily the ocular, cardiovascular, and skeletal systems.
  • Occurs due to a missense mutation in the fibrillin-1 gene located on chromosome 15 at band q21.1 (15q21.1).

Morphological features:

  1. Skeletal abnormalities:
    1. Typically the patient is unusually tall with exceptionally long extremities and long, tapering fingers and toes.
    2. Hyperextensibility due to laxity of joint ligaments.
    3. The head is commonly dolichocephalic (long-headed).
    4. A variety of spinal deformities may appear, including kyphosis, scoliosis, or rotation or slipping of the dorsal or lumbar vertebrae.
    5. The chest is classically deformed, presenting either pectus excavatum (deeply depressed sternum) or a pigeon-breast deformity.
  2. Ocular changes:
    1. Most characteristic is bilateral subluxation or dislocation (usually outward and upward) of the lens, referred to as ectopia lentis.
  3. Cardiovascular lesions:
    1. Most life-threatening features of this disorder. The two most common lesions are mitral valve prolapse and, of greater importance, dilation of the ascending aorta due to cystic medial necrosis.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is warfarin induced skin necrosis seen?
questions.solution:
Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is seen in patients with congenital or acquired deficiencies of protein C or protein S.

Warfarin-induced skin necrosis:

  • Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is seen in patients with congenital or acquired deficiencies of protein C or protein S. Initiation of warfarin therapy in these patients produces a precipitous fall in plasma levels of proteins C or S, thereby eliminating this important anticoagulant pathway before warfarin exerts an antithrombotic effect through lowering of the functional levels of factor X and prothrombin.
  • The resultant procoagulant state triggers thrombosis.
  • A rare complication of warfarin, skin necrosis usually is seen 2–5 days after initiation of therapy.
  • Well-demarcated erythematous lesions form on the thighs, buttocks, breasts, or toes.
  • Typically, the center of the lesion becomes progressively necrotic.
  • Examination of skin biopsies taken from the border of these lesions reveals thrombi in the microvasculature.
  • Treatment involves discontinuation of warfarin and reversal with vitamin K, if needed. An alternative anticoagulant, such as heparin or LMWH, should be given in patients with thrombosis. Protein C concentrate can be given to protein C–deficient patients to accelerate healing of the skin lesions.
  • Occasionally, skin grafting is necessary when there is extensive skin loss.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is consistent with a diagnosis of myocardial infarction?
questions.solution:
LDH 1>LDH 2 is known as the flipped LDH pattern. It is suggestive of myocardial infarction.

Under normal conditions, LDH 2 is predominantly present in the blood and LDH 1 is predominantly present in the heart. When cardiac tissue is damaged LDH 1 is released into the bloodstream.

LDH is a tetrameric enzyme with 4 subunits. It has four subunits with two isoforms: H isoform (heart) and M isoform (muscle)

LDH Type  Composition Location
LDH-1 HHHH Heart and RBC
LDH-2 HHHM Heart and RBC
LDH-3 HHMM Lungs, brain, lymphatic tissues, and platelets
LDH-4 HMMM Liver and skeletal muscle
LDH-5 MMMM Liver and skeletal muscle

questions.text: A 35-year-old man died in a road traffic accident. On autopsy, the following appearance of the kidney was noted. Which of the following is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Cysts in liver, pancreas, and spleen

questions.solution:
The gross image suggests that the patient had autosomal-dominant polycystic kidney disease (ADPKD). This condition is not associated with hepatic fibrosis. However, patients with autosomal recessive (childhood) polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD) have congenital hepatic fibrosis.

ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 
  • Hepatic cysts - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts 
  • Splenic cysts
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse 
There are very few case reports with lung cysts in ADPKD patients, but the association between ADPKD and lung cysts has not been proved. However, there is a three-fold increase in the incidence of bronchiectasis in ADPKD patients. 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text: Which is the monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
The monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of rheumatoid arthritis is sarilumab.

It is an IL-6 receptor antagonist indicated for the treatment of adults with moderate to severe rheumatoid arthritis who show inadequate response or intolerance to one or more disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs (DMARDs).

Option A: Durvalumab is an anti PD-L1 antibody approved for metastatic urothelial cancer.

Option C: Nivolumab is a fully human monoclonal IgG4 antibody that blocks the interaction between PD-1 (Programmed cell Death-1) receptor and its ligands.

Option D: Pembrolizumab (formerly called lambrolizumab or MK-3475) is a humanized monoclonal IgG4-κ isotype antibody that blocks the interaction between PD-1 and its ligands. Nivolumab and pembrolizumab are used to treat advanced melanoma.

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cardioselective beta blocker with antioxidant property?
questions.solution:
Nebivolol is a cardioselective beta-blocker with additional antioxidant property.

Nebivolol:

  • Nebivolol is a third-generation, long-acting, and highly selective β1 adrenergic receptor antagonist
  • It stimulates NO-mediated vasodilation via β3 receptor agonism
  • Nebivolol is approved for the treatment of hypertension
  • It has potential utility in the treatment of heart failure with reduced ejection fraction
  • Nebivolol reduces oxidative stress and may have favorable effects on both carbohydrate and lipid metabolism
  • This can be used in metabolic syndrome.

Related Pearl: Cardioselective beta blockers: Mnemonic

Cardioselective Beta blockers Act At Nothing But Myocardium Exclusively.

  • C: Celiprolol ( III )
  • B: Bisoprolol
  • A: Acebutolol
  • A: Atenolol
  • N: Nebivolol ( III )
  • B: Betaxolol ( III )
  • M: Metoprolol
  • E: Esmolol

( III ) - Third generation beta blockers. All the others are second generation beta blockers

questions.text: A study was conducted on the effectiveness of a keto diet for weight loss. Weight of the participants was measured before starting the keto diet and after 1 month of the keto diet.  Which of the following is the most appropriate test to test the statistical significance of the change in weight?
questions.solution:
Since the effect of keto diet is checked on the same individuals, before and after the keto diet, therefore the test used is paired t test.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl with a seizure disorder is started on phenytoin therapy. Which of the following must be supplemented in this patient?

Usage of phenytoin leads to folate deficiency and megaloblastic anemia. Hence, folic acid must be supplemented.
