questions.text: All are true about first trimester abortion except

choices.text: Mifepristone 200 mg oral given on day 1
Suction evacuation is done at around 7-12 weeks
Medical outpatient abortion is effective upto 9 weeks

questions.solution:
Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal suppository is given for second trimester abortion and not first trimester abortion.

Dinoprostone gel (PGE2 analog) was used for cervical ripening and resulted in a shorter induction abortion interval which is much beneficial in seconfd trimester than the first trimester. Also, it is quite expensive and needs refrigeration.

Misoprostol, a synthetic analogue of PGE1 being much cheaper, safe and capable of being easily stored at room temperature has been tried by both oral and vaginal routes.

Suction evacuation is done at around 7-12 weeks. For suction abortion done at <6 weeks gestation, a distinct drawback is that the pregnancy may be small and missed by the curette. To identiy placenta, the aspirated contents are rinsed in a strainer to remove blood, and then placed in a clear plastic container with saline and examined with back lighting. Placental tissue macroscopically appears soft, fluffy, and feathery.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9weeks)

First trimester 

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol


Misoprostol only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually or buccally.

 

Methotrexate/Misoprostol

(d) Methotrexate, 50 mg/m2 body surface area intramuscularly or orally; followed in 3-7 days by:

(e) Misoprostol, 800 mcg vaginally. Repeat if needed 1 week after methotrexate initially given
Second Trimester

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended) : 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Misoprostol Alone(Alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Dinoprostone

20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr

Concentrated Oxytocin

50 units oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused during 3 hr; then 1-hr diuresis (no oxytocin); then escalate sequentially in a similar fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units oxytocin each in 500 mL normal saline

questions.text: A 67-year-old patient presented with swelling around the knee, restriction of movement and minimal or no pain. The x-ray of the knee is given below. The diagnosis is _________.
questions.solution:
The x-ray depicts severe joint destruction and instability, seen on (a) varus stress (b)Neutral (c) valgus stress on the patient's knee joint. There is minimal pain and this indicates a neuropathic cause like Charcot arthropathy.

Diabetes is the most common cause of Charcot arthropathy, while tertiary syphilis was one of the common causes previously.

Rheumatoid arthritis, osteoarthritis and psoriatic arthropathy present with pain.

questions.text: Which of the following does not supply the palate?
questions.solution:
The tonsillar branch of facial artery supplies the palatine tonsil and not the palate.

Blood supply of the palate:

  • Hard palate - greater (descending) palatine artery which is a branch of the third part of the maxillary artery.
  • Soft palate - ascending palatine branch of the facial artery, ascending pharyngeal artery, and lesser palatine arteries.

questions.text: Which of the following is not associated with cancer risk?
questions.solution:
Schatzki’s ring is not associated with cancer risk.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal ring encircling lumen of the esophagus, usually situated at the squamocolumnar junction. It is associated with Hiatal hernia and gastroesophageal reflux. Schatzki ring is one of the most common causes of intermittent food impaction. Also known as "steakhouse syndrome" because meat is a typical instigator.

The best form of treatment of a symptomatic Schatzki’s ring in patients who do not have reflux consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients with a ring who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is necessary to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Eosophageal achalasia and zenker's diverticulum are linked with metaplasia and increased risk of cancer.

Pseudoachalasia is caused by an adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

Related Pearl: Achalasia Cardia

Achalasia cardia is a rare disease caused by the loss of ganglion cells within the esophageal myenteric plexus. Their absence leads to increased tone of the lower esophageal sphincter, impaired relaxation of the lower esophageal sphincter (LES), and absent peristalsis.

Achalasia is the only true motility disorder of the esophagus.

  • Primary achalasia is due to ganglion cell degeneration and is thought to be due to an autoimmune process attributable to latent infection with human herpes simplex virus 1 (HSV1) combined with genetic susceptibility.
  • Secondary achalasia may arise in Chaga's disease.

Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia (solid and liquid food)
  • Regurgitation
  • Chest pain
  • Weight loss
  • Bronchitis, pneumonia, or lung abscess from aspiration

Differential diagnosis: Diffuse esophageal spasm, pseudoachalasia

On barium swallow: Bird beak-appearance

Investigation of choice: Manometry (most sensitive)

Treatment: Pneumatic dilatation, Heller myotomy

questions.text: Abnormalities related to P300 evoked potential on EEG is reported in which of the following disease?
questions.solution:
An abnormal ‘P300’ evoked potential is seen in schizophrenia.

Abnormalities related to the following evoked potentials may be seen on EEG in patients with schizophrenia,

  • P300: It is a large, positive wave which occurs 300 mil­liseconds after a sensory stimulus is detected.
  • N100: It is a negative wave that occurs 100 milliseconds after a stimulus.
  • Contingent negative variation: It is a slow developing negative wave that occurs after a stimulus and serves as a warning for an upcoming stimulus.

questions.text: Zuska’s disease refers to

choices.text: Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of breast
Benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages

questions.solution:
Zuska’s disease, also called recurrent periductal mastitis, is a condition of recurrent retro areolar infections and abscesses.

Smoking has been implicated as a risk factor for this condition.

Treatment: Managed symptomatically by antibiotics coupled with incision and drainage as necessary.

Option a: Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of the breast is referred to as Mondor’s disease.

Option b: Benign inflammation of one or more costal cartilages is referred to as Tietze’s syndrome.

Option d: Stewart Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma in chronic long-standing lymphoedema following mastectomy.

questions.text: What is the drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus?
questions.solution:
The drug of choice for lithium-induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is amiloride.

Amiloride belongs to the K+-sparing diuretic group. It is a renal epithelial Na+ channel(ENac) inhibitor in collecting duct cells. Lithium enters through the ENac and inhibits the action of the anti-diuretic hormone. Amiloride blocks the entry of Li+ ion through the ENac and thus mitigates diabetes insipidus induced by lithium.

The most important adverse effect of amiloride is hyperkalemia. Other adverse effects include nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, and headache.

Other options:

Option A: Demeclocycline belongs to the tetracycline group of antibiotics. It interferes with the anti-diuretic hormone action but is used in the treatment of the syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone(SIADH). 

Option B: Thiazide diuretics inhibit the Na+-Cl- symport present in the distal convoluted tubule of the nephron. It is used in the treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus by decreasing the ability of the kidney to excrete free water. It increases the reabsorption of water in the proximal tubule and reduces the ability of the distal tubule to dilute the urine. 

Option C: Tolvaptan is a vasopressin antagonist used in the treatment of SIADH, hypervolemic and euvolemic hyponatremia.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about infant larynx?

choices.text: Epiglottis is soft and omega shaped
Larynx positioned at the level of C2-C3
Supra glottis is the narrowest part

questions.solution:
Subglottis(not supraglottis) is the narrowest part of infant larynx.

Laryngeal cartilages  Soft and collapsible  Ossified and hard

questions.text: The patient whose hands are shown in the image below is developmentally delayed with a short, stocky build. Which of the following laboratory values is consistent with this condition?
questions.solution:
Considering the given options, based on the history and the image showing a short 4th metacarpal, the most likely diagnosis is pseudohypoparathyroidism. It is characterized by hypocalcemia, hyperphosphatemia, and high PTH. 

Pseudohypoparathyroidism occurs due to mutations in GNAS gene, leading to the formation of defective Gsα protein. This means that end-organ effects of PTH are hampered in patients suffering from pseudohypoparathyroidism. Even though PTH levels are high, it is not able to perform its normal function. Hypocalcemia is seen in these patients due to insufficient calcitriol production in the proximal renal tubules and consequent impaired intestinal calcium absorption. Urinary phosphate excretion is also impaired, causing hyperphosphatemia. 

Most patients with pseudohypoparathyroidism have characteristic skeletal features. These include short stature, early-onset obesity, round face, short metacarpals, and short metatarsals. This complex of skeletal abnormalities are referred to as Albright's hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). Treatment of pseudohypoparathyroidism consists of a high dose of calcium and activated vitamin D (calcitriol).

  Pseudo-hypoparathyroidism Pseudo-pseudo-hypoparathyroidism
AHO features Present Present
Serum calcium Decreased Normal
Serum phosphate Increased Normal
Serum PTH Increased Normal
Urinary cAMP on administering PTH Decreased response

Normal response
Resistance to other hormones Present Absent

questions.text: Which anticoagulant is used for electrolyte estimation?
questions.solution:
Lithium heparin is used for Electrolyte estimation.

Heparin

  • It is the anticoagulant causing the least interference with the test.
  • It is the best anticoagulant to use when minimal hemolysis is desired e.g. for sodium and potassium.
  • Heparin accelerates the action of antithrombin III which neutralizes thrombin and thus prevents the formation of fibrin from fibrinogen.
  • Heparin is added (0.2 mg /mL of blood) or a drop of heparin is drawn into the syringe.
  • Usually found as green top tubes
  • Drawbacks
    • It inhibits the acid phosphatase activity.
    • It gives a blue background for Wright’s stain smears so not good for peripheral blood smear interpretation.
    • It also affects the binding of triiodothyronine and thyroxine to their carrier protein and produces a higher free concentration of these hormones.
    • It interferes with binding of calcium to EDTA.

questions.text: A lesion reported as BIRADS grade 4b, has a _______% chance of being malignant
questions.solution:
A lesion reported as BIRADS grade 4b, has a 10-49% chance of being malignant.

BIRADS Grade

  • Grade 3: < 2% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 4:
    • 4a: 2 - 9% chance of being malignant
    • 4b: 10 - 49% chance of being malignant
    • 4c: 50 - 94% chance of being malignant
  • Grade 5: ≥ 95% chance of being malignant

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy

questions.text: Tidal volume is_____

choices.text: Inspiratory capacity minus inspiratory reserve volume

questions.solution:
The tidal volume = inspiratory capacity - inspiratory reserve volume.

Related Pearl: Lung volumes and capacities

The amount of air that moves into the lungs with each inspiration (or the amount that moves out with each expiration) during quiet breathing

questions.text: A 60-year-old male came to the hospital with complaints of diplopia, and progressive headache. Examination of extraocular movements revealed the findings as shown in the image, when the patient attempted to look right. Lesion involving which cranial nerve marked in the image below is likely to cause the condition, and which eye is affected?
questions.solution:
The clinical finding shown in the image is suggestive of lateral rectus palsy of the right eye, which occurs due to the lesion involving right abducens nerve. In the given image, showing the base of the brain, the right abducens nerve is marked as ‘3’.

The Abducens nerve arises from the brainstem between the pons and medulla oblongata. It enters the orbit through the superior orbital fissure and innervates the lateral rectus muscle through its medial (ocular surface).

Determining the palsy:

The abduction and adduction of the eye are caused by the action of the lateral rectus and medial rectus muscles respectively.

The lateral rectus is innervated by abducens nerve (VI) while the medial rectus is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (III).

Horizontal conjugate movements occur when both eyes moves horizontally to look right or left.

  • In right gaze: The right eye abducts and the left eye adducts.
  • In left gaze: The right eye adducts and the left eye abducts.

In the image, when the patient attempted to look right, the left eye adducted normally, while the right eye failed to abduct. This is suggestive of right lateral rectus palsy due to the lesion involving the right abducens nerve.

Note: If the same finding as shown in the image is seen when the patient is looking straight (neutral gaze), then the affected eye is the left eye. In such case, due to left lateral rectus palsy, the action of left medial rectus is unopposed causing adduction of the left eye.

Related Pearl: Extraocular Muscles and Their Actions

questions.text: Diagnostic criteria for primary abdominal pregnancy is
questions.solution:
The criteria laid down by Studdiford is used to diagnose primary abdominal pregnancy.

Site of pregnancy Criteria Management
Primary abdominal pregnancy

Studdiford's criteria

  • Both the tubes and ovaries should be normal
  • Absence of uteroperitoneal fistula
  • Pregnancy must be exclusively related to the peritoneal surface 
 Surgical management
Ovarian pregnancy

Spiegelberg's criteria

  • The tube on the affected side must be intact
  • Gestational sac must occupy the position of the ovary
  • Gestational sac connected to the uterus by ovarian ligament
  • Definite ovarian tissue must be found in the sac wall
 Surgical management
Cervical pregnancy

Rubin's criteria (Palmatic's criteria)

  • The uterus is smaller than surrounding distended cervix
  • Internal os is not dilated
  • Curettage of the endometrial cavity is nonproductive of placental tissue
  • External os opens earlier than in spontaneous abortion
  • Medical management if vitals are stable
  • Surgical management if vitals are unstable

questions.solution:
Services provided through ICDS scheme Anganwadi workers:

  • Supplementary nutrition
  • Infant & Young Child feeding (IYCF) Promotion & Counselling

questions.text: A study was conducted in a school to compare the heights of children of different grades. The children from 5th grade to 10th grade, were divided according to their grades, and their heights were measured. The appropriate statistical test of significance that should be used is ______
questions.solution:
Since more than two groups (from 5th class to 10th class) are compared in the above study, ANOVA test should be used.

Analysis of variance or ANOVA is used when more than 2 groups (means) are compared for difference.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: The antidiabetic drug that does not act by increasing insulin secretion is?
questions.solution:
Canagliflozin is a SGLT2 inhibitor that inhibits the sodium-glucose cotransporter localted in the proximal portion of the renal tubule.

It blocks glucose transport in the proximal tubule and lower blood glucose by promoting urinary loss.

Glimipiride and repaglinide are insulin secretagogues (options a and c).

Vildagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor and indirectly increases insulin secretion by prolonging the action of GLP-1 (option b).

questions.text: All of the following are true about autoimmune gastritis except:

choices.text: Auto-antibodies to parietal cells and intrinsic factor

questions.solution:
• Autoimmune gastritis is associated with hypergastrinemia.
  • Autoimmune gastritis is characterized by:
    • Antibodies to parietal cells which are responsible for the secretion of gastric acid and intrinsic factor.
    • Reduced serum pepsinogen I concentration.
    • Endocrine cell hyperplasia.
    • Vitamin B12 deficiency.
    • Defective gastric acid secretion (achlorhydria).

questions.text: Which of the following statements are false with respect to the inverse stretch reflex?
questions.solution:
Option D is a false statement as the inverse stretch reflex can be stimulated by a passive stretch as well as an active contraction.

When the tension in the muscle increases and surpasses a limit, contraction suddenly ceases and the muscle relaxes. This relaxation in response to an overt stretch is called the inverse stretch reflex.

The receptor involved in this reflex is the Golgi tendon organ (Option B). The Golgi tendon organ consists of a net-like collection of nerve endings that are arranged in series (Option C) within the muscle fibers. This arrangement allows for Golgi tendon organs to be stimulated by both active contraction and passive stretch of the muscle, unlike muscle spindles. One Golgi tendon organ innervates 3-25 muscle fibers. 

The afferents from the Golgi tendon organ are the Ib myelinated nerve fibers. The Ib nerve fibers synapse with inhibitory interneurons present in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the motor neurons supplying the muscles. Thus, this is a disynaptic reflex (Option A).

Related Pearl: Summary of Muscle Reflexes

Reflex

Number of synapses

Stimulus

Stretch reflex

(knee-jerk)

Monosynaptic

Muscle is stretched

Ia

Contraction of the muscle

Golgi tendon reflex/ Inverse stretch reflex (clasp-knife)

Disynaptic

Muscle contraction

Ib

Relaxation of muscle

Flexor-withdrawal reflex (after touching a hot stove)

Polysynaptic

Pain

II, III, and IV

Ipsilateral flexion; contralateral extension

questions.text: A 10 year old malnourished girl with severe anemia and fatigue whose fecal exam detects the egg given in the image. What was the most likely means by which this child was infected?
questions.solution:
This child has the typical symptoms of hookworm disease.

The infection is acquired by penetration of the filariform larvae through the skin of the feet or buttocks, after contamination of soil with the eggs of the agent deposited in human feces.

The eggs are oval and thin-shelled and contain a clearly visible four to eight-cell stage embryo. There is a characteristic clear space between the shell and the developing embryo.

Ascaris egg morphology:

Fertilized and unfertilized Ascaris lumbricoides eggs are passed in stool of the infected host.

  • Fertilized eggs are are rounded and have a thick shell with an external mammillated layer that is often stained brown by bile. 
  • In some cases, the outer layer is absent (known as decorticated eggs).
  • Infertile eggs may be oval or irregularly shaped with a thin shell and containing refractile granules.

Transmission is through the fecal-oral route, usually through the ingestion of eggs.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: Identify the instrument.
questions.solution:
The image shows a Humby's knife.

This instrument is used to harvest a split skin graft. The average thickness of the graft obtained from a Humby's knife is 0.3 mm.

questions.text: Not true regarding the condition in the given image?

choices.text: Incomplete cyst wall removal causes recurrence
A punctum may not always be visible

questions.solution:
The image shows an infected sebaceous cyst(epidermoid cyst) as evident by the inflammation of the swelling. Malignancies in epidermoid cysts are very rare. 

Other options: 

Incomplete removal of the cyst wall is indeed a frequent cause of recurrence

Punctum is not always clinically visible as it can be buried

Injection of triamcinolone Perilesionally aids faster resolution & clearing of infection. But this does not cause the eradication of cyst 

 

The most common site of a Sebaceous cyst is postauricular sulcus or below and behind the ear lobule. They are fixed to the skin and usually have a central punctum.

Treatment depends on the clinical state of the cyst. When inflamed or infected, they should be incised and drained initially, total surgical excision should be done once the inflammation has subsided.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented to the gynecology OPD with a history of abdominal pain and distension of abdomen. Ultrasound imaging revealed tumor in the right ovary. Serum level of inhibin was raised. The histopathology of the tumor is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histopathology showing Call-Exner bodies are suggestive of granulosa cell tumor.

Call-Exner bodies are small, distinctive, glandlike structures filled with an acidophilic material resembling immature follicles. Additionally, small, cuboidal to polygonal cells are seen which may grow in anastomosing cords, sheets, or strands. 

Granulosa cell tumors are composed of cells that resemble granulosa cells of a developing ovarian follicle. It can be of adult and juvenile types. Elevated tissue and serum levels of inhibin, a product of granulosa cells, are associated with this tumor.

Mutations of the FOXL2 gene are seen in most adult granulosa cell tumors.

questions.text: You notice the following appearance in the X-Ray of a patient.  Which of the following conditions is the least likely cause for this?
questions.solution:
The X-ray is characteristic of Pneumoperitoneum which is not seen in Acute intestinal obstruction.

  • The erect X-ray shows gas under both the diaphragms, and the most important cause for this is a hollow viscus perforation.
  • An intestinal obstruction would show multiple dilated loops on X-ray with possible air-fluid levels. Only when the obstruction becomes severe and there is perforation, pneumoperitoneum occurs.
  • Causes other than perforation are:
    • Chilaiditi syndrome (where the intestine is seen between the liver and diaphragm giving a false impression of free air)
    • Sub-phrenic abscess
    • Postoperatively air may be present in the abdomen up to 7 days

Other signs in pneumoperitoneum:

  • Rigler’s sign: The outer and inner walls of the bowel loop are delineated by gas
  • Football sign/ Air dome sign: A central round air collection seen on a supine x-ray
  • Inverted V sign: Gas is seen on either side of the umbilical ligament

Note:

In an emergency setting, where a patient presents with peritonitis and Xray abdomen confirming pneumoperitoneum, an emergency laparotomy is undertaken to manage the bowel perforation.

questions.text: What is the preferred treatment of uterine prolapse in a nulliparous woman who desires future pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Sling surgery or cervicopexy is usually performed in a young female with uterine prolapse who is nulliparous and desires future pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Nulliparous or congenital prolapse

  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery 
  • Le Fort's repair
  • Colpocleisis

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: Which of the following abnormalities is least likely to be detected in the first trimester sonography?
questions.solution:
Corpus callosum agenesis is least likely to be detected in the first trimester sonography.  

Detection rates are very high for anencephaly, holoprosencephaly and ventral wall defects.  

First trimester sonography can reliably diagnose

  • Anembryonic gestation,
  • Embryonic demise,
  • Ectopic pregnancy, and
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease.

The first trimester is also the ideal time to evaluate the uterus, adnexa, and cul-de-sac.

Determination of chorionicity in a multifetal gestation is most accurate in the first trimester.    

Some Indications for First-Trimester Ultrasound Examination :

  1. Confirm an intrauterine pregnancy
  2. Evaluate a suspected ectopic pregnancy
  3. Define the cause of vaginal bleeding
  4. Evaluate pelvic pain
  5. Estimate gestational age
  6. Diagnose or evaluate multifetal gestations
  7. Confirm cardiac activity
  8. Assist chorionic villus sampling, embryo transfer, and localization and removal of
  9. an intrauterine device
  10. Assess for certain fetal anomalies, such as anencephaly, in high-risk patients
  11. Evaluate maternal pelvic masses and/or uterine abnormalities
  12. Measure nuchal translucency when part of a screening program for fetal aneuploidy
  13. Evaluate suspected gestational trophoblastic disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding achondroplasia?

choices.text: Associated ligament laxity can cause kyphosis

questions.solution:
Achondroplasia is a defect  in endochondral ossification of the bones mostly affecting limbs. They are not prone for fractures.

In the lumbar spine, profound lordosis, bulging intervertebral discs, and a narrowed spinal canal are characteristic of achondroplasia.

  • Left side: Arch of the aorta from the left common carotid to the left subclavian arteries
6th Recurrent laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Arytenoid cartilages
 		  
  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle)
  • Right side: right pulmonary artery 
  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus

questions.text: According to WHO, a child is severely malnourished if __________
questions.solution:
According to WHO, a child is severely malnourished if:

  • Symmetrical edema is present
  • Weight/Height is <70% of expected
  • Height/age is <85% of expected

Note: Weight-for-age is not a parameter for WHO classification of malnutrition. It has limited clinical signifcance as it does not diferentiate between wasting and stunting.

WHO classification of malnutrition:

 

Parameter  Moderate malnutrition Severe malnutrition
Symmetrical edema no yes
weight/height(wasting) -2 to -3 S.D(70 to 79% of expected) < -3 S.D (<70%)
Height/age(stunting) -2 to -3 S.D(85 to 89%) < -3 S.D (<85%)

questions.text: Which amongst the following molecules play an important role in transmigration of leucocytes.
questions.solution:
CD31 (PECAM-1) helps in the transmigration of leucocytes across the wall of blood vessels.

Selectins (Both P&E) help in rolling; chemokines in activating the neutrophils to increase avidity of integrins; integrins help in firm adhesion.

questions.text: The auto-antibody that is associated with myasthenia gravis, from the following, is _______

choices.text: Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LPR4) antibody

questions.solution:
One of the auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis is anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LPR4) antibodies

 

Related Pearl: Auto antibodies in a few disorders

Auto-antibodies in myasthenia gravis:

i) Anti-acetylcholine receptor (AChR) antibodies

ii) Anti-muscle-specific kinase (MuSK) antibodies

iii) Anti-low density lipoprotein receptor-related protein 4 (LRP4) antibodies

Anti-C1q antibodies are associated with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and membrane proliferative glomerulonephritis (MPGN). 

Anti-Smith antibodies (Anti-Sm) are associated with SLE.

Anti-lysosome associated membrane protein-2 (LAMP-2) antibodies are associated with certain types of vasculitis.

questions.text: Which among the following layer has abundant desmosomes ?
questions.solution:
Stratum spinosum or prickle cell layer contains abundant desmosomes.

The image showing layers of the epidermis, it is divided from deep to superficial as 

  • Stratum basale (Basal layer)
  • Stratum spinosum (Spinous or prickle cell layer)
  • Stratum granulosum (Granular layer)
  • Stratum lucidum (Clear layer)
  • Stratum corneum (Cornified layer)

Stratum spinosum- contain several layers of closely packed keratinocytes that interdigitate with each other by means of numerous cell surface projections. These cells are anchored to each other by desmosomes that provide tensile strength and cohesion to the layer. when the skin is seen under light microscopy, the cell tend to shrink away except where they are joined by desmosomes, giving them spiny appearance. 

 

Desmosomes:

They are the major intercellular junctions in the skin which join the adjacent keratinocytes.

They contain 3 proteins inside called as Desmoglein(dsg), Desmocollin and Desmoplakin.

Destruction Disease
Desmoglein IgG pemphigus
Staphylococcal scladed skin syndrome
Bullous impetigo
Desmocollin

IgA pemphigus
Desmoplakin

Paraneoplastic pemphigus

Note: If the question was asked about the location of Hemi-desmosomes, then the answer will be : Between stratum basale and dermo-epidermal junction.

questions.text: False about Lateral medullary syndrome is:

choices.text: Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature on the face
Contralateral loss of pain and temperature on the trunk and limbs
Ipsilateral laryngeal, pharyngeal and palatal hemiparalysis
Contralateral upper motor neuron deficit on the trunk and limbs

questions.solution:
The false statement about lateral medullary syndrome is contralateral upper motor neuron deficit on the trunk and limbs. Corticospinal fibers are not involved in lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome).

Lateral medullary syndrome: occlusion of vertebral, posterior inferior cerebellar, superior, middle, or inferior lateral medullary arteries.

On side of lesion:

  • Fifth nerve nucleus and descending tract: Pain, numbness, impaired sensation over face
  • Cerebellar fibers, spinocerebellar tract- Ataxia
  • Vestibular nucleus- Nystagmus, diplopia, oscillopsia, vertigo, nausea, vomiting
  • Descending sympathetic tract- Horner’s syndrome (miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating)
  • Ninth and Tenth nerve fibers- Dysphagia, hoarseness, paralysis of palate, paralysis of vocal cord, diminished gag reflex:

On opposite side:

  • Spinothalamic tract: Impaired pain and thermal sense over half the body, sometimes face

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face

  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome

  • Loss of gag reflex

  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Which of the following is used as a source of stem cells in stem cell therapy
questions.solution:
The sources of stem cells were until recently seen in bone marrow, embryo, amniotic fluid and umbilical cord blood but now in menstrual fluid as well.

Menstrual fluid:

  • The menstrual fluid contains mesenchymal cells such as mononuclear cells and fibroblasts.
  • These cells deteriorate with advanc­ing age.
  • Therefore, cells from young women are suitable for donation, and self-use at a later age if needed.
  • The kit con­tains antibiotics to prevent infection, and the menstrual fluid is cryopreserved and harvested.

The procedure is sim­ple, non invasive and painless as well as possible.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with fissured tongue and peripheral neuropathy. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Which vitamin deficiency is the likely cause of this?
questions.solution:
This patient is most likely suffering from riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency.

Deficiency of riboflavin is characterized by cheilosis, desquamation, and inflammation of the tongue, seborrheic dermatitis, corneal vascularization, anemia, and personality changes.

Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

questions.text: A 35-year-old asymptomatic woman on USG shows a unilocular cyst in the ovary of 6 cm with negative serology. Treatment involves:
questions.solution:
Follow up after 1-2 cycles of oral combined pills (conservative management) is the best treatment modality in the given scenario as it is most likely to be a functional cyst.

For conservative management of ovarian cysts, the following criteria should usually be met:

  • Asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Unilateral
  • No solid areas
  • Normal CA 125
  • Less than 7cm
  • Ultrasound re-examination after 3-6 months (no signs of increase in size or malignancy)

Features of a functional cyst:

  • Related to temporary hormonal disorders
  • Benign and rarely become complicated
  • Usually 6-8cm in diameter
  • Usually asymptomatic
  • Unilocular
  • Contains clear fluid, unless haemorrhage occurs
  • Lining epithelium corresponds to the functional epithelium of the unit from which they arise
  • Spontaneous regression occurs within 4-6 months

Treatment of functional cysts:

  • Usually conservative; spontaneous regression occurs after 4-6months.
  • Oral combined pills to hasten the regression of cyst.
  • Laparotomy for tumours more than 7 cm to prevent complications or malignant transformation.

questions.text: Amiloride is used in the treatment of_________
questions.solution:
Amiloride is used in the treatment of Liddle syndrome.

Amiloride is an inhibitor of renal epithelial Na+ channels ( K+ sparing diuretic).

Indications:

  • Edema/hypertesion: usually in combination with thiazides
  • Lithium induced polyuria: blocks lithium transport into collecting tubules.
  • Cystic fibrosis: aerolized amiloride enhances mucociliary clearance; acts by inhibitng Na+ absorption from epithelial surfaces and increasing hydration of secretions.
  • Liddle syndome: hyperactive epithelial sodium channels (ENaC) activity is reduced.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

questions.solution:
Opisthorchis viverrini (liver fluke) is implicated in the pathogenesis of cholangiocarcinoma.

Apart from Opisthorchis viverrini, Clonorchis sinensis is also known to cause cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.solution:
All sphingolipidoses involved in lipid storage disorder are inherited in an autosomal recessive manner, except alpha-galactosidase in Fabry’s disease which is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

questions.text: The device shown in the image works upon the principle of:
questions.solution:
The given image shows radiant warmers. They work under the principle of radiant heating.

Incubators work under the principle of Convective Heating.

The device is set in servo control mode and the temperature is set at 36.5 to 37-degree celsius.

 

Ideal Temperature of:

  • NICU - 30+/- 2 Degree celsius.
  • Labour Room - 25 Degree celsius

questions.text: Which of the following is the rate-limiting enzyme of the fatty acid synthesis pathway?
questions.solution:
Acetyl CoA carboxylase is the rate-limiting enzyme of the fatty acid synthesis pathway.

Acetyl CoA carboxylase converts acetyl CoA into malonyl CoA, the first step of de novo fatty acid synthesis. It is an allosteric enzyme activated by citrate in the well-fed state. Acetyl CoA carboxylase requires the following: 

  • NADPH as the reducing equivalent 
  • Biotin is a coenzyme needed by carboxylases
  • ATP for energy
  • Manganese (Mn2+)
  • HCO3- as the carbon donor

questions.text: In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if ___________.

choices.text: Urine output <100 ml in last 4 hours

questions.solution:
In Pritchard regimen, maintenance dose is given only if Patellar reflex is brisk.

Magnesium sulfate is used for management of eclampsia and as prophylaxis in severe pre-eclampsia. The two regimens commonly used are tabulated below.

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3–5 min followed by 10 g (50%), deep IM (5 g in each buttock) 5 g (50%) IM 4 hourly in alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4–6 g IV slow over 15–20 minute 1–2 g/h IV infusion

Patients must be monitored for magnesium toxicity. Repeated IM injections of Magnesium sulfate are continued only if:

  • The patellar reflex is present
  • Respirations are not depressed
  • Urine output in the previous 4 hours exceeded 100 mL

Measurement of serum magnesium levels is indicated to monitor magnesium toxicity if serum creatinine is > 1.0 mg/dL.

Management of magnesium toxicity:

  • Stop magnesium therapy
  • Estimation of serum magnesium and creatinine levels
  • Injection of calcium gluconate 10ml (10% solution) IV

Side effects of MgSO4:

  • Anuria
  • Pulmonary edema

Mechanism of action of MgSO4:

  • It is a membrane stabilizer and a neuroprotector by reducing motor endplate sensitivity to Ach
  • It blocks neuronal Calcium influx
  • Reduced presynaptic release of the neurotransmitter glutamate
  • Blockade of glutaminergic NMDA receptors
  • Potentiation of adenosine action

Note: MgSO4 does not control hypertension

questions.text: A 60-year-old man is diagnosed with carcinoma limited to the glottis of the larynx. Which of the following lymph nodes would be initially involved?
questions.solution:
Tumours limited to the glottis usually do not spread to any lymph node station as there are no lymphatics in the vocal cords.

However, if the tumour invades the supra- or the infra- glottic spaces, lymph node spread can occur. 

Squamous cell carcinoma is the most common malignant tumour of the larynx. Glottis is the most common site of cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about sarcoidosis is false?

choices.text: The granulomas of sarcoidosis can resolve with or without therapy
HLA-DRB1*1101 is associated with an increased risk for developing sarcoidosis
Persistent form of the disease is associated with high levels of IL-6
Severely immunocompromised patients of HIV rarely develop the disease

questions.solution:
IL-8, not IL-6, is often secreted at high levels in the persistent form of Sarcoidosis.

The granulomatous response of sarcoidosis can resolve with or without therapy. However, in at least 20% of patients with sarcoidosis, a chronic form of the disease develops.

HLA-DRB1*1101 is associated with an increased risk for developing sarcoidosis

Untreated patients with HIV infection, who lack helper T cells rarely develop sarcoidosis. In contrast, sarcoidosis becomes unmasked as HIV-infected individuals receive antiretroviral therapy as the immunity is gradually restored.

questions.text: Which of the following organisms causes the following disease?
questions.solution:
The image shows vesicles on the palms, soles, and oral mucosa, consistent with hand-foot-and-mouth disease. It is caused by coxsackievirus.

Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an exanthematous fever affecting mainly young children, characterized by oral and pharyngeal ulcerations and a vesicular rash of the palms and soles that may spread to the arms and legs. Vesicles heal without crusting, which clinically differentiates them from the vesicles of herpesviruses and poxviruses. It is usually a benign illness resolving in 1-2 weeks.

Coxsackie A16, A9, and B 1-3 are common causative agents.

Other diseases caused by Coxsackie A virus:

  • Aseptic meningitis is associated with a maculopapular rash.
  • Herpangina
  • Minor respiratory infections

Note: Conditions associated with the rash on palms and soles: Secondary syphilis, Hand foot, and mouth disease, Rickettsial feature caused by Rickettsia rickettsiae

questions.text: The image below is an axial CT scan of the upper abdomen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of pseudomyxoma peritonei

Pseudomyxoma peritonei is a peritoneal neoplasia characterized by the accumulation of mucin-producing tumor cells in the peritoneal cavity and usually occurs following rupture of mucinous adenocarcinoma of the appendix. However, it may also occur due to the rupture of the tumors of ovary, pancreas, stomach, colorectal, or urachus.

Imaging findings:

  • Accumulation of mucinous material, which is seen as masses of low attenuation on CT and moderately high signal intensity on MRI.
  • Scalloped indentation of the visceral surfaces of the liver and spleen.
  • The peritoneal surfaces may be thickened due to the solid components of the tumor.

questions.text: All the following statements are true about Meniere’s disease except?

choices.text: Affected individuals have significantly longer endolymph drainage systems
Deterioration of sensorineural hearing loss, typically low frequencies is seen
It is caused by inadequate absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac
Predisposing anatomic variations develop as early as 3 years of age

questions.solution:
Individuals with Meniere  disease  have  significantly  smaller  and  shorter  endo- lymph  drainage  systems  as  measured  by  the  distance  between  the  posterior  semicircular  canal  and  the  posterior  fossa  on  MRI.

These anatomic variations develop by 3 years of age and may predispose these individuals to later development of Meniere disease. Acute attacks are superimposed on a gradual deterioration in sensorineural hearing in the involved ear, typically in the low frequencies initially.

The underlying pathophysiology of hydrops is controversial, but inadequate absorption of endolymph by the endolymphatic sac is the prevalent theory.

questions.text: True about the condition shown in the image below

choices.text: It describes a transient condition in newborns
The membrane usually peels off within the first 4 months of life
It is a autosomal dominant condition.
It is not a type of congenital icthyosis

questions.solution:
The image shows a neonate encased in a shiny parchment‐like membrane indicative of a collodion baby, which is a transient condition in newborns. 

Except for Harlequin Ichthyosis, most autosomal recessive Congenital Ichthyosis patients present at birth as ‘collodion babies’.

  • This membrane usually peels off within the first 4 weeks of life.
  • Initially, the clinical presentation can be quite severe and often includes ectropion and everted lips of different degrees, this later clears.
  • Collodion babies look very much alike at birth, but later take different clinical courses such as :
    • Lamellar Icthyosis- Shedding of the collodion membrane is followed by the development of large dark grey/brownish scales affecting the trunk and the scalp, but sparing the face and extremities
    • Bathing Suit Icthyosis - Born as collodion babies, they later develop a lamellar type of ichthyosis that spares the face and the extremities, and follows the distribution pattern of bathing suits.
    • Congenital ichthyosiform Erythroderma
    • Self‐healing collodion baby 
    • Acral self‐healing collodion baby

Note: Several syndromic types of congenital ichthyosis such as trichothiodystrophy or Gaucher syndrome type 2 also typically present as collodion baby.

questions.text: Psoriatic plaques may be encircled by a clear halo or ring of Woronoff. This is formed due to which of the following changes around the plaque?
questions.solution:
As a result of ultraviolet light and coal tar therapy, a white ring (Woronoff's Ring) may develop in the normal skin adjacent to psoriatic plaques due to decreased PGE2 synthesis.

  • Typical psoriatic lesions are erythematous, scaly, plaques which are sharply delineated from surrounding unaffected skin.
  • The plaques are encircled by a clear peripheral zone of hypopigmentation, usually following phototherapy or coal tar therapy, called the halo or ring of Woronoff.
  • This is possibly formed due to local inability to synthesize PGE2 in response to an ultraviolet light stimulus, resulting from an inhibitor of prostaglandin synthesis.

Woronoff ring:

questions.text: False about septic tank represented in below-given image is

choices.text: Aerobic oxidation takes place outside the tank

questions.solution:
• Ideal retention period for a septic tank is 24 hours.
  • If the retention period is too small, there is insufficient treatment of sewage and if it is too long, then undue septicity results.

Related Pearl: Septic Tank

  • It is a water-tight tank into which household sewage is admitted for treatment.
  • Septic tanks are not recommended for large communities.
  • Design features:
    • There are single and double chambered septic tanks.
    • The usual minimum capacity recommended of a septic tank is 500 gallons for a household.
    • The length of a septic tank is twice its breadth.
    • The depth of a septic tank is usually 1.5 to 2m.
    • The recommended depth of liquid is 1.2m.
    • The tank has an inlet and outlet pipe along with a concrete cover.
    • Septic tanks are usually designed to have a retention period of 24 hours.
  • Working:
    • Sludge settles down and scum is formed at the surface
    • Liquid called effluent passes out through the outlet pipe from time to time
    • Anaerobic digestion takes place in the tank and reduces the solid waste which is followed by aerobic oxidation outside the tank
    • By these processes, sewage is purified
  • Operation and maintenance:
    • Soap water and phenols must not be used
    • Desludging must be done at least once a year

Below is an image of a double-chambered septic tank.

questions.text: GnRH analogs are useful in all except
questions.solution:
Uses of GnRH:

  • Preoperative shrinkage of uterine fibroids
  • Shrinkage of endometriosis
  • Shrinkage of endometrium prior to endometrial ablation
  • Hirsutism
  • Precocious puberty
  • In vitro fertilization
  • Prostatic cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is present in delta granules of platelets?
questions.solution:
Delta granules of Platelets have serotonin.

Platelets :

Platelets are disc­ shaped anucleate cell fragments that are shed from megakaryocytes in the bone marrow into the bloodstream. 

Their function depends on several glycoprotein receptors, a contractile cytoskeleton, and two types of cytoplasmic granules.

Granules are :

  • Alpha
  • Delta

α-Granules have :

  • Adhesion molecule p­-selectin on their membranes
  • Proteins involved in coagulation
    • Fibrinogen
    • Coagulation factor V
    • vWF
  • Protein factors involved in wound healing
    • Fibronectin
    • Platelet factor 4 (a heparin­ binding chemokine)
    • Platelet ­derived growth factor (PDGF)
    • Transforming growth factor­ β

Dense (or δ) granules contain

  • Adenosine triphosphate
  • Adenosine diphosphate (adp)
  • Ionized calcium
  • Serotonin

questions.text: A 62-year-old man presents to the ER with headache, fever, and vomiting for the past 5 hours. A CT image is shown below. Physical examination shows positive Kernig’s and Brudzinski’s signs. Vitals: Temp - 101 F, BP - 120/88 mmHg, PR - 110 beats/min, pupils reactive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) and the treatment of choice for this condition is surgical clipping. 

CT shows hyperattenuating material filling the subarachnoid space, which is suggestive of SAH. Most commonly, it occurs around the circle of Willis due to the rupture of a berry aneurysm at this location.

SAH can present with fever, positive Kernig’s sign, and Brudzinski’s sign, as well as mimic meningitis or encephalitis.

Treatment with the calcium channel antagonist nimodipine (60 mg PO every 4 h) improves outcome, by preventing ischemic injury.

Option A: Vancomycin + ceftriaxone is the recommended therapy for bacterial meningitis. Meningitis does not show hyper-attenuated subarachnoid space.

Option B: IV Tenecteplase is used for ischemic stroke without bleeding complications.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in Zellweger spectrum disorders?
questions.solution:
Sudden Infant Death Syndrome (SIDS) is not included in Zellweger spectrum disorder.

Zellweger spectrum disorders are Peroxisomal Biogenesis Disorders. It includes

a) Zellweger syndrome (also known as Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome) - most severe form

b) Neonatal adrenoleukodystrophy (NALD)

c) Infantile Refsum disease - least severe form

 

 

Zellweger syndrome:

  • Caused by mutations in PEX family of genes -also called as peroxins involved in Peroxisome Biogenesis /Peroxisomal enzymes themselves 
  • Biochemical findings :
    • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids
    • abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
    • marked reduction of plasmalogens

questions.text: The following type of wound can be seen in all, except ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a stellate/ cruciate type of wound, which is seen in a contact shot, not in a close shot.

Close-shot wound features include wounds with the victim within a range of 5 to 8 cm, characterized by circular shapes with inverted edges. Notable signs include blackening and tattooing around the wound area. Additionally, there may be burning of hair, along with abrasion and the presence of a grease collar.

Other options:

Option A: Bursting of the skull is associated with a contact shot wound.  

Option B: Firearm exit wounds can be of various shapes, such as round, cruciate, stellate, elliptical, or crescent-shaped. Exit wounds of the head are usually star-shaped.

Option C: Contact shot features are :

  • An imprint of muzzle around the wound – Recoil abrasion.
  • Back spatter - Sucking of tissue, Cloth fibers, inside the barrel.
  • Pinkish-red discoloration due to CO.
  • Shape - Stellate, Cruciate, Elliptical.
  • Margins - everted.
  • Bursting fractures – In head wounds.
  • Cavitation - abdominal wounds.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about medullary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) does not take up radioactive iodine as MTC is TSH-independent.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular (C cells) derived from the neural crest. Histological analysis shows characteristic amyloid stroma. High levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen are produced by many medullary tumors. It also secretes 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin) or prostaglandin which may be a reason for diarrhea in 30% of cases. 20% are familial (multicentric and bilateral) and seen in younger ages. 80% sporadic (originate in one lobe) and is seen in the 6th decade. It is diagnosed by FNAC.

Treatment includes total thyroidectomy plus elective dissection of the central neck nodes plus or minus ipsilateral modified radical neck dissection (if neck node positive). If nodal metastasis cure is unlikely, the gross disease should be removed.

Related Pearl: Secretion of medullary thyroid tumors

Medullary thyroid tumor secrete the following:

  • Calcitonin
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Calcitonin gene–related peptide
  • Histaminadases
  • Prostaglandins E 2 and F 2 α
  • Serotonin

Calcitonin and serotonins are responsible for diarrhea in MTC.

questions.text: All are true regarding the condition shown below except:

choices.text: It is more prevalent in women than in men
According to the CEAP classification, the above condition belongs to class C3
Their distribution indicates which superficial system is defective
The duplex ultrasound imaging has become the mainstay of investigation for this condition

questions.solution:
The above image shows presence of varicosities without edema, skin changes or ulcers. Class C2 indicates varicose veins and C3 indicates edema.

The prevalence of varicose veins is 25-30% in women, and 15% in men.

Distribution of varicosities indicate which superficial system is defective:

  • Medial thigh and calf varicosities indicate long saphenous incompetence
  • Posterolateral calf varicosities indicate short saphenous vein incompetence
  • Anterolateral thigh and calf varicosities indicate isolated incompetence of proximal anterolateral long saphenous tributary

Duplex ultrasound imaging has become the mainstay of investigation for varicose veins.

questions.text: The red cell inclusions seen below in the smear are
questions.solution:
Peripheral blood smear preparation with standard Wright-Giemsa stain shows smooth, round basophilic (purple) particles in eosinophilic erythrocytes suggestive of Howell Jolly bodies

Howell-Jolly bodies persist in those with functional hyposplenism or asplenia:

  • Autosplenectomy due to sickle cell anemia
  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Megaloblastic anemia
  • Myelodysplastic syndrome (MDS)
  • Radiation therapy
  • Severe hemolytic anemia
  • Splenectomy following trauma

 

Papenheimer bodies -irregular abnormal granules of iron seen as basophilic erythrocytic inclusions usually located at periphery

  •  Thalassemia
  •  Sideroblastic anemia
  •  Hemolytic anemia

 

Heinz bodies contain Denatured Hb that appears purple-blue on the supravital stain

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Unstable HB

 

Cabot rings are made of microtubules remnants from a mitotic spindle

  • Asplenia
  • Lead poisoning
  • Pernicious anemia
  • Thalassemia

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies
