questions.text: Identify the abnormality in the given ECG:
questions.solution:
The ECG shows atrial flutter.

Atrial Flutter

  • Narrow complex tachycardia
  • Regular atrial activity ranges from 150 to 300 bpm
  • Flutter waves (“saw-tooth” pattern) best seen in leads II, III, aVF
  • Loss of the isoelectric baseline

questions.text: In forming 3D structure of protein following factors help except_______________
questions.solution:
Peptide bond helps in primary structure of protein (not 3D structure) 

3D structure of protein:

  • Amino acid sequence determines the tertiary structure of proteins.
  • Interaction of polypeptides also helps the  three dimensional structure of protein.
  • Chaperones helps in protein folding and hence are invoved in the three dimensional structure.
  • Side chains help in the formation of bonds involved in tertiary structure of proteins.

questions.text: Letulles technique is an autopsy technique characterised by ________

choices.text: Removal of organs one by one

questions.solution:
Letulle's technique is characterized by en masse removal of organs. It means thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one big organ block.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Hereditary fructose intolerance (HFI) is inherited in ______
questions.solution:
Hereditary fructose intolerance shows autosomal recessive inheritance.

Deficiency of aldolase B leads to intracellular accumulation of fructose 1-phosphate.

Clinical features:

  • Severe hypoglycemia,
  • Vomiting,
  • Jaundice,
  • Hepatomegaly,
  • Hyperuricemia, and
  • Lactic acidosis

Treatment is removal of fructose and sucrose from the diet.

questions.text: An abdominal mass in a patient with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis is best seen _________.

choices.text: During palpation over the left hypochondrium

questions.solution:
In a child with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS), the abdominal mass is best seen during test feed in the right upper quadrant. 

Hypertrophic pyloric stenosis most presents with non-bilious projectile vomiting. It is common between 2 and 8 weeks of age. Hypertrophy of the circular muscle of the pylorus results in constriction and obstruction of the gastric outlet. Male infants are at a higher risk.

Clinically, when the infant is given a test feed, an olive-shaped mass is palpable in the right upper quadrant and visible peristalsis is usually observed moving from left to right across the abdomen.

Infants with hypertrophic pyloric stenosis develop a characteristic metabolic abnormality- hypochloraemic hypokalaemic metabolic alkalosis. Persistent vomiting results in loss of hydrochloric acid leading to the development of metabolic alkalosis (due to loss of H+) and hypochloremia (due to loss of Cl-).

All infants with congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis are evaluated with an ultrasound (investigation of choice). It confirms the diagnosis in the majority of cases.

Management: Rehydration and metabolic correction prior to definitive surgery - Ramstedt's pyloromyotomy.

questions.text: Embolism of the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery would result in ischemia of which of the following areas of the heart?

choices.text: Anterior part of the left ventricle
Posterior part of  the left ventricle

questions.solution:
Embolism of the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery would result in ischemia of posterior part of the left ventricle.

  • Anterior part of left ventricle supplied by anterior interventricular artery.
  • Anterior 2/3 of ventricular septum by anterior interventricular artery.
  • Posterior 1/3 ventricular septum by posterior interventricular artery.
  • Posterior part of left ventricle by circumflex artery.

Blood Supply of Heart :

 

Right coronary artery

Left coronary artery

Origin

Anterior aortic sinus of ascending aorta, diameter less than left coronary artery

Left posterior aortic sinus of ascending aorta. (Right posterior aortic sinus – noncoronary sinus)

Branches

Right conus artery (third coronary artery)

Right anterior ventricular artery – supplies sternocostal surface of right ventricle.

Atrial rami – supplies right atrium.

Posterior interventricular artery – supplies diaphragmatic surface of right and left ventricle.

Right posterior atrial and ventricular rami

Anterior interventricular artery

Anterior ventricular rami

Circumflex artery

SA nodal branch arise from this in 35% of subjects

Single Left marginal (obtuse )artery

Atrial branch

Areas of distribution

Whole of right atrium

Most of right ventricle except a strip along anterior interventricular groove

Part left ventricle adjoining posterior interventricular groove

Most of left atrium

Most of left ventricle except area adjoining posterior interventricular groove

Small part of right ventricle along anterior inter ventricular groove

 

Blood Supply to Ventricular Septum

  • Septal branch from posterior interventicular artery - Posteroinferior one-third of ventricular septum
  • Septal branch from anterior interventricular artery - Anterosuperior two third of ventricular septum

questions.text: Depth of inspiration is increased by_____

choices.text: Ventral group of neurons in medulla

questions.solution:
Depth of inspiration is increased by the apneustic center.

The apneustic centre sends signals to prevent switching off of inspiration maintained by the dorsal respiratory group of neurons, thereby increasing depth of inspiration. 

In contrast to this, the pneumotaxic center primarily limits inspiration by controlling the "switch off" point of the inspiratory ramp signal. 

A note on inspiratory ramp signal:

The neural signals transmitted to the inspiratory muscle, mainly the diaphragm, is not the instantaneous burst of action potentials. Instead, it begins weakly and increases steadily in a ramped manner. The advantage of the ramp is that it causes a steady increase in the volume of the lungs during inspiration, rather than inspiratory gasps.

Control of the limiting point at which the ramp suddenly ceases is the mechanism by which the respiratory centers control depth and rate of respiration. 

Option A: Pneumotaxic center of the pons regulates the rate and depth of breathing.
Option B: Ventral group of neurons regulate expiration.
Option C: Dorsal group of neurons regulate inspiration.

questions.text: Cyanide blocks citric acid cycle by blocking which of the following ?
questions.solution:
Cyanide blocks citric acid cycle by blocking NAD+.

Cyanide blocks complex 4 of the electron transport chain, thereby directly inhibiting electron transport, causing ↓ proton gradient and block ATP synthesis.

As a result electron carriers NADH and FADH cannot unload their electrons, thus reducing the concentration of NAD+ and FAD+ which is required for the Kreb’s cycle to proceed.

Related Pearl: Electron transport chain: components and its inhibitors

questions.text: Agoraphobia is fear of
questions.solution:
Agoraphobia is defined as morbid fear of places from which the patient feels that he/she cannot escape. Claustrophobia is a type of agoraphobia.

The DSM-5 defines agoraphobia as characterized by fear (imminent) or anxiety (anticipated) in multiple public situations, be they amongst crowds or simply being out alone.

Option b:Acarophobia is fear of Small objects.

Option c: Nosocomephobia is fear of hospitals.

Option d: Acrophobia is fear of heights.

Phobia is defined as persistent, pathological, unrealistic, intense fear of an objector situation.

The phobic person may realize that the fear is irrational but is, nonetheless, unable to dispel it.

Some examples are:

Phobia Fear of
Acarophobia Small objects
Acrophobia High places
Agoraphobia Open or cowded places, leaving familiar setting of home
Aichmophobia Pointed objects
Ailurophobia Cats
Algophobia Pain
Androphobia Men
Astraphobia or astrapophobia Thunder and lightning
Autophobia Being alone, or of self
Bathophobia Depths
Claustrophobia Closed or confined places
Coprophobia Excreta
Cynophobia Dogs
Demophobia Crowds
Erythrophobia Blushing
Gynophobia Women
Haphephobia Being touched
Hematophobia Sight of blood
Hydrophobia Water
Hypnophobia Sleep
Llalophobia or glossophobia Speaking
Mysophobia Dirt, contamination
Necrophobia Dead bodies
Nyctophobia Darkness, night
Panphobia Everything
Pathophobia or nosophobia Disease, suffering
Peccatophobia Sinning
Pedophobia Children
Phonophobia Speaking aloud
Photophobia Strong light
Sitophobia Eating
Taphophobia Being buried alive
Thanatophobia Death
Toxophobia Being poisoned
Xenophobia Strangers
Zoophobia Animals

questions.text: According to the Maternity Act, 2017 what is the duration of paid leave for a mother who is adopting a child?
questions.solution:
A mother who is adopting a child will be given a paid leave for a duration of 12 weeks.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Funic souffle is due to increased blood flow in
questions.solution:
Funic or fetal souffle

  • Due to the rush of blood through the umbilical arteries.
  • It is a soft, blowing murmur synchronous with the fetal heart sounds.

Uterine souffle

  • Is a soft blowing and systolic murmur heard low down at the sides of the uterus, best on the left side.
  • The sound is synchronous with the maternal pulse and is due to increase in blood flow through the dilated uterine vessels.
  • It can be heard in big uterine fibroid.

questions.text: A pregnant woman is found to have an amniotic fluid index of 26 cm. This condition is associated which of the following?
questions.solution:
Amniotic fluid index of more than 24 cm is said to indicate hydramnios or polyhydramnios.

Hydramnios is often a component of hydrops fetalis.

All other conditions are associated with oligohydramnios where the AFI (amniotic fluid index) is less than or equal to 5 cm.

questions.text: The device shown in the image cannot be used for _____.

choices.text: A patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment

questions.solution:
Ilizarov fixator cannot be used for a patient with cellulitis of the same limb compartment as it would cause direct seeding of tissue.

Uses:

  • Limb lengthening
  • Nonunion
  • Deformity correction
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Arthrodesis by crushing the articular surfaces against each other

It can also be used for preventing the progression of fat embolism syndrome as external fixation is one of the modalities used as a part of damage control surgery.

questions.text: On experimental infusion of serotonin into the coronary artery, which of the following responses do you expect?

choices.text: Hypertension, Tachycardia & Rapid  Shallow Breathing-> Apnoea
Hypotension, Bradycardia & Apnea -> Rapid  Shallow Breathing
Hypotension, Tachycardia & Apnea -> Rapid  Shallow Breathing

questions.solution:
Hypotension, Bradycardia & Apnea -> Rapid Shallow Breathing will be produced.  

Bezold Jarisch Reflex will get stimulated on experimental infusion of serotonin into the coronary artery.

Other substances that can elicit the same reflex includes veratridine, capsaicin, phenylbiguanide etc.

Bezold Jarisch Reflex is also called Coronary Chemoreflex.  The sequence of events are:

Receptors -> C fiber endings Afferent -> Vagus Response -> Apnea -> Tachypnoea->Hypotension->Bradycardia  

This response is elicited only when infused into the coronary artery and not on infusion into the right ventricles.

Clinical Relevance: 

  • This reflex may be activated
    • During myocardial ischemia and reperfusion as a result of increased production of oxygen radicals 
    • By agents used as radiocontrast for coronary angiography.   
  • Another hypothesis is that it may help reduce the amount of inspired pollutants that gets absorbed into the blood, thereby protecting vital organs from potential toxicity of these pollutants, and facilitating their elimination 
  • Vasovagal syncope has also been attributed to Bezold-Jarisch Reflex

Related Pearl: Respiratory responses mediated by airway and lung receptors

Related Pearl: Physiological significance of Hering-Breuer inflation and deflation reflex

Advantage of Hering-Breuer inflation reflex

  • By cutting down the inspiration time-
    • Prevents overinflation of the lungs
    • Lungs operate at lower lung volumes thus wastage of energy is prevented

Advantage of Hering-Breuer deflation reflex

  • Prevents atelectasis of the lungs

questions.text: All the following are features of Wilson’s disease except___________.

choices.text: Copper in blood is of no diagnostic use
Increased urine excretion of copper is most specific screening test

questions.solution:
Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. There is a copper overload that primarily affects the liver (leading to cirrhosis) and the brain (leading to neurologic and psychiatric symptoms). 

Clinical features of Wilson's disease include: 

  • Hepatic features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient might develop cirrhosis and acute decompensation of liver function. Massive release of copper into the circulation from the liver can lead to hemolytic anemia.
  • Neurologic features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia.
  • Psychiatric features include personality changes (irritability, anger) depression, and anxiety.
  • Ocular features include Kayser-Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract. 
  • Other manifestations include renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis. 

Reduced serum ceruloplasmin (option A) and elevated urinary copper excretion (option D) point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Measurement of serum copper is of no diagnostic use (option C) since it may be low, normal, or elevated depending on the stage of evolution of the disease. Percutaneous liver biopsy for measuring hepatic copper content is the gold standard investigation for establishing the diagnosis.

Copper chelation in patients with Wilson's disease is done using penicillamine. Pyridoxine is prescribed with penicillamine to counteract the deficiency that may develop with the treatment. In patients with predominant neurological manifestations, trientine is used as the chelating agent because penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms. Tetrathiomolybdate is under trial for the treatment of Wilson's disease. Zinc is used for maintenance therapy in patients after the initial chelation is complete.

Mutation in ATP7A gene causes impaired copper absorption and transport, leading to Menkes disease. This is characterized by brittle and kinky hair.

questions.text: A gasless abdomen is seen in:
questions.solution:
A gasless abdomen is an X-ray feature that can be seen in acute pancreatitis. Patients with acute pancreatitis can have significant vomiting and diarrhea that may produce a gasless abdomen.

Common causes of gasless abdomen include:

  • High obstruction: gastric outlet obstruction, congenital atresia
  • Small bowel obstruction 
  • Bowel ischemia
  • Ascites
  • Acute pancreatitis
  • Gastroenteritis
  • Large abdominal mass - due to displacement
  • Post-surgery following total colectomy, esophagogastrectomy, gastrectomy, and low anterior resection
  • A paucity of small bowel gas may be a normal finding in some adults

Note: In intussusception, an X-ray shows small bowel obstruction, a mass, and a paucity of gas in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: Which of the following vessel is not ligated in case of epistaxis control?
questions.solution:
The internal carotid artery is not ligated as it is the main vessel supplying the central nervous system.

When all the methods of epistaxis control fail, surgical ligation of vessels or embolization is the last resort of control of epistaxis.

Hierarchy of ligation: Sphenopalatine artery > Internal maxillary artery > External carotid artery > anterior/posterior ethmoidal artery.

questions.text: The Lineweaver-Burk plot corresponds to
questions.solution:
The image shows a Lineweaver Burk Plot also called a Double Reciprocal Plot of uncompetitive inhibition.

Km can be calculated from the x intercept.

questions.text: A female patient complains of palpitations and weight loss. Laboratory evaluation shows thyroid-receptor antibody. Which of the following statements is not true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: Associated with enlargement of extraocular muscles

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Graves' disease. Radionuclide scan shows increased uptake with diffuse distribution in Graves' disease.

The hyperthyroidism of Graves’ disease is due to the presence of thyroid-stimulating immunoglobulins (TSI). These are synthesized by lymphocytes present in the thyroid gland, as well as in bone marrow and lymph nodes. TSI include TSH receptor antibodies (TRAb), which act on the TSH receptors and stimulate the thyroid gland to produce and release more thyroid hormones, T3 and T4. Feedback inhibition by thyroid hormones causes TSH levels to be suppressed (option D).

Patients present with features of hyperthyroidism like hyperactivity, irritability, heat intolerance, sweating, and palpitations. Diarrhea, weight loss despite increased appetite, and oligomenorrhea are also seen. On examination, tremors and proximal muscle weakness might be seen. Pretibial myxedema (option A) refers to the noninflamed indurated plaque, pink-purple in color, which is seen most commonly on the skin of the anterior aspect of the leg. Thyroid acropachy is a form of clubbing of the fingers. Both these features are relatively specific to Graves' disease but are not seen in all the patients.

Graves ophthalmopathy occurs due to increased volume of the retroorbital connective tissues and extraocular muscles (option B) due to marked lymphocytic infiltration of the retro-orbital space, accumulation of hydrophilic glycosaminoglycans such as hyaluronic acid and chondroitin sulfate, and increased numbers of adipocytes. Early signs of Graves' ophthalmopathy include lid retraction and lid lag on downgaze. Later, the patients develop proptosis, diplopia, corneal damage (due to proptosis), and optic nerve compression causing permanent vision loss. 

The diagnosis of Graves' disease is established by measuring TSH levels (will be suppressed) and T3/T4 levels (will be elevated). Measurement of TRAb is required if the diagnosis is unclear. Radionuclide scan shows diffusely increased uptake in cases of Graves' disease. 

Treatment of Graves' disease includes:

  • Anti-thyroid drugs such as propylthiouracil, carbimazole, and methimazole. Propylthiouracil is the preferred anti-thyroid drug during pregnancy especially till 14-16 weeks, because carbimazole and methimazole are associated with aplasia cutis (absence of skin, usually on the scalp). 
  • Propranolol is given to control adrenergic effects before the effect of anti-thyroid drugs takes effect fully.
  • Radioiodine ablation can be used as a first-line modality, or can be used for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs. Pregnancy and breastfeeding are absolute contraindications for radioiodine ablation. 
  • Total thyroidectomy is done for patients who have relapsed despite taking anti-thyroid drugs and prefer surgical treatment over radioiodine ablation.

questions.text: All of the following are advantages of the case-control study except?
questions.solution:
Incidence of a disease cannot be calculated from a case-control study.

Advantages of case-control study:

  • Simple to conduct
  • Less time consuming
  • Less expensive
  • No problem in follow up/drop out (attrition)
  • Suitable for rare diseases
  • Multiple types of exposure causing a single disease can be studied
  • The odds ratio can be obtained

Disadvantages of case-control:

  • Bias is present- Either recall or selection bias
  • The temporality of association cannot be determined
  • The natural history of the disease cannot be studied
  • Incidence, relative risk, and attributable risk cannot be calculated

questions.text: MHC molecules have promiscuous binding specificity. This implies that

choices.text: A particular MHC molecule has the potential to bind to different peptides
When MHC molecules bind to peptides, they are degraded
Peptides bind with low affinity to MHC molecules
None of the above describes promiscuous binding specificity

questions.solution:
• A particular MHC molecule has the potential to bind to different peptides
  • MHC class I and II molecules are glycoproteins which present peptides to the T cells. Each MHC molecule has only one binding site. Many different peptides can bind to the same MHC molecule. This type of binding is termed as promiscuous binding.
  • Each class I or II molecule will bind only to certain peptides and will have a set of criteria that a peptide must have in order to bind to binding site.
  • A few residues in the peptide, called anchor residues, bind to specific pockets on the MHC-I, resulting in some specificity of interactions with MHC.
  • Thus, many different peptides can bind to a single MHC, however, some peptides can bind to more than one MHC.

The following table shows the differentiating characteristics of MHC Class I and MHC Class II antigens.

MHC Class I MHC Class II
Present on all nucleated cells ( except sperms) and platelets Present on antigen presenting cells
Presents endogenous peptide antigen to  CD8+ T cells Presents Exogenous antigen to CD4+ T cells
Presents antigen via Cytosolic pathway Presents antigen via Endocytic pathway
Peptide binds to α1/α2 groove Peptide binds to α1/β1 groove
α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells  β2 binds to CD4 on Helper T cells

questions.text: Which of the following is true about triage during the disaster?
questions.solution:
• In triage, green is low priority or ambulatory patients and those with minor illnesses.
  • Red is a high priority or transfer; yellow is medium priority and black is dead or moribund patients.
  • Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and the likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention.
  • It is done at the site of the disaster.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Type of patients Examples
Red (High priority)

Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer.

May survive if timely medical intervention can be given
  • Tension pneumothorax
  • Airway obstruction
  • Hemothorax
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Acute circulatory arrest
  • Major intra-abdominal bleed etc.
Yellow (Medium priority)

Possible resuscitation or surgery in the next 24 hours.

Likely to survive if prompt treatment is given.
  • Compound fractures
  • Degloving injuries
  • Pelvic fracture
  • Spinal injuries
  • Moderate head injury
Green (Low priority)

Ambulatory patients or minor illnesses.

Likely to survive if treatment is slightly delayed.
  • Simple fractures
  • Minor lacerations etc.
Black (Least priority)

Dead or moribund patients.
  • Severe brain injury
  • Major damage / disruption to chest wall and abdominal structures

questions.text: A Female with a history of postpartum hemorrhage requiring massive transfusion with full recovery 6 months earlier is now diagnosed with Sheehan’s syndrome. Which of the following is not seen in this syndrome?

choices.text: Cold intolerance due to lack of TSH and subsequent hypothyroidism
Secondary amenorrhea due to lack of FSH and subsequent anovulation
Regression of secondary sexual characters due to decreased estrogen synthesis from gonads
Salt depletion and hypovolemic shock due to lack of aldosterone

questions.solution:
Aldosterone secretion is not significantly affected by pituitary apoplexy.

 

Pituitary apoplexy is hemorrhagic infarction of large pituitary adenomas or pituitary infarction consequent to traumatic major blood loss. If this major blood loss is during delivery it's called Sheehan's syndrome.

 

Sheehan syndrome:

  • The hyperplastic enlargement of the pituitary, which occurs normally during pregnancy, increases the risk for hemorrhage and infarction.
  • Affected women may have persistent hypotension, tachycardia, hypoglycemia, and lactation failure.
  • Most prominent among symptoms are the inability to nurse and postpartum amenorrhea.
  • Because deficiencies of some or all pituitary responsive hormones may develop after the initial insult, Sheehan syndrome can be heterogeneous and may not be identified for years
  • The sequential order of hormone loss in Sheehan’s syndrome is usually GH > Prolactin → FSH/LH → TSH → ACTH.
  • Cortisol levels are affected leading to hypovolemia, hypoglycemia, hyponatremia. But as aldosterone is unaffected there is no salt wasting.

questions.text: Type 3 dysbetalipoproteinemia is due to

choices.text: Lipoprotein lipase or Apo CII deficiency

questions.solution:
Familial type 3 dysbetalipoproteinemia is an autosomal recessive condition caused by defective ApoE.

Related Pearl: Familial Dyslipidemias

Type Increased levels  Manifestation
1. Hyperchylomicronemia(type I hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons, VLDL, TG  Pancreatitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and xanthomas
2. Familial hypercholesterolemia(type II hyperlipoproteinemia) LDL and cholesterol Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
3. Dysbetalipoproteinemia(type III hyperlipoproteinemia) Chylomicrons and VLDL Atherosclerosis and xanthomas
4. Hypertriglyceridemia(type IV hyperlipoproteinemia) VLDL and TG Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which is not true regarding this initiative?

choices.text: Is aimed towards adolescent girls to provide them sanitary napkins
Targets to provide sex education to adolescent girls
Includes both both boys and girls of adolescent age group
Comes under Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram

questions.solution:
The image here shows “Saathiya”, a government initiative launched to provide a platform for communication to adolescent age-related health issues.

Peer Educators (Saathiya), meaning “a good friend”, are trained by the government with the help of Saathiya salah mobile application.

These Saathiyas act as a catalyst for generating demand for adolescent health services and imparting age-appropriate knowledge on key adolescent health issues to their peer groups.

Rashtriya Kishor Swasthya Karyakram (RKSK) identifies six strategic priorities for adolescents i.e. nutrition, sexual and reproductive health (SRH), non-communicable diseases (NCDs), substance misuse, injuries and violence (including gender-based violence) and mental health.

“Suvidha” is the program aimed for the provision of sanitary napkins.

Sanitary napkins were made available for Rs.1 per pad at over 3200 Janaushadhi Kendras across India.

The program aimed to ensure napkins were made available by May 28, 2018, celebrated as World Menstrual Hygiene Day.

questions.text:
A hemodynamically stable patient developed regular, narrow complex PSVT. The patient had a history of stroke. Which of the following is best indicated for termination of arrhythmia?

PSVT- Paroxysmal supra-ventricular tachycardia
questions.solution:
Intravenous adenosine is preferred for termination of arrhythmia in this patient who is stable with regular and narrow complex PSVT (paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia).

Carotid sinus massage is provided as first-line therapy only if there is a low risk of carotid vascular disease. It is contraindicated in patients with carotid bruit and prior history of stroke as in this patient (option A).

Adenosine may precipitate atrial fibrillation. In patients with WPW syndrome, where AF may lead to hemodynamic instability, IV beta-blockers or calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem) are used (option C).

IV Procainamide is used if the above agents fail to terminate the arrhythmia.

questions.text: Sparse axillary hair appears at which stage of axillary hair development?
questions.solution:
Sparse axillary hair appears at stage 2 of axillary hair development

Axillary Hair Development  
The sequence of axillary hair development is as follows:  

  • A1—prepubertal stage. No axillary hair present.  
  • A2—appearance of sparse axillary hair
  • A3—adult distribution of thick, coarse and dark pigmented hair 

Thelarche  

  • The first sign of puberty is the development of the breasts.  
  • Breast budding usually appears between the ages of 9–11 years; it is indicative of the competency of the hypothalamic– pituitary–ovarian axis. 

Stages 

  • B1—Denotes the prepubertal breast. At this infantile stage only the papilla is elevated.  
  • B2—Denotes thelarche. The breast buds are palpable, areola enlarges and the breast is elevated like a small mound. 
  • B3—There is further enlargement of the breast and its areola without separation of its contours. 
  • B4—Preferential growth of the areola and nipple leads to formation of a secondary mound over the mound of the breast. 
  • B5—Formation of the mature adult breast. There is recession of the areola into the general contour of the breast because of greater growth of the breast tissue. 

Pubic Hair Development  

The stages of pubic hair growth are as follows:  

  •  P1—prepubertal stage when there are no coarse pubic hair present, the vellus hair present over the pubic area are similar to the ones seen over the abdominal wall. 
  • P2—pubarche denotes the appearance of long or slightly curved and pigmented hair sparsely over the labia.  
  • P3—darker, coarser and curly hair are seen spread over the mons pubis.  
  • P4—the preadult stage when thick dark growths of curly hair are seen covering the area short of the inverted triangle.  
  • P5—adult inverted triangular distribution of thick, coarse, dark curly hair spreading out towards the medial aspects of the thighs.

questions.text: An intubated patient is on the ventilator in an ICU. An intern who is to calculate the GCS score recognizes that the patient opens eyes to verbal command and is able to withdraw when a painful stimulus is applied. The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score of the patient is
questions.solution:
The GCS score of the patient in the above scenario is E3 VNT M4.

Analyzing the GCS score of the above patient,

  • Eye opening to verbal commands – 3
  • Verbal response – NT (NT stands for Not testable, as the patient is intubated)
  • Motor response – withdrawal to pain – 4

In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as ‘not testable,’ NT.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals the following finding. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. What is the most common cause of this condition in such patients?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with a positive Kernig's sign, is suggestive of meningitis. Cryptococcus is the leading infectious cause of meningitis in patients with AIDS. It generally occurs in untreated patients, with CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL.            

Most patients present with a picture of subacute meningoencephalitis. The CSF profile may show modest elevations in WBC or protein levels and decrease in glucose. The CSF opening pressure is usually elevated (yeast colonies obstruct the free flow of CSF causing increased CSF pressure).

The diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made by identification of Cryptococcus neoformans yeast cells in CSF with india ink stain or by the detection of cryptococcal antigen using latex agglutination (CrAg).

Prophylaxis: Oral fluconazole when CD4+ T cell count is <100/μL.

Treatment:

  • Induction - IV or liposomal amphotericin B with flucytosine for at least 2 weeks, continuing with amphotericin alone ideally until the CSF culture turns negative.
  • Maintenance -  Oral fluconazole until the CD4+ T cell count has increased to >200 cells/μL for 6 months in response to cART.

questions.text: According to the national framework for malaria elimination in India, states were categorized based on ______.
questions.solution:
The annual parasite index (API) is used to categorize states/union territories under the national framework for malaria elimination in India.

The national framework for malaria elimination in India was launched in February 2016 with the following goals:

  • Eliminate malaria throughout the entire country by 2030
  • Maintain malaria-free status in areas where transmission has been interrupted and prevent re-introduction

It uses the annual parasite index to classify states/union territories into four categories.

  • Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/union territories with zero cases
  • Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/union territories with all their districts having API <1
  • Category 2 (pre-elimination phase): States/union territories with API <1, but some of their districts having API≥1
  • Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States/union territories with API≥1

API is calculated by the formula: confirmed cases during one year X 1000 / population under surveillance.

Regions with API≥ 2 are considered as high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Other options:

Option B: Slide positivity rate is used to describe the percentage of slides positive for the malarial parasite. The type of species is not taken into account.

Option C: Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum species. 

Option D: Annual blood examination rate is derived by the formula - number of slides examined X 100/ Population. It is considered an index of operational efficiency.

 

 

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

 

Related Pearl: Responsibilities of Health Workers

Female Health Worker

Male Health Worker

Maternal and child health services

Family planning services and registers

Medical Termination of Pregnancy

Universal Immunization Program

Detection of non communicable diseases

Dai training

Treatment of minor ailments

Participate in team activities

Malaria slides and surveillance

Leprosy follow-up

Identification and follow-up cases of blindness

Reproductive and child health services

RNTCP

Expanded Immunization Program

Environmental sanitation including chlorination of water and proper waste disposal

Common Responsibilities

Nutrition

Distribution of contraceptives

Work on communicable diseases like DOTS activities

Record and report vital events

Record keeping and maintaining registers

questions.text: All of the following are allosteric inhibitors of pyruvate dehydrogenase except
questions.solution:
Allosteric inhibitor is defined as a substance that binds to the enzyme and induces the enzyme's inactive form. Allosteric regulators are an important feedback inhibition mechanism, where the end products of the reaction inhibit the reaction producing them.

Allosteric inhibitors of pyruvate dehydrogenase are:

  • NADH
  • Acetyl CoA
  • ATP

questions.text: Heymann nephritis is due to antibodies against which antigen?

choices.text: α3 chain of type IV collagen

questions.solution:
Heymann nephritis is due to antibodies against antigen megalin present in epithelial cell foot processes.

Heymann nephritis rat model is the well-studied experimental counterpart of membranous nephropathy, from which much of the underlying pathophysiology of glomerular immune complex-mediated diseases has been deduced.

It is induced by immunizing rats with an antigen, now known to be megalin.

Other options:

  • M type phospholipase A2 receptor (PLA2R) is the antigen involved in most cases of primary membranous nephropathy.
  • NC1 domain of α3 chain of type IV collagen is the antigen responsible for anti-GBM antibody-induced glomerulonephritis and Good pasture syndrome.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements is/are false about transfusion-associated malaria?
  1. Sporozoite is the infective stage of the parasite.
  2. Pre-erythrocytic stage is not present.
  3. It may be associated with severe complications and relapses.
  4. It has a shorter incubation period compared to mosquito-borne malaria.
  5. It requires radical treatment.
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3 and 5 are false. In transfusion-associated malaria, trophozoite is the infective stage (1). It does not show relapses (3) and does not require radical treatment (5).

Transfusion-transmitted malaria:

  • This condition occurs when a person rcieves blood infected with the malarial parasite.
  • The parasite may survive in stored blood for 1 to 2 weeks.
  • Unlike mosquito-borne malaria where sporozoites enter the blood,here transfused RBCs containing the trophozoites enter the patient’s (recipient’s) blood directly. Hence, there is no pre-erythrocytic stage and the incubation period is usually shorter than mosquito-borne malaria.
  • The patient may develop severe complications.
  • However, hypnozoites are absent and there are no relapses, hence no radical treatment is required.

Other conditions where the trophozoites directly cause the infection include: congenital malaria (due to transplacental transmission from mother to fetus), renal transplantation, and shared syringes among drug addicts.

Related Pearl: Comparison between mosquito-borne and transfusion-transmitted malaria.

  Mosquito-borne malaria Transfusion transmitted malaria
Mode of transmission Mosquito bite Transfusion of infected blood or blood products
Infective stage Sporozoite Trophozoite
Pre-erythrocytic stage Present Absent
Incubation period Long Short  
Complications Comparatively less Associated with severe complications
Hypnozoites May be seen in infection with P. vivax and ovale Absent
Relapse May occur Does not occur
Radical treatment Required Not required

questions.text: The coronal suture present between the frontal and parietal bones descends down until it reaches ______
questions.solution:
• The coronal suture is present between the posterior margin of the frontal bone and the anterior margins of the two parietal bones.
  • It descends down until it meets the junction between the greater wing of the sphenoid and the squamous temporal bone at the pterion.

Pterion:

  • All four bones of one side (Frontal, Parietal, Temporal, and Sphenoid) meet at a roughly H-shaped sutural junction termed the pterion.
  • This is an important landmark as it overlies both the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere.
  • The pterion corresponds to the site of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle of the neonatal skull, which closes in the sixth month after birth. 

The bregma is present the junction of the frontal bone and two parietal bones. It represents the site of the anterior fontanelle in a young child. 

The lambda is present at the junction of right and left parietal bones and the occipital bone. The lambdoid suture delineates the articulation between the posterior borders of the right and left parietal bones and the superior border of the occipital bone.

questions.text: Vitamin A deficiency was found to be a public health problem in a region X. The prevalence of Bitot’s spots in population at risk in this region should be ___________
questions.solution:
Prevalance of Bitot’s spots in the population at risk should be >0.5% For vitamin A deficiency to be considered as a public health problem.

As vitamin A can be stored in body for first 6 to 9 month, 6 months to 6 years is the population at risk for vitamin A deficiency.

Prevalence criteria for determining Xerophthalmia problem:

Criteria  Prevalence in population at risk (6 months to 6 years) 
Night blindness >1% 
Bitot’s spots   >0.5% 
Corneal xerosis/ Keratomalacia  >0.01% 
Corneal ulcer  >0.05% 
Serum retinol (<10mcg/dl)  >5%

questions.text: Which of the following is disabling hearing loss in adults according to the WHO definition of hearing loss?

choices.text: >40 dB in the worser hearing ear
>50 dB in the worser hearing ear
>40 dB in the better hearing ear
>50 dB in the better hearing ear

questions.solution:
Disabling hearing loss: refers to hearing loss greater than 40 dB in the better hearing ear in adults and greater than 30 dB in the better hearing ear in children.

Grades of hearing loss :
Mild : 26 - 40 dB
Moderate : 41 - 60 dB
Severe : 61 - 80 dB
Profound : >81 dB

questions.text: Sacubitril is a new drug approved for chronic heart failure. The mechanism of action of sacubitril is:
questions.solution:
Sacubitril is a neutral endopeptidase (neprilysin) inhibitor.

Sacubitril is a prodrug that is activated to sacubitrilat. It can inhibit the enzyme neprilysin (neutral endopeptidase), which is responsible for the degradation of atrial and brain natriuretic peptides (reduction of blood volume). Therefore, it increases the levels of atrial and brain natriuretic peptides and lowers blood pressure.

In 2015, the FDA approved the use of sacubitril in combination with valsartan, at a ratio of 1:1, for the treatment of chronic heart failure.

questions.text: Which of the following is the main arterial supply of palatine tonsils?

choices.text: Tonsillar branch of the facial artery
Descending palatine branch of maxillary artery
Ascending palatine branch of facial artery

questions.solution:
The main arterial supply of tonsil is by the tonsillar branch of the facial artery.

Five arteries supply the tonsil:

  1. Tonsillar branch of the facial artery (the main artery)
  2. Ascending palatine branch of the facial artery
  3. Ascending pharyngeal branch of the external carotid artery
  4. Dorsal lingual branches of the lingual artery
  5. Descending palatine branches of the maxillary artery

questions.text: A patient shows FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted, under what category would he be classified based on GOLD criteria?
questions.solution:
FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted is classified as severe COPD under GOLD classification.

The severity of COPD is assessed by Global Initiative for Lung Disease (GOLD) classification:

  GOLD Stage   Severity   Spirometry
I Mild FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥80% predicted
II Moderate FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥50% but <80% predicted
III Severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 ≥30% but <50% predicted
IV Very severe FEV1/FVC <0.7 and FEV1 <30% predicted

questions.text: True about the circuit given below is _________

choices.text: Also called Jackson Rees modification circuit

questions.solution:
The circuit given in the image is Mapleson A or Magill circuit. It has a low fresh gas flow rate requirement of 1 x minute ventilation to prevent rebreathing of carbon dioxide. Hence, it is considered the best for spontaneous ventilation.

In Mapleson circuits D, E, and F, the amount of fresh gas flow required is 2.5 times a minute ventilation and in mapleson circuits B and C, it is much higher.

Mapleson circuit A is not very useful in controlled ventilation because minute ventilation as high as 20 L/minute (fresh gas flow rate should be greater than 3 times minute ventilation) is needed to prevent rebreathing. Mapleson circuit D is used for controlled ventilation.

 

Related Pearl: Mapleson Classification

Mapleson circuit   Other name  Fresh gas flow rate
Spontaneous ventilation  Controlled ventilation
A Magills 1 minute ventilation (MV) i.e. 80 ml/kg/min Very high and difficult to predict
B - 2-3× (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
C Water’s to and fro 2-3 × (MV) 2-2.5 × (MV)
D Bain circuit 2-3 × (MV) 1-2 × (MV)
E Ayre’s t-piece 2-3 × (MV) 3 × (MV)
F Jackson rees modification 2-3 × (MV) 2 × (MV)

 

Note:

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in spontaneous ventilation is  A > DFE > CB (A Dog Can Bite - Usually a spontaneous event)

The efficiency of Mapleson circuits in controlled ventilation is DFE > BC > A (Dead Babies can't assist - controlled)



Related Pearl: Identification of Mapleson's circuits

Mapleson System

 Fresh gas flow inlet APL valve location Reservoir bag Corrugated tubing Example and comments
A Near bag Near patient Present Present

Magill;

Lack (co-axial) 
B Near patient Near patient Present Present Obsolete
C Near patient Near patient Present Absent Obsolete; Still used in emergency resuscitation (AMBU bag)
D Near patient Away from patient Present Present Bain (co-axial)
E Near patient Absent Absent Present Ayre's T piece
F Near patient Absent Present Present Jackson Rees Modification for pediatric patients

questions.text: A breastfeeding mother presented to the clinic with fever and breast pain for the past 2 days. The affected breast appears as shown in the image below. There is extreme tenderness on palpation. Which of the following is the most common source for the organism causing this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of lactational mastitis. The most common source of infection is from the infant's nasopharynx.

Lactational mastitis is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus present in the infant's nasopharynx. The organism enters the breast tissue through cracked nipples and multiplies in the stagnant breast milk. Patients present with fever with a firm, red, tender, and swollen quadrant of the unilateral breast.

Painful breasts must be managed by the use of analgesics. Breastfeeding should be continued if the pain is less severe. Antibiotics like flucloxacillin, co-amoxiclav are used to treat the infection. If the patient develops an abscess, then the abscess has to be drained by aspiration or incision.

  Bacterial mastitis Breast abscess
Condition Localized inflammation due to ascending infection or infection due to milk stasis  Occurs as a complication of mastitis, with pus formation
Symptoms Dull pain Throbbing pain
Signs (if any) Tenderness, erythema Point tenderness, erythema, induration of skin (if chronic) lymphadenopathy, fluctuation test +ve
Management Analgesics, antibiotics Analgesics, aspiration of pus, antibiotics

questions.text: An asymptomatic 30-year-old man presents with a lesion on his thigh as seen in the below image. He returned a week ago from the US where he inspected farming areas during the summer. The best management for this patient would be:

choices.text: Reassurance as it is a fixed drug eruption

questions.solution:
The given image classically depicts the bull’s eye lesion (erythema chronicum migrans) and the clinical history is suggestive of the diagnosis of Lyme disease. The drug of choice for early asymptomatic Lyme disease is Doxycycline 100 mg BD.

Lyme disease is caused by the spirochete Borrelia burgdorferi and is transmitted by the hard tick, Ixodes. It usually occurs after a tick bite while strolling through the farms. Most of them do not recall the bite and the initial presentation is only a skin lesion known as erythema chronicum migrans.

It is only after dissemination, that the disease spreads to joints (arthritis), heart (AV blocks), and the nervous system (neuroborreliosis).

The treatment protocol for early Lyme disease includes:

  • Doxycycline 100 mg BD (Drug of choice) for 2-3 weeks (or)
  • Amoxicillin 500 – 1000 mg for 2-3 weeks (for children < 9 years, pregnant women)

In severe disseminated cases, Ceftriaxone 2 g IV for 2-3 weeks can be given. 

Other options:

Option A - Chloroquine and tafenoquine are used to prevent Plasmodium vivax malaria relapse. There are no clinical symptoms suggestive of Malaria. 

Option C - Antihistamines can be used to treat urticaria. Patients present with short-lived itchy weals, angioedema, or both. 

Option D - Fixed drug eruption presents as a sharply defined oval or round erythematous, edematous plaque. It becomes dusky, violaceous, and vesicular or bullous. It occurs in the lips, genitals, palms, and soles.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the mucocele of the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
The gall bladder is easily palpable in mucocele.

  • Mucocele is due to prolonged obstruction of the cystic duct usually by a large solitary calculus.
  • Obstructed GB lumen is progressively distended by mucus or by a clear transudate produced by mucous epithelial cells.
  • Clinical features:
    • A visible, easily palpable, non-tender gall bladder
    • Frequently remains asymptomatic.
  • Treatment: early cholecystectomy

questions.text: A diabetic patient presents with bloody nasal discharge, orbital swelling, and pain. The culture of Periorbital pus showed the following appearance. The most probable organism is
questions.solution:
The image shows septate hyphae showing dichotomous branching with typical conidiophore seen in microscopy which is characteristic of aspergillus infection.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: You suffer a bleeding puncture wound on your finger while assisting with surgery on a patient infected with HIV. What regimen should you take in this situation?
questions.solution:
Recommended post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is a three-drug regimen that includes lamivudine, tenofovir, and dolutegravir.

A regimen for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. 

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Code

HIV Source Code

          PEP Recommendation

1

 1

 Not required

1

 2

 Recommended

2

 1

 Recommended

2

 2

 Recommended

3

 1/2

 Recommended

2/3

Not known

Consider PEP if HIV prevalence is high in the given population

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: True regarding osteosarcoma is:

choices.text: Pathological fracture is the most common presentation
There is increased risk of osteosarcoma in Paget’s disease
Most commonly occurs around the hip

questions.solution:
There is an increased risk of osteosarcoma in Paget’s disease.

Osteosarcoma can be primary or secondary. Secondary osteosarcoma may be related to previous radiation, Paget’s disease, fibrous dysplasia, bone infarcts, chronic osteomyelitis or in dedifferentiated chondrosarcomas.

Patients complain of worsening pain and swelling, particularly suffering night pain, non-mechanical pain or joint restriction. Pathological fracture is rare. Typically metaphyseal or metadiaphyseal, the majority present at the distal femur, proximal tibia, proximal femur and humerus.

questions.text: Punishment for infanticide comes under:
questions.solution:
In India, infanticide is considered as murder and punishment is given under section 302 IPC.

Option C: IPC 304A – Punishment for Rash or Negligent Homicide. If death of a person is caused by any rash or negligent act, not amounting to culpable homicide, the punishment is imprisonment up to 2 years, or fine or both.

Option D: IPC 306 – Punishment for abetment of suicide.

Other relevant sections:

  • Section 317 IPC – Abandoning the foetus.
  • Section 318 IPC – Concealment of birth.

questions.text: A surgeon sees a necrotic bowel when operating on a child for an inguinal hernia. What is true about the resection and anastomosis of the bowel?

choices.text: The surgeon must use chromic catgut
The surgeon must not include the submucosa in the sutures
The surgeon must use the single-layer, extramucosal suture technique
The surgeon must use the single-layer seromuscular suture technique

questions.solution:
The standard technique used currently for resection anastomosis of the bowel is a one-layer extra mucosal suture technique since it causes the least tissue necrosis and luminal narrowing. Interrupted and continuous single-layer suture techniques are adequate and safe.

The extra mucosal suture must also include the submucosa because this layer has a high collagen content and it is the most stable suture layer in all sections of the gastrointestinal tract.

Catgut has now been replaced with absorbable synthetic polymers. Stapling devices can be used when speed is required.

questions.text: Risk of tubal pregnancy is increased by all except?
questions.solution:
Oral combined pill use does not increase the risk of ectopic pregnancy. In fact, combined pills reduce the risk of ectopic pregnancy.

Risk factors of ectopic pregnancy:

  • Previous ectopic pregnancy
  • Tubal corrective surgery, tubectomy
  • IUCD
  • Assisted reproductive technology
  • Documented tubal pathology
  • Pelvic inflammatory disease (Chlamydia infection and salpingitis isthmica nodosa)
  • Genital tuberculosis
  • Endometriosis
  • Pelvic adhesions
  • Congenital elongation, accessory ostia, diverticula
  • Transmigration
  • Smoking
  • Prior abortion
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Prior Caesarean delivery
  • Progesterone-only pills (POPs)

questions.text: The morphologic hallmark of nonrheumatic, calcific aortic stenosis is?

choices.text: Heaped-up calcified masses within the aortic cusps
Involvement of the free edges of the cusps preventing opening
Functional valve area is increased by large nodular calcific deposits

questions.solution:
The morphologic hallmark of nonrheumatic, calcific aortic stenosis is heaped-up calcified masses within the aortic cusps that ultimately protrude through the outflow surfaces into the sinuses of Valsalva, preventing the opening of the cusps.

The free edges of the cusps are usually not involved. Functional valve area is decreased by large nodular calcific deposits, causing obstruction to outflow.

In contrast to rheumatic and congenital aortic stenosis, commissural fusion is not usually seen.

Note: 

Calcific Aortic Stenosis is the most common of all valvular abnormalities

questions.text: The type of uterine fibromyoma in the image
questions.solution:
The given image depicts Submucous type of uterine fibromyoma.

Uterine myomas are broadly classified into 3 types.

They are-

  • Intramural - remains within the myometrial wall.
  • Submucous - present inside the uterine cavity and covered only by a thin endometrium.
  • Subserous - present towards the peritoneal surface.

Treatment includes:

  • Hormones to shrink the fibroid
  • Uterine artery embolization.
  • Myomectomy.
  • Total / subtotal hysterectomy.

Related Pearl: Secondary changes and complications in fibromyomas

  • Hyaline change, cystic degeneration and atrophy
  • Calcareous degeneration, osseous degeneration
  • Red degeneration
  • Sarcomatous change
  • Torsion, hemorrhage
  • Infection/ ulceration, particularly in the dependent part of a submucous polyp
  • Inversion of the uterus
  • Endometrial carcinoma associated with fibromyoma
  • Endometrial and myohyperplasia
  • Accompanying adenomyosis
  • Parasitic fibroid

questions.text: Which of the following is true about lipoprotein metabolism and its disorders?

choices.text: HDL has maximum cholesterol and cholesterol ester
Molecular defect in familial hypercholestrolemia is lipoprotein lipase
Abetalipoproteinemia is due to mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene

questions.solution:
Abetalipoproteinemia is due to loss of function mutation in gene encoding Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP).

MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons and VLDL's in the intestine and liver, respectively. Therefore, when MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL and LDL are not produced.

Other options:

LDL has maximum cholesterol and cholesterol ester.

HDL has maximum electrophoretic mobility, least diameter and maximum protein content.

Molecular defect in familial hypercholesterolemia is in LDL receptors. Whereas molecular defect in familial chylomicronemia syndrome is in lipoprotein lipase or Apo CII.

questions.text: An HIV positive pregnant woman was brought to the ER after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. CECT was done which showed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the cerebral lesions was done and the image is given below. Which of the following is the most appropriate drug for her treatment?
questions.solution:
Seizures in an HIV-positive patient with CECT showing multiple enhancing lesions and the image showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding bradyzoites encased in cysts are suggestive of cerebral toxoplasmosis. Spiramycin is the drug of choice during pregnancy.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in HIV-positive patients and usually occurs when CD4+ T cell counts <100/μL. Patients present with altered mental status, fever, seizures, headaches and focal neurologic findings, like motor deficits, cranial nerve palsies, movement disorders, dysmetria, visual-field loss and aphasia. On contrast-enhanced CT, ring-enhancing lesions are seen. Calcification may also be seen in old lesions.

Other diagnostic tests include Sabin-Feldman dye test, indirect immunofluorescence, indirect hemagglutination, complement fixation test (CFT) and ELISA. Sabin-Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against toxoplasma which remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is the most commonly used test and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks. The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

questions.text:
The stool culture of a patient with suspected food poisoning produced hemolytic colonies on blood agar. The isolated organism gave a positive indole test and a positive MUG test. You observe the following colonies on eosin methylene blue agar. Identify the organism.

MUG - 4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide
questions.solution:
The given scenario of a patient with suspected food poisoning with stool culture growing hemolytic colony on blood agar with a positive indole test and MUG test with a iridescent green colony growth on eosin methylene blue agar is characteristic of Escherichia coli. 

E. coli produces the enzyme β-glucuronidase which is tested using the MUG test. In it, the substrate MUG (4-methylumbelliferyl-β-glucuronide) is reduced by the enzyme to produce a fluorescent color which indicates a positive MUG test.

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

questions.text: The first internal organ to putrify is  usually the __________
questions.solution:
The order of putrefaction of organs from first to last:

Larynx and trachea—> Stomach, intestine, spleen—>Liver and lungs —> Brain—>Heart—->Kidney and the bladder—>Prostate and uterus—>Bones

  • first external sign: Greenish discoloration of the skin over the region of the caecum.
  • Earliest internal change: Reddish-brown discoloration of the inner surface of vessels, especially of the aorta.
  • Sulphmethemoglobin is the agent imparting greenish color.

Related Pearl: Order of Putrefaction

  • Larynx and trachea – first organ to putrify   
  • Stomach, intestine, and spleen
  • Liver and lungs
  • Brain
  • Heart
  • Kidney and bladder
  • Prostate and uterus – virgin uterus resists putrefaction whereas uterus soon after delivery putrefies rapidly.
  • Skin, muscle, tendon
  • Bones


NOTE: This is only a generalised order of putrefaction, as each case must be assessed as per the attending factors, both endogenous and exogenous.

questions.text: A 39-year-old man had sustained major injuries in an accident as his legs were trapped under the wheel of a car. Which of the following agents can be ideally used by the EMS personnel to provide sedation and pain relief to the patient while shifting him to the hospital?
questions.solution:
Ketamine is the ideal agent of choice to provide sedation and analgesia in the prehospital setting.

Drugs that can be used by nurses and paramedics in the prehospital setting like the site of RTA/Trauma should have-

  • Wide safety margin, even for inexperienced providers
  • Hemodynamic stability
  • Minimal respiratory depression
  • Ease of administration
  • Early-onset of action

Ketamine provides potent analgesia and sedation for entrapped patients with trauma during extrication. It maintains hemodynamic stability in patients with hypovolemic shock, is a potent bronchodilator, and causes minimal respiratory depression. Because of its hallucinogenic properties, benzodiazepines should be co-administered. In larger doses, it can be used for induction of anaesthesia.

Option C: Benzodiazepines like diazepam and midazolam have wide safety margins and can be administered via many routes and can be used to provide sedation, but lack an analgesic action.

Option A and B: Propofol causes hemodynamic instability and respiratory depression and thiopentone produces effects similar to propofol.

questions.text: A scaphoid fracture is bridged using the following screw. Identify the screw
questions.solution:
This is a Herbert screw, which is cannulated and threaded at both ends. It is designed for use in fractures of small articular bones such as the carpals and the scaphoid. The proximal portion has a wider pitch to its thread. This screw is used where a standard screw would impinge on adjacent tissues.

The Acutrak screw is also used for the treatment of most scaphoid fractures.  It is a cannulated, headless and fully threaded screw.

The interference screw is a direct tendon-to-bone interference fixation device.

questions.text: The posture shown in image is seen in :
questions.solution:
The given image shows decorticate posturing. It is caused due to upper midbrain damage.

Decorticate posture is caused due to damage to the upper midbrain. The upper limbs are flexed, the lower limbs are extended with toes pointed slightly inward, and the head is extended. Decorticate posturing is given a score of 3 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Decerebrate posture is caused by damage to the lower midbrain and upper pons. Here, lower extremities are extended with toes pointed inward and upper extremities extended with fingers flexed and forearms pronated. The neck and head are extended. Decerebrate posture has a score of 2 in best motor response on the Glasgow Coma Scale.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: Which of the following media is used as transport media for Neisseria species?
questions.solution:
Stuart Transport Medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to laboratory.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

  • Sodium glycerophosphate
  • Sodium thioglycollate
  • Calcium chloride
  • Methylene blue
  • Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

  • This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium which prevent microbial proliferation.
  • Because of this composition the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
  • Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes.
  • Methylene blue acts as oxidation reduction indicator.
  • Calcium chloride maintains permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.
  • The medium appears colourless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

Related Pearl: Organisms and their transport media

Organism Transport media
Streptococcus Pike’s media
Neisseria Stuart media
Shigella, Salmonella Cary Blair medium
Vibrio cholera

Cary Blair medium

Venkatraman–Ramakrishnan medium

Autoclaved sea water

questions.text: Both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies are found in case of
questions.solution:
Both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies are found in case of infection with measles virus and CMV.

Inclusion bodies:

  • Inclusion bodies are structures with different size, shape, location and staining properties that can be demonstrated in virus infected cells.
  • It is made up of
    • Crystalline aggregates of virions
    • Viral antigens at the site of virus synthesis
    • Degenerative changes produced by the virus in infected cells

Important inclusion bodies:

Intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies

Negri bodies - Rabies virus

Paschen bodies - Variola virus

Guarnieri bodies - Vaccinia virus

Bollinger bodies - Fowl pox virus

Molluscum bodies - Molluscum contagiosum virus

Perinuclear cytoplasmic body - Reovirus
Intranuclear inclusion bodies
  • Cowdry type A inclusion bodies

             Torres bodies - Yellow fever

             Lipschultz bodies - Herpes simplex

  • Cowdry type B inclusion bodies - Adenovirus, Polio virus
Both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies:  Measles and cytomegalovirus (Owl’s eye appearance)

questions.text: Ascoli’s thermo precipitin test is used to demonstrate the toxicity of:
questions.solution:
Ascoli's Thermo precipitation test is used for the diagnosis of anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) using a tissue extract and anthrax antiserum.

It is a precipitin test in which the antibody produces visible precipitate when it reacts with the antigen. It is used for detection of anthrax bacilli in animal hides and meat.

But this test lacks specificity because the thermostable antigen of bacillus anthrax is shares by other species of bacillus too.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: A 10-year-old male child presents with a history of easy bruisiability and hemarthrosis. Investigations revealed normal platelet count and bleeding time, normal PT, and prolonged PTT. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The symptom of hemarthrosis and the investigations are suggestive of a coagulation disorder. Among the given options, hemophilia A is a coagulation disorder, while all the other conditions are platelet disorders.

Bleeding into joints (hemarthrosis) and deep tissues is a feature of coagulation disorders, whereas platelet disorders usually present with mucocutaneous bleeding such as petechiae, purpura, epistaxis, or GI bleed. Prolonged PT/aPTT is a feature of coagulation disorders, while prolonged bleeding time is a feature of platelet disorders.

In the given scenario, normal platelet count and bleeding time exclude platelet disorders. Normal PT indicates normal functioning of the extrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade, and prolonged PTT indicates a defect in the intrinsic pathway.

Hemophilia is an X-linked (recessive) coagulation disorder associated with mutations in factor VIII, affecting the intrinsic pathway. The patients present with easy bruising, significant hemorrhage following trauma and operative procedures, and hemarthroses, but no petechiae. The diagnosis is confirmed by carrying out factor VIII-specific assays. Infusions of recombinant factor VIII are used for treatment. 

Other options:

Option 1: Von Willebrand disease is an autosomal dominant disorder that is associated with qualitative/quantitative defects in the von Willebrand factor (vWF). vWF is a protein necessary for platelet adhesion, platelet aggregation, and stabilization of factor VIII.

Option 3: Bernard-Soulier disease is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIb receptor necessary for platelet adhesion to the subendothelial collagen. 

Option 4: Glanzmann's thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive condition that is characterized by the absence of the GpIIb/IIIa receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.
