questions.text: A 75-year-old man presents to the OPD with a high-grade fever and a productive cough. Your senior asks you to calculate his modified CURB-65 score.  Which of the following is not included in the modified version of the CURB-65 criteria?

choices.text: Systolic BP ≤ 90 mmHg or Diastolic BP ≤ 60 mmHg

questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient presented with symptoms of community-acquired pneumonia. Blood urea nitrogen is not included in the modified version of the CURB-65 criteria. This elimination removes the need for laboratory testing.

CURB-65 and the Pneumonia severity index (PSI) are tools used for decision-making with regard to whether or not a patient diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia requires hospital admission.

CURB-65 assesses five factors, which include confusion, blood urea nitrogen, respiratory rate, blood pressure, and age greater than 65. In a modified version of the CURB-65, the blood urea nitrogen has been removed. It also helps in assessing the mortality rate in those diagnosed with community-acquired pneumonia.

The pneumonia severity index assesses for as many as 20 items under demographics, clinical history, physical examination, laboratory, and imaging findings. Based on the criteria the patients are stratified into five risk groups.

Related Pearl: CURB-65 Criteria

This is a score to determine the severity of pneumonia.

The CURB-65 criteria include five variables(1 point for each variable):

  • Confusion 
  • Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) >7 mmol/L
  • Respiratory rate ≥30/min 
  • Blood pressure, systolic ≤90 mmHg or diastolic ≤60 mmHg 
  • Age ≥65 years.

Management:

0 point: Treat as an outpatient

1 to 2 points: Admitted to the hospital

≥3 points: ICU admission

Treatment of Community-Acquired Pneumonia 

Score - 0: The drug of choice is macrolides.

                     Azithromycin 500mg OD

                                  or

                   Clarithromycin  500mg BD

                                  or

                   Doxycycline  100mg BD.

Score - 1: Treated with azithromycin  500mg OD + ceftriaxone 2gm OD.

               Respiratory quinolones (Levofloxacin) are not preferred.

Score - >2: Azithromycin 500mg OD + Ceftriaxone 2gm IV OD and specific management.

NOTE:- In a modified version of the CURB-65, the criteria of blood urea nitrogen has been removed.

           This elimination removes the need for lab testing.

questions.text: The most common primary malignant orbital tumor in children originates from _________
questions.solution:
The most common primary malignant orbital tumor in children is rhabdomyosarcoma, which usually arises from soft tissues such as muscle.

  • Most common primary malignant orbital tumor in children: Rhabdomyosarcoma
  • Most common primary benign orbital tumor in adults: Cavernous hemangioma 
  • Most common primary malignant orbital tumor in adults: Lymphoma

questions.text: The mother of a newborn in your unit is extremely sick and is unable to feed her baby. The relatives have arranged a breast milk donor and wish to feed the baby using the device shown in the image. This method of primary feeding can be recommended in newborns with a gestational age of _______
questions.solution:
The given image shows paladai. It can be used as a primary feeding method during routine feeding in neonates born at gestational age 32-34 weeks only. Sick mothers or mothers with contraindications to breastfeeding can feed their child using paladai. The milk can either be expressed breastmilk or they can resort to using undiluted cow milk or formula feeds. 

<32 weeks will not have the coordination between swallowing and breathing. So, paladai can only be used occasionally.

>34 weeks will have a completely mature sucking pattern when breastfeeding becomes more preferred.

Choice of initial feeding methods in low-birth-weight (LBW) infants

Gestational Age Feeding Skill Matured Method of Feeding
<28 weeks No proper sucking effort. No propulsive motility of the gut IV Fluids
28-32 weeks

Sucking Bursts develop

No coordination between suck/swallow and breathing

 Oro-gastric/ Nasogastric tube feeding with occasional spoon/ paladai feeding
32-34 weeks Slightly mature sucking pattern. Coordination between breathing and swallowing begins Feeding by spoon/paladai/cup
>34 weeks Mature sucking pattern. More coordination between breathing and swallowing Breastfeeding

questions.text: Exposure to sound with a minimum level of _______ dB can lead to rupture of tympanic membrane, resulting in hearing loss
questions.solution:
Exposure to sound with a minimum level of 160 dB can lead to rupture of tympanic membrane, resulting in hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Effects of Noise Exposure

  • Auditory effects
    • Auditory fatigue appears at 90 dB and is greatest at 4000 Hz. Whistling and buzzing in ear occurs with auditory fatigue.
    • Temporary deafness or hearing loss occurs after a single exposure to a noise, usually at a frequency range of 4000 – 6000 Hz. It disappears after 24 hours following noise exposure.
    • Permanent hearing loss can result after continuous or repeated exposure to noises around 100 dB. It occurs commonly as occupational hearing loss.
    • Exposure to noise above 160 dB may rupture the tympanic membrane and cause permanent hearing loss.
  • Non-auditory effects
    • Interference with speech occurs when sound has a frequency of 300 – 500 Hz
    • Annoyance is a psychological response to noise which can greatly affect efficiency and concentration
    • Noise has also been known to cause some physiological changes like increased blood pressure, intracranial pressure, increased sweating, etc.

questions.text: Which of the following interleukin preparations are used in severe thrombocytopenia
questions.solution: Interleukin-11 stimulates hematopoiesis and a recombinant human preparation, oprelvekin is indicated in severe thrombocytopenia.

questions.text: The image given below shows an eyeball with a refractive error. All the following fundal changes can be seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image given above shows parallel rays of light converging at a point in front of the retina. Hence, the refractive error is myopia. All the fundal changes mentioned above can be seen in myopia, except cattle track appearance.

Cattle truck appearance is seen in branch retinal artery occlusion (not myopia).

Pathological/degenerative myopia is characterized by progressive anteroposterior elongation of the scleral envelope associated with secondary ocular changes due to mechanical stretching of the involved tissues.

Clinically patients present with defective vision, floating black opacities (muscae volitantes), and difficulty with night vision. Examination of the fundus reveals the following changes:

  • Optic disc:
    • Temporal myopic crescent
  • Retina and choroid:
    • Lacquer cracks are fine irregular yellow lines crisscrossing at the posterior pole, due to ruptures in the Bruch membrane.
    • Subretinal coin hemorrhages develop from lacquer cracks.
    • Fuchs spot: It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion at the macula which develops after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed.
    • A pale tessellated (tigroid) appearance of the fundus is seen due to diffuse attenuation of the RPE with large choroidal vessels.
    • Lattice degeneration
  • Vitreous: Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) appears as Weiss' reflex.
  • Posterior staphyloma.

The image given below shows fundal changes seen in pathological myopia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

Related Pearl: Grading of Myopia

American Optometric Association (AOA) Grading of Myopia:

  • Low myopia, when the error is < –3D.
  • Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.
  • High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a parenteral anticoagulant?
questions.solution:
Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor.

Heparin, fondaparinux and enoxaparin (LMWH) are parenteral anticoauglants (options a, b and c).

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids has an ammonia group in its side chain and is thus likely to be an intermediate of the urea cycle?
questions.solution:
• Arginine is an amino acid having an ammonia side chain and is also part of the urea cycle.
  • Citrulline and ornithine are other important urea cycle intermediates.
  • Aspartate is condensed with citrulline to form argininosuccinate in the urea cycle(Aspartate is not an intermediate)
  • Acetylglutamate is a cofactor in the joining of carbon dioxide with ammonia to form carbamoyl phosphate at the beginning of the urea cycle.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: A defect in which chromosome leads to the condition exhibiting the following ocular manifestation?
questions.solution:
The image shows Lisch nodules which are iris hamartomas, seen in neurofibromatosis. It is usually seen in NF1, caused due to mutation of NF1 gene on Chromosome 17.

The NF1 gene product, neurofibromin, normally serves as a tumor suppressor.

Neurofibromatosis:

  • Autosomal-dominant neurocutaneous syndrome
   NF1 (von Recklinghausen disease)
       NF2 (Central Neurofibromatosis)

Mutation on Chromosome 17

   2 or more of the following should be present:

  • 6 or more café-au-lait spots
  • 2 or more neurofibromas or one plexiform neuroma
  • Freckling in axillary or inguinal region 
  • 2 or more Lisch nodules
  • Dysplasia of the sphenoidal and tibial bone
  • A first degree relative with NF1
  • Optic gliomas

Mutation in Chromosome 22

  • Predisposes to multiple tumors of the nervous system.
  • Most common are bilateral vestibular schwannomas; intracranial and spinal meningiomas, gliomas, neurofibromas, and posterior subcapsular lenticular opacities.
  • Vestibular schwannomas: Benign tumors arise from the intracanalicular segment of the vestibular portion of inferior division of vestibulocochlear nerve. Extracanalicular extension into the cerebellopontine angle can lead to "ice cream cone" appearance in MRI.

Axillary freckling

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of the vector of malaria?

choices.text: Larva parallel to undersurface of water

questions.solution:
• Anopheles mosquito larvae do not have siphon tubes.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation

Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A  leprosy vaccine is being introduced on a pilot basis in India. Which of the following mycobacterial species is the basis for its development?
questions.solution:
Mycobacterium indicus pranii is the basis for the development of a leprosy vaccine.

The leprosy vaccine species was originally called Mycobacterium W (M.w) but was later renamed Mycobacterium indicus pranii. The vaccine is administered via intradermal route. The dose is 0.1 ml. It is divided into two equal doses and given on both arms.

Booster doses will be given to maintain the immunity level. These are given only in one arm.

Since its development as an anti-leprosy vaccine, Mycobacterium indicus pranii (MIP) has been evaluated as prophylactic as well as a therapeutic vaccine against TB in animal models and clinical set-ups. Besides the presence of its unique immunogens, MIP also shares a repertoire of highly antigenic proteins of M.tb that renders it as a promising vaccine candidate.

questions.text: Identify this arthropod known to transmit endemic typhus:
questions.solution:
Rat fleas are known to transmit bubonic plague, endemic typhus and chiggerosis (tropical typhus).

Sandflies transmit diseases like kala-azar.

Tsetse flies transmit trypanosomiasis or sleeping sickness.

Reduviid bugs transmit Chagas’ disease and are also called cone-nose bugs/kissing bugs/ assassin bugs/vampire bugs.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought to the emergency with symptoms of cyanosis, rapid breathing, and failure to thrive. The chest X-ray of the child is given below. Probable diagnosis is ____________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a snowman or figure of 8 appearance. The probable diagnosis in the above case is Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection.

TAPVC: Pulmonary veins instead of draining into left atrium drain into right atrium directly or indirectly. Following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior vena cava or the left innominate vein
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

questions.text: All are examples of hypersensitivity mediated by antibodies except:
questions.solution:
Serum sickness is an example of type III / immune complex mediated hypersensitivity.

Type III/ immune complex mediated hypersensitivity :

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus
  • Arthus reaction
  • Reactive arthritis
  • Polyarteritis nodosa
  • Serum sickness
  • Poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis

Related Pearl: Types of Type II Antibody-Mediated Hypersentivity

There are 3 mechanisms involved in type 2 hypersensitivity reactions- 

  1. Antibody-mediated cellular dysfunction- antibodies react with antigens present on cell surfaces or in the extracellular matrix cause disease by destroying these cells, triggering inflammation, or interfering with normal functions
    1. Myasthenia gravis (against acetylcholine receptor)
    2. Graves’ disease (against TSH receptor)
    3. Pemphigus Vulgaris (against epidermal cadherin)
    4. Pernicious anemia (against intrinsic factor)
    5. Insulin resistant diabetes (against insulin receptor
  2. Antibody-mediated opsonization and phagocytosis -antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement and Recruiting Phagocytes
    1. Transfusion reactions
    2. Erythroblastosis fetalis
    3. Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
    4. Autoimmune thrombocytopenic purpura
  3. Complement and Fc receptor-mediated inflammation- antibodies may deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating complement
    1. Goodpasture syndrome
    2. Vasculitis due to ANCA
    3. Acute rheumatic fever
    4. Vascular rejection in organ graft 

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: Which salivary gland tumor appears as a hot spot on technetium-99m scan?
questions.solution:
Warthin tumour is a salivary gland tumour that appears as a hot spot on the technetium-99m scan.

Because of the high mitochondrial content within oncocytes, the oncocyte-rich warthin tumor and oncocytomas incorporate technetium-99m and appear as hot spots on radionuclide scan.

Warthins tumour:

  • Warthins tumor is seen in elderly male smokers
  • 2nd most common benign tumour of parotid gland.
  • Usually Unilateral and involves the lower pole of parotid
  • Slow growing well encapsulated, cystic
  • Hot spot on radionuclide scan
  • Histology- Lined by double layer of neoplastic epithelial cells resting on dense lymphoid stroma.
  • Investigation- FNAC
  • Treatment- Superficial parotidectomy

questions.text: An elderly male presented with a history of fall on outstretched hand following which he developed swelling of the wrist. His X-ray is shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above X-ray shows fracture scaphoid.

Scaphoid fractures account for almost 75 percent of all carpal fractures although they are rare in the elderly and in children.

Mechanism of injury- The combination of forced carpal movement and compression, as in a fall on the dorsiflexed hand.

Diagnostic sign- precisely localized tenderness in the anatomical snuff box. 

X-ray-

  • Anteroposterior, lateral and oblique views are all essential
  • often a recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.
  • Usually, the fracture line is transverse, and through the narrowest part of the bone (waist), but it may be more proximally situated (proximal pole fracture).
    Old, un-united fractures have hard borders, making it seem as if there is an extra carpal bone.
  • Relative sclerosis of the proximal fragment is pathognomonic of avascular necrosis.

NOTE: The distal fragment, unrestrained by the scapholunate ligament, flexes and the proximal fragment tilt dorsally with the lunate (a DISI deformity). The hump-backed deformity of the scaphoid is permanent.

questions.text: Which is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Nodular Sclerosis is the most common subtype of Hodgkin lymphoma.

Nodular Sclerosis type:

  • Most common form of HL (65-70%)
  • Incidence is equal in men and women
  • Commonly involves the lower cervical, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes
  • Adolescents and young adults affected commonly
  • Excellent prognosis

Morphology: Lacunar variant of RS cell is seen

questions.text: True about the structure given below is ________

choices.text: They are nuclear remnants in RBC

questions.solution:
The image shows Heinz bodies which are seen in G6PD deficiency.

Heinz bodies:

  • Exposure of G6PD deficient red cells to high levels of oxidants causes the cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. These become denatured and form membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies.
  • Visualized by supravital staining.
  • Bite cells - as the splenic macrophages pluck out these inclusions, bite cells are produced.

Howell Jolly bodies:

  • Small nuclear remnants seen as inclusions in red cells due to asplenia.
  • They can also be seen in sickle cell anemia due to auto splenectomy or in Hereditary spherocytosis or thalassemia post splenectomy in some red cells but it is not characteristic. The image shows Howell Jolly bodies in peripheral blood smear.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with gait abnormalities and tremors. The eye examination reveals the following. Which of the following is true about this condition:
questions.solution:
Serum copper level is low.

The image above shows fine, pigmented and granular deposits in the cornea. This finding is characteristically seen in Wilson’s disease. It is an autosomal recessive condition due to mutation of ATP7B gene.

Although Wilson’s disease is caused because of excess copper deposition in tissues, the serum copper level is normal to low. This is because copper is mainly present in the plasma in the bound form with ceruloplasmin. Because the functional ceruloplasmin is low is in plasma, the copper gets deposited in tissues. The free copper also gets excreted in the urine causing urine copper level to be high.

Kayser–Fleischer rings (KF rings) are dark rings that appear to encircle the iris of the eye. They are due to copper deposition in part of the cornea (Descemet's membrane).

Sunflower cataracts are another ocular manifestation of Wilson disease and occur when copper deposits accumulate in the lens. Other findings in Wilson’s disease:

  • Hepatic: Liver failure, coombs negative haemolytic anaemia, acute hepatitis, cirrhosis
  • Neurologic: Dysarthria, movement disorders often stats unilaterally
  • Psychiatric: Depression , personality change, irritability.

questions.text: Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of bleeding located _________
questions.solution:
Hematemesis and melena are the usual presenting features of upper gastrointestinal bleeding. Upper GI bleeding is derived from a source proximal to the ligament of Treitz.

The ligament of Treitz is part of the duodenojejunal junction and forms the line of demarcation for gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding.

Upper GI bleeding refers to bleeding proximal to the ligament of Treitz, and lower GI bleeding refers to bleeding distal to the ligament of Treitz.

questions.text: A 24-year-old woman at 28 weeks of gestation presents with chills and cyclical fever with sweats. She is diagnosed with P. falciparum malaria infection. Which of the following regimens will you prescribe her?
questions.solution:
A 28 week pregnant female suffering from falciparum malaria should be treated with Artemesinin based combination therapy.

Treatment of malaria in pregnancy:

  • 2nd and 3rd trimester: ACT is preferred as quinine can cause increased risk of hypoglycemia.
  • 1st trimester: Drug of choice for falciparum malaria during 1st trimester of pregnancy is quinine combined with clindamycin for 7 days. Artemisinin based combination therapy (ACT) is not recommended during 1st trimester of pregnancy because of lack of safety data.

Doxycycline is not indicated in pregnancy.

questions.text: Reliable diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma can be made from all except
questions.solution:
Papanicolaou smear is not a reliable diagnostic test for endometrial carcinoma. It is positive only in 30 percent of cases of endometrial cancer.

Diagnosis of endometrial carcinoma:

  • Endometrial biopsy: using a Sharman curette or a soft, flexible, plastic suction cannula (pipelle) has been done with reliability (90%). Histology is the definitive diagnosis.
  • Ultrasound and color Doppler (TVS):

-Endometrial thickness > 4 mm.

-Hyperechoic endometrium with irregular outline.

-Increased vascularity with low vascular resistance.

-Intrauterine fluid.

  • Hysteroscopy: It helps in the direct visualization of the endometrium and to take target biopsy.
  • Fractional curettage: It is the definitive method of diagnosis and can also detect the extent of growth.

questions.text:
The craniovertebral joint consists of:
1.	Atlas
2.	Axis
3.	Occipital Condyles
questions.solution:
Craniovertebral joints are formed by the articulation of the cranium with the vertebral column. The joint consists of atlas, axis and occipital condyles.

The atlanto-occipital and atlantoaxial joints are together called the craniovertebral joints.

These joints allow for a wide range of head movements that include horizontal and vertical movements and the eye-head coordination.

questions.text: Which of the following findings are seen in a patient with Brown-Sequard syndrome?

choices.text: Upper Motor Neuron type of paralysis below the lesion on the opposite side
Impaired fine touch below the lesion on the opposite side
Loss of crude touch below the lesion on the same side
Loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side

questions.solution:
A patient with Brown Sequard syndrome will have a loss of vibration sense below the lesion on the same side.

Brown-sequard syndrome is caused due to hemisection of the Spinal cord. It can be caused by fracture-dislocation of the vertebral column, by a bullet or stab wound, or by an expanding tumor.

Clinical features:

  • Pyramidal tract: Pyramidal weakness (ipsilateral upper motor neuron type of paralysis) below the level of the lesion on the same side as the lesion (pyramidal tract crosses in the medulla).
  • Dorsal columns: Impaired fine touch, 2 point discrimination, proprioception, vibration below the level of lesion on the same side of lesion (dorsal column fibres cross in the medulla).
  • Spinothalamic tract: Loss of pain, temperature, crude touch, pressure sensation below the level of the lesion on the contralateral side of the lesion (spinothalamic tract crosses midline after entering the cord).

 

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A person knows the truth and willfully conceals the truth and instead gives false evidence in the court of law. He will be punished under which IPC
questions.solution:
The person in the above situation has committed perjury.

Section 193 IPC deals with Punishment for giving or fabricating false evidence in judicial proceeding or in any other case.

Section Related with
191 Deals with false evidence and is based upon recognition of decline of moral values and erosion of sanctity of oath.(Perjury)
192 Fabricating false evidence
193 Punishment for giving or fabricating false evidence in judicial proceeding or in any other case.
197 Issuing or signing a certificate knowing or believing that the certificate is false.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses causes tropical spastic paraparesis?
questions.solution:
Human T-lymphotropic virus (HTLV) is the causative agent of the neurodegenerative disorder HTLV-1-associated myelopathy or tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP).

TSP resembles multiple sclerosis and is associated with progressive weakness of the legs and lower body. The patients develop spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, hyperreflexia, ankle clonus, and extensor plantar response. The disease progresses slowly and takes the form of thoracic myelopathy. MRI reveals lesions in the white matter and the paraventricular regions of the brain and spinal cord. The spinal cord shows symmetric degeneration of the lateral columns. 

HTLV-1 is a retrovirus with an affinity for mature T lymphocytes. It is transmitted via blood transfusions, contaminated needles, sexual intercourse and breastfeeding (mother-to-child transmission). HTLV-1 also causes adult T-cell leukemias and lymphomas (ATL), uveitis, infective dermatitis, arthritis and Sjögren’s syndrome.

questions.text: Which of the following anticancer drugs can cause a hypercoagulable state?
questions.solution:
L-asparaginase can cause a hypercoagulable state.

L-asparaginase causes the breakdown of asparagine and thus interferes with protein synthesis. It can inhibit the production of clotting factors, leading to cerebral haemorrhage. It can also inhibit anti-clotting proteins and can lead to cortical vein thrombosis and other hyper-coagulable sates.

questions.text: The section of the rectus sheath as shown in the image below is taken____
questions.solution:
The above section of rectus sheath is taken above the arcuate line, which corresponds to approximately one-third of the distance between the umbilicus and the pubis.

Although , a section below the umbilicus could be similar to that of a section above the arcuate line,the single best answer would be above the arcuate line.

 

  • The rectus sheath is a fibrous sheath which encloses the rectus abdominis muscle. It is formed by the aponeuroses of the external oblique, internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles. Each aponeurosis is bilaminar.
  • The anterior portion of this sheath extends the entire length of the muscle and fuses with periosteum and ligaments at sites of the muscle’s attachments.
  • The posterior part of the sheath is complete behind the upper two-thirds of the muscle but absent below the arcuate line. Below this level, rectus abdominis lies on the transversalis fascia and extraperitoneal connective tissue.

The composition of the rectus sheath is as follows

Above the arcuate line:

  • The anterior wall of the rectus sheath is formed by both laminae of external oblique and anterior lamina of internal oblique
  • The posterior wall is formed by posterior lamina of internal oblique and both laminae of transversus abdominis

Below the arcuate line:

  • All three aponeuroses from the external oblique, internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscles pass into the anterior rectus sheath.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with features mimicking appendicitis. Upon removal, the appendix is found to be grossly and histologically normal. A stool examination revealed motile gram-negative rods with a safety pin appearance. What is the etiology of this infection?
questions.solution:
It is a case of pseudo-appendicitis (appendicitis-like syndrome), caused by Yersinia enterocolitica. The picture showing bipolar staining or safety pin appearance is suggestive of Yersinia species on Wayson stain.

Yersinia enterocolitica is a gram-negative bacillus with a safety pin appearance. It causes gastroenteritis or mesenteric lymphadenitis after ingestion of contaminated food or water. 

In young children, it causes a self-limiting diarrheal illness. Patients with HLA-B27 who were infected with Y. enterocolitica develop arthralgia, arthritis, and erythema nodosum. 

Yersinia can be recovered from the stool of infected patients using selective media called CIN (Cefsulodin-Irgasan-Novobiocin) agar incubated at room temperature. Their colonies have a bull's eye appearance with a red center on CIN agar. Yersinia enterocolitica is motile at 25 °C, which differentiates it from Y. pestis which is non-motile.

Treatment for gastroenteritis caused by Y. enterocolitica consists of ciprofloxacin or a third-generation cephalosporin.

Other options : 

Option A: Clostridium difficile is a long slender gram-positive bacillus. It has large spores which are oval and subterminal. It is an opportunistic organism that rarely causes disease and does so only when normal flora is lost. It causes acute colitis with bloody or watery diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi are gram-negative rods that are motile with peritrichous flagella. It causes enteric fever or typhoid fever. 

Option C: Vibrio parahaemolyticus resembles V. cholera in its morphology except that it is capsulated shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. Strains isolated from humans are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar (special high salt blood agar). This is known as the Kanagawa phenomenon. It causes food poisoning associated with marine food intake. Abdominal pain, vomiting diarrhea, and fever are the usual signs. 

Related Pearl: Food Poisoning

Organism Symptoms Common food source

Staphylococcus aureus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Ham, poultry, potato, cream pastries, mayonnaise
Bacillus cereus Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea Fried rice

Clostridium perfringes Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Beef, poultry, legume, gravies
Bacillus cereus Abdominal cramps, diarrhea Meat, vegetables, dried beans, cereals
>16 hrs incubation period  
Vibrio cholerae Watery diarrhea Shellfish, water
Salmonella species Inflammatory diarrhea Beef, poultry, eggs

Campylobacter jejuni Inflammatory diarrhea Poultry, raw milk

questions.text: True statement concerning compound A is _____

choices.text: Seen predominantly with high flow techniques

questions.solution:
• True statement concerning compound A is less common with Amsorb adsorbent.
  • Compound A is fluoromethyl-2,2-difluoro-1-(trifluoromethyl) vinyl ether which is the degradation product of sevoflurane by the strong bases like sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide present in calcium hydroxide–based carbon dioxide absorbents (soda lime)
  • Compound A is nephrotoxic, not neurotoxic. It is also associated with transient albuminuria and glucosuria

Factors that increase the concentration of compound A include:

  • Prolonged exposure to sevoflurane
  • Higher concentrations of sevoflurane in the anesthetic circuit
  • Low flow anesthetic technique
  • The type of absorbent - baralyme and classic soda-lime had been with withdrawn due to a greater risk of compound A formation as they contain sodium hydroxide and potassium hydroxide. Potassium hydroxide produces a greater amount of compound A than sodium hydroxide. Newer soda-lime contains no potassium hydroxide.
    • Compound A formation is less or absent with amsorb due to its greater inertness.
  • Higher absorbent temperatures
  • Fresh absorbent
  • Desflurane on degradation with dry desiccated baralyme produces carbon monoxide. Although this phenomenon is seen with all halogenated inhalational anesthetics, it is maximum with desflurane ( desflurane ≥ enflurane > isoflurane >> halothane = sevoflurane)

questions.text: A surgeon applies a very tight plaster cast on patient’s leg and asks the patient to inform if he develops any numbness. The patient develops numbness but does not inform the doctor immediately. Next day, when the patient informs the doctor, the doctor says he is too busy to remove the cast. After a few days, the patient develops a permanent injury. The doctor is held guilty under:
questions.solution:
This is a case of last clear chance doctrine and the doctor is held guilty.

In this case:

  • The doctor showed negligence by applying tight plaster cast, however, gave proper instructions to the patient.
  • The patient has neglected by not informing the doctor immediately after he developed numbness.
  • When the patient informed the doctor the next day, the doctor still had a chance to remove the cast and prevent permanent injury. But the doctor again neglected and thus missed the last clear chance.

So, the doctor cannot plead for contributory negligence and will be held guilty under the last clear chance doctrine.

Other options:

Option D: Medical maloccurrence is a defence against negligence for doctors. In certain cases, despite proper medical skill, attention, and care, the patient may fail to respond or suffer from the adverse effects of drugs. 

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: The complications associated with extubation are all except:

choices.text: Increased blood pressure and heart rate

questions.solution:
The complication associated with extubation is negative pressure pulmonary edema which is a dangerous and potentially fatal condition.

Complications associated with extubation:

  • Laryngospasm and bronchospasm
  • Negative pressure pulmonary edema
  • Upper airway obstruction
  • Hypoventilation
  • Hemodynamic changes (hypertension, tachycardia)
  • Coughing and straining leading to surgical wound dehiscence
  • Laryngeal or airway edema
  • Paradoxical vocal cord motion
  • Arytenoid dislocation
  • Aspiration

Factors associated with increased extubation risk:

  • Airway risk factors
    • known difficult airway
    • airway deterioration (bleeding, edema, trauma)
    • restricted airway access
    • obesity and obstructive sleep apnea
    • aspiration risk
  • General risk factors
    • cardiovascular disease
    • respiratory disease
    • neuromuscular disease
    • metabolic derangements
    • special surgical requirements

questions.text: Which of the following methods of antibiotic susceptibility testing cannot be used to calculate the minimum inhibitory concentration of an antimicrobial drug?
questions.solution:
Minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) cannot be calculated using Kirby-Bauer's disk diffusion method and Stokes disk diffusion method as they are semi-quantitative methods.

MIC is the lowest concentration of an antimicrobial agent that will inhibit the visible growth of a microorganism. Methods to determine MIC include:

  • Tube dilution method
  • Agar dilution method
  • E-test method

World Antimicrobial Awareness Week, Nov 18-24 2022, is a global campaign that is celebrated annually to improve awareness and understanding of antimicrobial resistance and encourage best practices among the public. The theme for this year is “Preventing Antimicrobial Resistance Together” to encourage the prudent use of antimicrobials and to strengthen preventive measures addressing antimicrobial resistance

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has cervical intraepithelial neoplasia III. What would be the management?
questions.solution:
Colposcopy with LEEP would be appropriate management for CIN III.

Loop electrosurgical excision procedure (LEEP) is an opd procedure done under colposcopic view and local anesthesia.Here, a low voltage current is passed through the loop and a cone of tissue is removed from the cervix. This procedure causes minimal bleeding and the tissue removed is sent for histopathological examination (HPE). This is the treatment of choice for CIN 2&3 of any age and parity.

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: Which of the following is a risk factor for endometrial carcinoma?
questions.solution:
HRT, DM, Hypertension are among the risk factors for endometrial carcinoma.

Predisposing factors of endometrial carcinoma:

  • Hormone replacement therapy (HRT): Unsupervised and unopposed replacement increases the risk.
  • Chronic non-ovulatory cycles as seen in DUB.
  • Familial Lynch II syndrome ( anorectal, breast and endometrial cancer)
  • History of radiation exposure
  • Tamoxifen therapy
  • Obesity
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Polcystic ovarian disease
  • Granulosa cell tumour of ovary

questions.text: Which of the following is not considered a type of headache under trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia?
questions.solution:
Trigeminal neuralgia is not included under Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias.

The headaches classified under Trigeminal autonomic cephalalgias(TAC) include :

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicrania
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks
  • Hemicrania continua
  • Probable trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia

TACs need to be differentiated from short-lasting headaches that do not have prominent cranial autonomic syndromes, like trigeminal neuralgia, hypnic headaches, and primary stabbing headaches.

questions.text: A 56-year-old woman coming from a hilly area presents a hard swelling in the neck which moves up with deglutition. The biopsy on the frozen section is given below. All of the following are true about this carcinoma, except that _____.

choices.text: It is associated with RAS mutation.
It usually presents as solitary nodule.
It can be diagnosed by FNAC.

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a patient from a hilly area (iodine-deficient) and the biopsy specimen showing capsular invasion by tumor follicles confirms the diagnosis of follicular carcinoma. Follicular carcinoma cannot be diagnosed by FNAC.

FNAC cannot distinguish between follicular adenoma and follicular carcinoma. Capsular invasion must be present to diagnose follicular carcinoma, which can be seen only on biopsy.

Related Pearl: Follicular thyroid malignancy

It is more common in iodine-deficient areas. It is associated with p53, PTEN, PAX/PPAR-gamma, RAS, miRNA (miR-197 and miR-346).

It commonly presents as solitary thyroid nodules and the mean age of presentation is 50 years. It can also occur in long-standing cases of multinodular goitre.

FNAC is unable to distinguish between benign and malignant follicular lesions as malignancy is defined by capsular and vascular invasion. Hence, Trucut biopsy is required to confirm malignancy.

Histological findings:

  • Encapsulated
  • Uniform microfollicles or sheets of cells devoid of colloid
  • Capsular and vascular invasion indicates malignancy
  • Tumour thrombus within middle thyroid/ jugular veins may be seen at the time of surgery

Vascular (hematogenous) dissemination is common, with metastases to bone, lungs, liver, and elsewhere. The prognosis depends largely on the extent of invasion and stage at presentation.

Serum thyroglobulin levels are used for monitoring tumour recurrence, as they are undetectable after complete treatment.

questions.text: Famciclovir is a prodrug of _____
questions.solution:
Famciclovir is the diacetyl ester prodrug of 6-deoxy penciclovir and lacks intrinsic antiviral activity.

Mechanism of action:

It is a acyclic guanine nucleoside analogue and is an inhibitor of viral DNA synthesis. In HSV- or VZV-infected cells, penciclovir is phosphorylated initially by viral kinases. Penciclovir triphosphate is a competitive inhibitor of viral DNA polymerase.

Pharmacokinetics:

Oral penciclovir has low (<5%) bioavailability. In contrast, famciclovir is well absorbed orally (bioavailability ~75%).

Adverse effects:

  • Headache, diarrhea, and nausea
  • Urticaria, rash, and hallucinations or confusional states (predominantly in the elderly)

Uses:

  • Herpes labialis
  • Genital herpes
  • Herpes zoster
  • In immunocompetent persons with recurrent orolabial herpes

questions.text: A patient aged 63 years, is diagnosed to have severe aplastic anemia. HLA compatible sibling is available. The best option of treatment is:

choices.text: A conventional bone marrow transplantation from the HLA identical sibling
A non- myelo ablative bone marrow transplantation from the HLA identical sibling

questions.solution:
Treatment for elderly patients with severe aplastic anemia is immunosuppression with anti-thymocyte globulin plus cyclosporine.

Treatment of severe aplastic anemia:

Young adults (<40 years) who have HLA matched siblings- Allogenic Bone marrow Transplantation; Adults (>40 years) / without HLA matched sibling -  Anti thymocyte globulin plus cyclosporine

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with dyspnea and cough. Chest X-ray revealed irregular linear densities, particularly in both lower lobes. Histopathological examination of lung biopsy is shown below. This patient has a higher risk of developing:
questions.solution:
The image shows golden-brown, beaded rods with a translucent center called asbestos bodies which are seen in asbestosis. These patients are at risk of developing both lung carcinoma and mesothelioma.

Asbestosis is marked by diffuse pulmonary interstitial fibrosis and the presence of multiple asbestos bodies.

Option A: Centrilobular emphysema may develop in simple coal workers' pneumoconiosis. 

Option B: Increased susceptibility to tuberculosis is seen in silicosis. 

Option C: Occupational asthma may be triggered by fumes (epoxy resins, plastics), organic and chemical dust (wood, cotton, platinum), gases (toluene), or other chemicals (formaldehyde, penicillin products).

questions.text: Identify the following deformity seen in a patient complaining of pain and swelling of her hands.
questions.solution:
The image is showing flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint is suggestive of Boutonnière deformity seen in patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

Heberden’s and Bouchard’s nodes are nodules in osteoarthritis that are palpable in the distal interphalangeal joint and proximal interphalangeal joints respectively. 

Related Pearl: Deformities in rheumatoid arthritis

Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint. 

 

Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the DIP joint.

 

Z line deformity: Radial deviation of the wrist with ulnar deviation of digits. 

Eversion at hindfoot (subtalar joint), hallux valgus (shown below), hammertoe.

Windswept deformities of toes - Valgus deformities of toes in one foot and varus in the other foot. 

Piano-key movement of the ulnar styloid. 

Trigger finger due to flexor tendon synovitis.

questions.text: Womb stone appearance is seen in which type of degeneration
questions.solution: Calcific degeneration of a fibroid involves deposition of calcium carbonate and phosphate within the tumor. When whole of the tumor is converted into a calcified mass, it is called womb stone.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters are used in the staging of chronic kidney disease?
questions.solution:
Stages of chronic kidney disease (CKD) are stratified by estimated GFR (eGFR) and degree of albuminuria in order to predict the risk of progression of CKD. Serum creatinine is not directly used in the staging of chronic kidney disease.

Stages of Chronic Kidney Disease based on GFR
Stage

GFR

(ml/min/1.73sq.mt)

 Description
1 ≥90 Normal or increased GFR with other evidence of Kidney Damage
2 60-89 Slight decrease in GFR, with other evidence of kidney damage
3A 45-59 Moderate decrease in GFR with or without other evidence of Kidney Damage
3B 30-44
4 15-29 Severe decrease in GFR, with or without other evidence of kidney damage
5 <15 Established renal failure, also known as End-Stage Renal Disease

questions.text: All are true regarding measles vaccine except_________
questions.solution: Measles vaccine has a sub-cutaneous (and not intramuscular) dose of 0.5ml. The first dose is given at 9 months and second dose at 16- 24 months.

questions.text: The characteristic inclusion in the cytoplasm of the cell seen below contains:
questions.solution:
The image shows a Mott Cell containing multiple immunoglobulin globules in grapelike cytoplasmic droplets. Mott Cells may be seen in African trypanosomiasis and in multiple myeloma.

Other options:

Option A: Viral inclusions containing replication proteins and virions may be seen in the case of HSV-infected cells. Intranuclear inclusions called Cowdry Type A bodies as shown below are seen. These bodies push the host cell chromatin to the edge of the nucleus.

Option D: Apoptotic cells break up into fragments called apoptotic bodies. These apoptotic bodies have intact plasma membranes but altered structures. Councilman bodies are a type of apoptotic body. They are acidophilic (eosinophilic) globule of cells that represents a dying hepatocyte often surrounded by normal parenchyma.

Related Pearl: Pathological Named Bodies

Bodies Found in
Asteroid bodies Sarcoidosis, Sporotrichosis

Halberstaedter–Prowazek bodies

 Trachoma 
Miyagawa bodies Lymphogranuloma venereum 
Levinthal–Cole–Lillie bodies Psittacosis
Leishman–Donovan bodies Kala-azar 
Negri bodies Rabies
Guarnieri bodies Vaccinia
Bollinger bodies Fowl pox
Henderson–Paterson bodies Molluscum contagiosum 
Cowdry type-A bodies Yellow fever, Herpes virus infection 
Cowdry type-B bodies Adenovirus, poliovirus
Rusell bodies Multiple myeloma 
Aschoff bodies Rheumatic fever 
Call–Exner bodies Granulosa cell tumor of the ovary 
Civatte (colloid) bodies Lichen planus 
Michaelis–Gutmann bodies Malakoplakia 
Lewy bodies Parkinson's disease 
Pappenheimer bodies Non-heme iron pigments in siderocytes 
Howell–Jolly bodies Splenectomy, Megaloblastic Anemia, Hemolytic anemia 
Heinz bodies G-6-PD deficiency 
Gamna–Gandy bodies Congestive splenomegaly 
Mallory bodies Hyaline inclusions in hepatocytes seen in alcoholic cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis
Councilman bodies Hepatocytes undergoing apoptosis, seen mainly in acute viral hepatitis.
Psammoma bodies Dystrophic calcification in meningioma, papillary serous cystadenoma of ovary & papillary carcinoma of thyroid, papillary type of renal cell carcinoma.
Donovan bodies Granuloma inguinale 
Nissl's bodies Cytoplasmic inclusions in neurons 
Mooser bodies Typhus fever
Creola bodies Asthma 
Verocay bodies Schwannoma 
Schiller–Duval bodies Endodermal sinus tumor 

Hirano bodies

  Alzheimer’s disease

Ferruginous bodies

 Asbestosis 

Related Pearl: Pathological Cells/Bodies in Multiple Myeloma

  • Dutcher bodies - pale-staining, PAS-positive intranuclear inclusions within plasma cells containing Ig, which are more common in IgA myeloma (Image below). 

Russell bodies - They are globular intracellular accumulations of immunoglobulins (Ig). Russell bodies are distended endoplasmic reticulum. Plasma cells filled with multiple Russell bodies are called Mott cells.

  • Flame cells - Plasma cells with fiery red cytoplasm due to vermillion-staining, glycogen-rich IgA in cytoplasmic projections

questions.text: All of the following structures arise from Wolffian duct except:

choices.text: Proximal part of prostatic urethra in males
Posterior wall of urethra in females

questions.solution:
Prostatic utricle in males arises from paramesonephric duct (or mullerian duct) and not from Wolffian duct.

In males, under the influence of the anti-Mullerian hormone (AMH) produced by the Sertoli cells, the paramesonephric ducts degenerate and only two structures are derived from it:

  • appendix of the testis 
  • prostatic utricle 

Structures arising from mesonephric/Wolffian duct are:

Males Females
Ureteric bud and its derivatives Ureteric bud and its derivatives
Trigone of bladder Trigone of bladder
The proximal part of the prostatic urethra The posterior wall of the urethra
Spermatic pathway Gartner's duct
Appendix of epididymis  

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Mesonephric (Wolffian) duct and Paramesonephric (Mullerian) duct

Structures arising from mesonephric/Wolffian duct

Males Females
Ureteric bud and its derivatives Ureteric bud and its derivatives
Trigone of bladder Trigone of bladder
The proximal part of the prostatic urethra The posterior wall of the urethra
Spermatic pathway Gartner's duct
Appendix of epididymis  

Structures arising from the paramesonephric/Mullerian duct

Males Females
Appendix of testis Fallopian tube
Prostatic utricle Uterus
  Cervix
  Upper vaginal wall

questions.text: A patient develops holosystolic murmur 4 days after an anterior wall myocardial infarction. It is most likely due to
questions.solution:
Apical septal rupture is the most likely cause of a holosystolic murmur that develops 4 days after an anterior wall myocardial infarction (MI).

Mechanical complications that occur 3-5 days following an MI include:

  • Papillary muscle rupture
  • Interventricular septal rupture

Papillary muscle rupture causes holosystolic murmur due to flail leaflet and mitral regurgitation. This most often occurs on the first day, with a second peak several days later.

Interventricular septal rupture causes holosystolic murmur due to Left to right shunt. It is associated with a step up in oxygen saturation from Right atrium to right ventricle.

The artery supplying the anterior wall is the left anterior descending (LAD) branch of the Left coronary artery.  It also supplies the apical septum and anterolateral papillary muscle.

Arterial trunk Frequency of involvement Region of myocardium affected
LAD 40-50%

Anterior wall of left ventricle near the apex

Anterior portion of ventricular septum

Apex circumferentially
RCA 30-40%

Inferior/posterior wall of left ventricle

Posterior portion of the ventricular septum

Inferior/posterior right ventricular free wall (in some cases)
LCX 15-20% Lateral wall of left ventricle except at the apex

Note:

  • Anterolateral papillary muscle – LAD & LCX
  • Posteromedial papillary muscle - RCA

Apical septal rupture is the best answer since the anterolateral papillary muscle receives dual blood supply from left circumflex (LCX) branch as well as LAD and is not prone to rupture.

The posteromedial papillary muscle and basal septum are supplied by the right coronary artery. The posteromedial papillary muscle rupture is the more likely to develop ischemia and rupture due to its single blood supply.

questions.text: A patient comes with complaints of frequent episodes of gingival bleeding along with numerous petechiae on the leg. The platelet count is 50,000/microliter and the peripheral smear shows large platelets with normal morphology. Other laboratory investigations are normal. Which of the following statements is false about this condition?

choices.text: It is an autoimmune mediated condition
Antibodies are directed against platelet factor 4
There are increased number of megakaryocytes in bone marrow
The treatment is by administering I.V. immunoglobin

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP). The false statement is that the antibodies are directed against platelet factor 4. Antibodies against platelet factor 4 are seen in heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT).

ITP is an autoimmune disorder caused by antiplatelet antibodies that destroy platelets. The antibodies are directed against platelet membrane glycoproteins IIb-IIIa or Ib-IX. It is a diagnosis of exclusion. It can be primary (idiopathic) or secondary, associated with SLE, Hepatitis C, and HIV.

Acute ITP is usually seen in children, while chronic ITP occurs commonly in adults. Clinically, the patient may present with a history of easy bruising, gingival bleeding, petechiae, and ecchymoses. 

Investigations show isolated thrombocytopenia. Peripheral smear may show large platelets with normal morphology and bone marrow shows an increase in megakaryocytes (non-specific findings of thrombopoiesis). 

Initial treatment includes administering steroids and IVIg (intravenous immunoglobulin). TPO (thrombopoietin) receptor agonists, romiplostim and eltrombopag, are effective in increasing platelet counts in patients not responding to traditional treatment. Spleen is a major site for the removal of opsonized (targeted) platelets, and so, splenectomy remains a treatment option in severe thrombocytopenia and refractory cases.

Note- Heparin-induced thrombocytopenia is an autoimmune condition, seen after the administration of heparin. It is more common with unfractionated heparin compared to low molecular weight heparins. This condition is not associated with bleeding. On the contrary, it is associated with thrombosis.

Related Pearl: Idiopathic/Immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

It is characterized by

  • Isolated thrombocytopenia—the presence of antibody against platelet membrane glycoprotein and subsequent destruction in reticuloendothelial system
  • Normal bone marrow—normal or even increased number of megakaryocytes
  • Absence of other causes of thrombocytopenia. 

Types:

Acute (<6 months) and chronic (>6 months) idiopathic/immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP)

Features

Acute ITP

Chronic ITP

Peak incidence

2–6 years

20–40 years

Sex predilection

None

female: male ratio of 3:1 

Antecedent infection

Common 1 to 3 weeks before

Unusual

Onset of bleeding

Abrupt

Insidious

Platelet count

<20000/microlitre

30–80000/microlitre

Eosinophilia/lymphocytosis

Common

Rare

Duration

2–6 weeks

Months or years

Spontaneous remission

80% of cases

Uncommon

Related Pearl: Causes of Thrombocytopenia

I. Decreased Production of Platelets

  1. Selective impairment of platelet production
    • Drug-induced: alcohol, thiazides, cytotoxic drugs
    • Infections: measles, human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)
  2. Nutritional deficiencies - B12, folate deficiency
  3. Bone marrow failure - aplastic anemia
  4. Bone marrow replacement - leukemia, disseminated cancer, granulomatous disease
  5. Ineffective hematopoiesis - myelodysplastic syndromes 

II. Decreased Platelet Survival

  1. Immunologic destruction
    • Primary autoimmune - chronic immune thrombocytopenic purpura, acute immune thrombocytopenic purpura
    • Secondary autoimmune - systemic lupus erythematosus, B-cell lymphoid neoplasms
    • Alloimmune - posttransfusion and neonatal
    • Drug-associated - quinidine, heparin, sulfa compounds
    • Infections - HIV, infectious mononucleosis (transient, mild), dengue fever
  2. Nonimmunologic destruction
    • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
    • Thrombotic microangiopathies
    • Giant hemangiomas

III. Sequestration - The spleen normally sequesters 30% to 35% of platelets. This can rise to 80% to 90% when the spleen is enlarged, producing moderate degrees of thrombocytopenia.

IV. Dilution - Transfusions

questions.text: A 20 year old primi with history of 3 months of  amenorrhoea came for routine antenatal check up. The USG done is suggestive of which fetal anomaly-
questions.solution:
The USG shows characteristic triangular facial appearance and shower cap sign pointing towards acrania.

Acrania - the absence of the cranium, with protrusion of a disorganized mass of brain tissue.

This anomaly is more prevalent in first birth and about 70% of fetuses are females.

questions.text: Children display pseudoparalysis of Parrot in which infectious disease?
questions.solution:
Pseudoparalysis of Parrot is a clinical sign in children with congenital syphilis.

Bone involvement in congenital syphilis leads to pain due to osteochondritis, which results in children refusing to move the affected limb. This is phenomenon is named pseudoparalysis of Parrot. Other features of congenital syphilis include thrombocytopenia, persistent rhinitis, and vasculitis.

Some manifestations of late-stage congenital syphilis are summarized in the table below.

SYMPTOMS/SIGNS DESCRIPTION/COMMENTS
Olympian brow The bony prominence of the forehead caused by persistent or recurrent periostitis
Clavicular or Higoumenakis sign Unilateral or bilateral thickening of the sternoclavicular portion of the clavicle
Saber shins Anterior bowing of the midportion of the tibia
Scaphoid scapula Convexity along the medial border of the scapula
Hutchinson Teeth Peg-shaped notches under central incisors. They erupt during 6th yr of life with abnormal enamel, resulting in a notch along the biting surface
Mulberry molars Abnormal 1st lower (6yr) molars characterized by small biting surface and excessive number of cusps
Saddle nose Depression of the nasal root, a result of syphilitic rhinitis destroying adjacent bone or cartilage
Rhagades Linear scars that extended in a spoke-like pattern from previous mucocutaneous fissures of the mouth, anus, and genitalia
Juvenile paresis Latent meningovascular infection; it is rare and typically occurs during adolescence with behavioral changes, focal seizures, or loss of intellectual function
Juvenile tabes Rare spinal cord involvement and cardiovascular involvement with aortitis
Hutchinson triad Hutchinson teeth, interstitial keratitis, and 8th nerve deafness
Clutton joint Unilateral or bilateral painless joint swelling (usually involving knees) from synovitis with sterile synovial fluid; spontaneous remission usually occurs after several weeks
Interstitial keratitis Manifests with intense photophobia and lacrimation, followed within weeks or months by corneal opacification and complete blindness
8th nerve deafness Maybe unilateral or bilateral. Appears at any age, manifests initially as vertigo and high-tone hearing loss, and progress to permanent deafness
A perforated nasal septum may be an associated abnormality.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to OPD with complaints of pain over the forearm. On detailed examination, several wounds with cigarettes burns are found. X-ray showed a spiral fracture of the radius. Which of the following is least likely seen in this condition?

choices.text: Multiple injuries at same stage of healing

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of battered baby syndrome. The classical feature of this condition is injuries inflicted are of different ages and in different stages of healing. This is due to the repetitive nature of child abuse.

A battered child is one who has received repetitive physical injuries as a result of non-accidental violence, produced by a parent or guardian, there may also be deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection.

This syndrome must be considered in any child:

  • In whom the degree and type of injury varies with the history given
  • When injuries are of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • When there is a purposeful delay in seeking medical attention despite serious injury
  • Who exhibits evidence of fracture of any bone, subdural hematoma, failure to thrive, soft tissue swelling or skin bruising
  • Who dies suddenly

Skeletal survey, which includes the following, should be done in a case of suspected child abuse:

  • AP views of the entire skeleton
  • Dedicated views of hands and feet
  • Lateral views of appendicular skeleton, skull, and spine

questions.text: A patient has a history of a road traffic accident 2 years back, and has developed pain and swelling now at the same site. His X-ray image is shown in the image given below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a history of an accident 2 years ago, experiencing symptoms of pain and swelling at the site of injury, and an X-ray of the lower limb revealing sequestrum and involucrum in the tibia, strongly suggests a diagnosis of chronic osteomyelitis.

Chronic osteomyelitis may occur by direct inoculation of the infective organism during trauma (like road traffic accidents). The infection continues to thrive within the bone leading to alternating quiescent and flare-up stages of chronic osteomyelitis.

Sequestrum is a piece of dead bone. It is formed when a fragment of bone gets separated from the healthy bone due to necrosis. It varies in size from a spicule to a large fragment and acts as a nidus for infection. It leads to abscess and persistent pus discharge in the bone. Sinus tracts are formed when the abscess from the infected bone drains out through the skin. 

The involucrum is the dense new sclerotic bone surrounding the sequestrum. It is formed from deep layers of stripped periosteum. Cloacae are the perforations in the involucrum. Pus and tiny spicules of bone may be discharged through them.

The radiograph below shows sequestrum, involucrum and cloacae: 

Option A: Osteogenic sarcoma characteristically shows the sun-burst appearance and Codman's triangle, as shown below.

 

Option B: Ewing's sarcoma shows an onion-skin appearance of the periosteum, as shown below.

Option D: Multiple myeloma shows multiple punched-out lesions of the bone, as shown below.

questions.text: Learned behavior which is socially acquired is known as?
questions.solution:
Culture:

  • Is the learned behavior which is socially acquired.

Other options:

Option A  - Custom:

  • The established patterns of behavior that can be objectively verified within a particular social setting.

Option B - Acculturation: Is ‘cultural contact’ or mixing of two cultures. It can occur through:

  • Trade and commerce
  • Industrialization
  • Propagation of religion
  • Education
  • Conquest

Option C  - Standard of Living:

  • Refers to the usual scale of our expenditure, goods we consume and the services we enjoy.
  • Standard of living (WHO) includes: 
    • Income and Occupation
    • Standards of housing, sanitation, and nutrition
    • Level of provision of health, educational, recreational and other services

Folkways:

  • Right ways of doing things in less vital areas of human conduct.
  • Mores are stringent customs.

questions.text: Monoclonal antibodies acting as enzymes are called _____
questions.solution:
Monoclonal antibodies acting as enzymes are called abzyme.

Abzyme:

These are monoclonal antibodies with catalytic activity. Natural abzymes with proteolytic activity are called proteabzymes. And those with DNA hydrolyzing activity are called DNA abzymes.

Granzyme:

Serine proteases that are released by granules within cytotoxic T cells and NK cells. They induce apoptosis in the target cells which may have become cancerous or become infected.

Lipozyme:

It is an hydrolase enzyme that catalyses the reaction between triacylglycerol and water to form diacylglycerol and a fatty acid anion. It is produced in the tongue and pancreas to help in digestion of dietary fats.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has hydrogen peroxide been recently approved for?
questions.solution:
A topical solution of hydrogen peroxide has been approved for the treatment of raised seborrheic keratoses.

Hydrogen peroxide is a keratolytic agent. Its exact mechanism of action in the treatment of seborrheic keratoses is not fully understood. Supraphysiologic concentrations may cause oxidative damage and death to seborrheic keratosis cells.

Hydrogen peroxide is commonly used as a disinfectant to clean wounds. It can also be used as a mouthwash.

questions.text: Cystathionine synthetase deficiency leads to
questions.solution:
Cystathionine synthetase deficiency leads to Homocystinuria type I

Homocystinuria type-1:

  • It is the most common inborn error of methionine metabolism.
  • It is characterized by developmental delay, ectopia lentis, progressive mental retardation, skeleton abnormalities.

questions.text: Congenital infection in fetus with minimal teratogenic risk is
questions.solution:
Teratogenic effects have not been documented with HIV infection. In Highly Active Antiretroviral therapy(HAART) , Efavirenz is avoided in the first trimester due to its teratogenic risk.

Effects of HIV

  • On mother:

-The course of HIV in mother remians unaltered as a result of pregnancy

-Maternal mortality or morbidity are not increased by HIV

-Main problems associated with HIV infection during pregnancy are related to preterm delivery and IUGR

  • On fetus:

-No teratogenic effects have been reported

-Preterm delivery, IUGR

No teratogenic effect

  • HIV
  • Measles
  • Influenza
  • Mumps

Infections causing congenital malformations (teratogenic effects)

  • Rubella
  • Varicella
  • CMV
  • Toxoplasmosis
  • Parvovirus

questions.text: Hyperacute graft rejection is commonly seen in the transplants of:-
questions.solution:
Hyperacute graft rejection is seen in the kidney.

Hyperacute rejection:-

Hyperacute rejection occurs usually within the first few hours post-transplantation and is mediated by preformed antibodies against ABO or MHC antigens of the graft. Once the antibodies bind to the transplanted tissues, rejection can be caused either

a) by activation of the complement system, which results in the chemotactic attraction of granulocytes and the triggering of inflammatory circuits, or

b) by ADCC

Pathological features of hyperacute rejection are the following:-

  • This is associated with the formation of massive intravascular platelet aggregates leading to thrombosis, ischemia, and necrosis
  • The hyperacute rejection episodes are irreversible and invariably results in graft loss. With proper cross-matching techniques, this type of rejection is almost 100% avoidable.
  • The hyperacute rejection by antibodies to all human cellular antigens is the major limitation of xenogeneic transplantation (e.g., pig to human)

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with the following finding on her finger. She says that she cut her finger while chopping vegetables 2 weeks ago. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and clinical findings are suggestive of exuberant granulation.

It is a deviation in wound healing where excessive amounts of granulation tissue protrude above the level of the surrounding skin and blocks re-epithelialization. It is also known as proud flesh.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with a testicular mass. It is likely to be ______
questions.solution:
A testicular mass in a male > 50 years of age is regarded as a lymphoma until proven otherwise.  

Testicular germ cell tumors occur commonly in the age group of 20-40 years.  

Hydrocoele presents as a cystic scrotal swelling, not as a testicular mass    

Related Pearl: Most common testicular tumors

Pre-pubertal age group Yolk sac tumor
15–34 years Germ-cell tumors
Adults Seminomatous and non-seminomatous
Elderly age group Lymphoma
Germ-cell testicular tumor Seminoma
Bilateral testicular tumor Lymphoma

 

Related Pearl: TNM staging of testicular tumour: American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and Union Internationale Contre le Cancer (UICC)

Primary tumor (T)

The extent of the primary tumor is usually classified after radical orchiectomy (except for pTis and pT4) and, for this reason, a pathologic (p) stage is assigned.

pTx - Primary tumor cannot be assessed

pT0 - No evidence of primary tumor (e.g., a histologic scar in testis)

pTis -  Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

pT1 - Tumor limited to the testis and epididymis without vascular/lymphatic invasion; tumor may invade into tunica albuginea but not tunica vaginalis

pT2 - Tumor limited to testis and epididymis with vascular/lymphatic invasion or tumor extending through the tunica albuginea, with the involvement of tunica vaginalis

pT3 - Tumor invades spermatic cord with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

pT4 - Tumor invades the scrotum with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

Regional lymph nodes (N)

NX - Regional lymph nodes cannot be assessed

N0 - No regional lymph node metastasis

N1 - Metastasis with lymph node mass ≤2 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, none more than 2 cm in greatest dimension

N2 - Metastasis with lymph node mass, 2–5 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, anyone mass >2 cm but not more than 5 cm in greatest dimension

N3 - Metastasis with lymph node mass >5 cm in greatest dimension

Distant metastasis (M)

MX - Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0 - No distant metastasis

M1 - Distant metastasis

M1a - Nonregional nodal or pulmonary metastasis

M1b - Distant metastasis at site other than nonregional lymph nodes or lung

Serum tumor markers (S)

SX - Marker studies unavailable or not performed

S0 - Marker study levels within normal limits

hCG(MIU/mL) <5000 5000–50,000  >50,000

questions.text: Pneumotaxic centre is located in _____
questions.solution:
It is located dorsally in the superior portion of the pons, which mainly controls rate and depth of breathing.

The function of the pneumotaxic center is primarily to limit inspiration, which in turn increases the rate of breathing. This is because limiting of inspiration also shortens expiration and the entire period of each respiration.
