questions.text: A 26-year-old athlete comes for a routine examination. He has no symptoms. The ECG is as shown below. Which of the following should be done?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows sinus bradycardia with a heart rate of 45 bpm. The patient is an athlete and heart rates are usually lower in athletes.

As the patient is asymptomatic no further therapy should be given to increase the heart rate.

Sinus bradycardia:

  • Sinus bradycardia is defined as SA nodal rhythm with a rate <60 beats/min. However, in young healthy adults and athletes, a resting heart rate of <60 beats/min is common.
  • Also, a sinus pause of upto 3 seconds on ECG is commonly seen in athletes and elderly individuals.
  • If the rate is <40 beats/min, in an awake individual in the absence of physical training, then it is considered abnormal.

Diagnosis of SA node dysfunction:

  • The presence of abnormal sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is insufficient to diagnose SA node dysfunction. Longer-term electrocardiographic recording and clinical correlation are required to establish the diagnosis.
  • On the contrary, the presence of symptoms without any sinus bradycardia or sinus pause on ECG is sufficient to rule out SA node dysfunction.

questions.text: The reagent used to distinguish staphylococci from streptococci is
questions.solution:
• The staphylococci are aerobic while the streptococci are aerotolerant anaerobes.
  • Streptococci ferment even in the presence of high levels of oxygen and lack catalase.
  • A standard quick test involves mixing staphylococci with hydrogen peroxide. The catalase-positive staphylococci convert hydrogen peroxide into water and oxygen. The generation of oxygen bubbles indicates that the gram-positive coccus is a Staphylococcus rather than a Streptococcus.
  • A coagulase test uses the serum to see if fibrinogen is clotted is used to distinguish the coagulase-positive staphylococci from coagulase-negative staphylococci.
  • Oxidase is not the reagent but the reactor in the oxidase test.

questions.text: All of the following nutrients are present in egg except
questions.solution:
Egg contains all nutrients except Carbohydrates and Vitamin C.

A 60 gm egg contains:

  • 6 g Fat
  • 6 g Protein
  • 30 mg Calcium
  • 1.5 mg Iron
  • 70 Kcal Energy

The cholesterol content is 250 mg/ egg. Egg protein has all 9 Amino acids needed for the body in the right proportions and hence it is considered as "Reference Protein".

Net Protein Utilization (NPU) of an egg is 94, meat is 80, milk is 75. Boiled egg is nutritionally superior to raw egg. Boiling destroys avidin, a substance that prevents the body from absorbing Biotin.

questions.text: A 33-year-old man is brought to the emergency department with a history of having swallowed mercury from a thermometer. History is suggestive of intellectual disability since childhood. What is your next step of action?

choices.text: Gastric lavage and activated charcoal administration

questions.solution:
The mercury found in a glass thermometer is elemental mercury. The absorption of elemental mercury by the GI tract is usually negligible, unless the mucosa is damaged. Hence, no treatment is required.

For ingestion of inorganic and organic mercury salts, the following steps are followed:

  • Aggressive IV hydration
  • GI decontamination, including gastric lavage 
  • Activated charcoal

Dimercaprol and succimer are the preferred chelators for mercury poisoning.

questions.text: The following images show:
questions.solution:
The following image shows the Jersey finger and baseball finger.

  • Jersey finger - It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of distal phalanx with the ring finger most commonly involved.
  • Baseball finger: Mallet finger/baseball finger is a disruption to the extensor tendon of the little finger or thumb when the collision with a hard object (a ball) forces it to flex past its normal range of motion.

 

Related Pearl: Important Injuries of the Hand

Gamekeeper's thumb: It is an injury of the thumb leading to avulsion, rupture or damage of the ulnar collateral ligament. It is commonly seen in gamekeepers and following a fall on an outstretched hand.

 
Mallet finger/baseball finger: It is a disruption to the extensor tendon over the DIP joint. It occurs when a collision with a hard object (e.g., a ball) forces it to flex more than its normal range of motion.
 

 

Jersey finger: It is an avulsion injury of the flexor digitorum profundus at the insertion of the base of the distal phalanx. The ring finger most commonly involved.

 

Trigger finger: A nodule on the flexor tendon prevents it from moving along the A1 pulley. This causes the finger to be stuck in a flexed position.

 

Boxer's fracture: It is a break in the neck of the metacarpal. It is caused by striking an object with a closed fist, as seen in boxing. The little finger is the most commonly affected.

questions.text: A 20-year old male came to the hospital with complaints of cough and difficulty in breathing and swelling of the face. On physical examination dilated neck veins were seen. A clinical diagnosis of SVC syndrome was made. Chest X-ray revealed widening of the superior mediastinum. What is the next step?

choices.text: Diuretics with low salt diet, head elevation, oxygen

questions.solution:
The next step in the above case is to obtain a CT scan. SVC syndrome is diagnosed by the absence or reduced opacification of the central veins and the presence of prominent collateral venous circulation.

Superior vena cava syndrome: It is a clinical manifestation due to the obstruction of superior vena cava which results in reduced venous return from head and neck and upper extremities.

Causes:

  1. Intravascular devices such as central venous catheters and pacemaker or defibrillator lead.
  2. Malignant tumors:
  • Lung cancer (MC: small-cell and squamous cell histologies)
  • Lymphoma (MC cause of SVC syndrome in young adults)

3. Metastatic cancers to mediastinal lymph nodes, from testicular and breast carcinoma

4. Other causes: Benign tumors, aortic aneurysm, thyromegaly, thrombosis, and fibrosing mediastinitis from prior irradiation, histoplasmosis, or Behçet’s syndrome.

Clinical features:

Symptoms:

  • Swelling of neck and face (commonly around the eyes)
  • Cough, dyspnea, dysphagia
  • Nasal congestion, Epistaxis, Hemoptysis
  • Headache, pain, dizziness, syncope, lethargy

Symptoms are aggravated on bending forward or lying down.

Physical findings:

  • Dilated neck veins, increased collateral veins on the anterior chest wall, cyanosis.
  • Edema of face, arms, chest
  • In severe cases, proptosis and edema of tongue and larynx may be seen.
  • Bilateral breast edema (unilateral edema is seen in axillary or subclavian vein obstruction).
  • Esophageal varices may be seen in SVC syndrome caused by hemodialysis catheters. Depending on the position of esophageal varices, the site of SVC obstruction can be evaluated as below:
    • Varices in upper third of esophagus - due to obstruction of SVC proximal to azygous vein
    • Varices in the entire length of esophagus - due to obstruction of SVC distal to azygous vein

Diagnosis:

  • SVC syndrome is usually diagnosed clinically.
  • Chest X-ray shows the widening of the superior mediastinum.
  • A CT scan is done for a detailed study of the mediastinal anatomy. SVC syndrome is diagnosed by the absence or reduce opacification of the central veins and the presence of prominent collateral venous circulation.
  • Once the CT report is obtained, further management depends on whether the patient has cancer or not.
    • If there is no history of malignancy: Detailed workup is done to rule out benign causes
    • If the patient has a known malignancy: Proceed to treatment

Treatment:

  • Management includes relieving tracheal obstruction if present and reduction of the swelling.
  • Diuretics with low-salt diet, head elevation and oxygen provide symptomatic relief.
  • Radiotherapy is provided for non-small-cell lung cancer, other metastatic solid tumors.
  • Chemotherapy is provided for small-cell carcinoma of the lung, lymphoma, or germ cell tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following receptors is not found in hairy skin?
questions.solution:
Merkel cells (Merkel-Ranvier cells) are found on glabrous (free from hair) skin and are highly specialized to respond to sustained pressure and touch.

They are slowly adapting receptors.

The remaining receptors are found in hairy skin.

Clinical significance: Merkel cells may become malignant and form a Merkel cell carcinoma, which is an aggressive and hard to treat cancer.

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

questions.text:
In Pemphigus Vulgaris, which of the following is true?
1: Anti desmoglein(anti-Dsg ) 1 antibodies predominate
2: There is marked blistering of the mucosa, with relative sparing of skin

choices.text: Both are correct and 1 is the reason for 2
Both are correct, but 1 is independent of 2

questions.solution:
In Pemphigus vulgaris, there is marked blistering of mucosa with relative sparing of skin.

In pemphigus vulgaris, Anti-Dsg 3 antibodies predominate. As, Dsg 3 is present in all the layers of mucosa, but is found only in the basal and immediate suprabasal layers of skin; the oral epithelium is primarily affected with relative sparing of skin remaining.

In the case of Pemphigus foliaceus, Anti- Dsg 1 antibodies predominate. Hence skin is primarily affected with sparing of oral mucosa.

questions.text: Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal joint of thumb after supracondylar fracture is due to the involvement of?
questions.solution:
Loss of flexion at the interphalangeal (IP) joint of the thumb, is due to the involvement of the anterior interosseous nerve (AIN).

Flexion of thumb occurs at 2 joints:

  1. IP joint: Flexor pollicis longus (FPL) supplied by the anterior interosseous nerve (a branch of the median nerve, C7 and C8). 
  2. MCP joint: Flexor pollicis brevis (FPB) supplied by the recurrent motor branch of the median nerve.

Other options:

  • Deep branch of ulnar nerve > ulnar claw hand

questions.text: A patient who got into an accident is brought to the casualty and is bleeding from his right leg. His blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg. Which of the following plays the most important role for sodium and water retention in this patient?
questions.solution:
The renin-angiotensin system plays the most important role for sodium and water retention in this patient as the patient has hypovolemia due to blood loss. (refer to figure)

The plasma concentration of renin is the rate-limiting step in the renin-angiotensin system; it is the major determinant of plasma angiotensin II concentration.

Angiotensin II stimulates the aldosterone and ADH secretion; it also constricts the blood vessels and causes thirst, which helps in maintaining blood pressure.

questions.text: Anticoagulant of choice for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia
questions.solution:
Lepirudin is the anticoagulant of choice for heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

In Heparin-Induced Thrombocytopenia (HIT), there is the formation of IgG antibodies against heparin platelet factor 4 complexes which activates them, resulting in a prothrombotic state even in the presence of thrombocytopenia.

HIT usually occurs 5-10 days after exposure to heparins.

Management of HIT:

  • Stop all forms of heparin, LMW Heparin
  • Direct thrombin inhibitors (Lepirudin, Argatroban) are anticoagulants of choice
  • Lepirudin is safe in Liver failure, Argatroban is safe in Renal failure
  • Lepirudin is continued till platelet count is 100000/microLitre
  • Warfarin is started and direct thrombin inhibitors are discontinued

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Insulin-like growth factor-1(IGF-1)?

choices.text: It is synthesized in the liver
It has a major role in fetal development
It is also synthesized by bone
It’s secretion is regulated by growth hormone levels

questions.solution:
IGF -2 has a major role in growth during fetal development, while IGF-1 plays a major role in skeletal and cartilage growth.

Insulin-like growth factors (IGF) are the polypeptide growth factors that are similar to insulin in their structures. They are also called somatomedins. IGFs that are found in human beings are IGF-1 and IGF-2.

IGF -1 is also called somatomedin C. It is synthesized by the liver and other peripheral tissues like bone. Secretion is independent of growth hormone before birth, however, after birth, the growth hormone stimulates the secretion of IGF-1. The major physiological role of IGF-1 is to stimulate skeletal and cartilage growth. Its plasma concentration rises during childhood, peaks during puberty, and declines during old age.

IGF-2 secretion is independent of the growth hormone levels. It has a major role in the growth of fetus before birth.

questions.text: All are risk factors for acute pancreatitis except:
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia and not hypocalcemia predispose to acute pancreatitis and the mechanism most likely involves hypersecretion and the formation of calcified stones intra-ductally.

The most common cause of Acute pancreatitis is Gall stones followed by alcohol.

Other causes are:

  • Post-ERCP
  • Abdominal trauma
  • Following biliary, upper gastrointestinal or cardiothoracic surgery
  • Ampullary tumor
  • Drugs (corticosteroids, azathioprine, asparginase, valproic acid, thiazides, oestrogens)
  • Hyperparathyroidism
  • Hypercalcaemia
  • Pancreas divisum

questions.text: Osborn J waves are not seen in :
questions.solution:
Osborn J waves are not seen in hyperkalemia.

Osborn J waves are the distinctive convex elevations of the J point as seen in the image.

It consists of an extra deflection on the ECG at the terminal junction of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST-segment takeoff.

  • Usually, it occurs when the core body temperature falls below 90°F (32°C), seen in conditions such as hypothermia (option A) secondary to severe hypothyroidism (option B)
  • Results from an exaggerated outward potassium current leading to repolarization abnormality
  • They can also be found in other conditions, such as hypercalcemia (option C)
  • Other causes include brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation, vasospastic angina, and idiopathic ventricular fibrillation

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

questions.text: Arias stella reaction is not seen in ________
questions.solution:
Arias stella reaction is not seen in salpingitis isthmica nodosa.

Arias-Stella reaction is seen in:

  • Uterine and ectopic pregnancy
  • Endometriosis
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)

Arias Stella reaction:

  • There is presence of typical adenomatous change of endometrial glands
  • There is intra luminal budding
  • Cell changes include loss of polarity of cells, pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, vacuolated cytoplasm and occasional mitosis.
  • This is due to the influence of progesterone.

questions.text: All of the following are type IV hypersensitivity reactions except:
questions.solution:
Polyarteritis nodosa is a type III hypersensitivity reaction, not type IV.

Type IV hypersensitivity reactions (delayed hypersensitivity reactions): These reactions are induced by sensitized T cells which on contact with the specific antigen, release cytokines that produce biological effects on leucocytes, macrophages, and tissue cells.

Examples of type IV hypersensitivity reactions include sarcoidosis, leprosy, type I lepra reaction, tuberculosis, psoriasis, inflammatory bowel disease, multiple sclerosis, and type 1 diabetes mellitus, contact dermatitis.

Type III hypersensitivity reactions: These reactions are induced by immune complexes which deposit in tissues or blood vessels, and elicit an acute inflammatory reaction by activating the complement system. The inflammatory reaction causes tissue injury.

Other examples of type III hypersensitivity reactions include systemic lupus erythematosus, serum sickness, arthus reaction, post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, rheumatoid arthritis, and type II lepra reaction.

Related Pearl: Examples of Type IV Hypersensitivity

Type IV Hypersensitivity Reactions 

  • Tuberculin reaction
  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Chronic graft rejection
  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is a contraindication for endoscopic sinus surgery?
questions.solution:
Acute rhinosinusitis with epidural abscess is a contraindication for functional endoscopic sinus surgery.

The endoscopic approach is contraindicated in the presence of an intracranial complication of acute infection such as:

  • Meningitis
  • Subperiosteal abscess
  • Epidural abscess
  • Cavernous sinus thrombosis
  • Any visual loss 

Note: Endoscopic sinus surgery is indicated in chronic bacterial rhinosinusitis, allergic fungal sinusitis with mycetoma and repair of cerebrospinal fluid leak.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in rheumatoid arthritis?
questions.solution:
Febuxostat is not used in rheumatoid arthritis. It is used in the treatment of gout.

 

Related Pearl: Important drugs for rheumatoid arthritis

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text: Which of the following are correctly matched?
questions.solution:
• Asteatotic dermatitis is also called Winter eczema.
  • Cradle cap and Dandruff are types of seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Bindi dermatitis is a type of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • Halo dermatitis is the occurrence of an eczematous ring surrounding a melanocytic nevus. It is also called Meyerson nevus or Meyerson phenomenon.
  • Vesicular dermatitis or Pompholyx is a form of eczema of the palms and soles in which edema fluid accumulates to form visible vesicles or bullae.

Dermatitis or Eczema is a reaction pattern caused by inflammation of the epidermis that typically manifests as scaling or crusting of the skin.

It is classified based on the etiology into Exogenous and Endogenous eczemas.

Condition Examples/ Synonyms Description
Exogenous eczemas: external factors predispose to eczema    
Allergic contact dermatitis Nickel dermatitis, Bindi dermatitis Delayed type of hypersensitivity reaction to a previously sensitized allergen
Irritant contact dermatitis Wear and tear dermatitis, Housewives eczema Cutaneous response to the physical/toxic effects of a range of environmental exposures.
Endogenous eczemas: Internal constitutional factors predispose to eczema      
Asteatotic dermatitis Winter eczema/Eczéma craquelé ‘Crazy paving’ pattern on legs due to dry skin, flares in winter
Atopic dermatitis Eczema infantum, eczema flexurarum, Hay fever eczema, asthmatic eczema Itchy, chronic relapsing condition that often starts in early childhood (<2 years) with erythema, papules/ papulovesicles, excoriation and lichenification in flexural distribution
Nummular dermatitis  Discoid eczema Circular or oval plaques of eczema with a clearly demarcated edge
Seborrheic dermatitis
  • Dandruff/ Sebo-psoriasis/ Pityriasis capitis/ Pityrosporal dermatitis
  • Cradle cap 
 Erythematous patches with superficial scaling, affecting areas with a high density of sebaceous glands- scalp, face, central chest, and anogenital areas

Cradle cap – seborrheic dermatitis

Bindi dermatitis- allergic contact dermatitis

Vesicular dermatitis - Pompholyx

questions.text: A 27-year-old female patient on oral contraceptive pills presents with complaints of abdominal pain for the past few days. She is evaluated further. Which of the following tumor is most likely to occur in this patient?
questions.solution:
The female patient with oral contraceptive pills (OCPs) usage and with complaints of abdominal pain is most likely to be associated with hepatic adenoma. It is the most frequent hepatic tumor in young women on oral contraceptive pills.

Hepatic adenoma

These are benign liver tumors seen in women aged 25 and 50 years. The lesions are solitary, well-defined, and vascular. They are found incidentally but can present in some cases with pain due to rupture or bleeding. They have malignant potential. Large hepatic adenomas are at an increased risk of rupture and intraperitoneal hemorrhage. Surgical excision is recommended if lesions are >5 cm.

Other options:

Option A: Hepatocellular carcinoma is one of the primary liver malignancies. Chronic hepatitis B infection and hepatitis C are considered risk factors. The cause of death in 60 percent of cases is related to cancer while the rest is due to an underlying pathology. Surgical resection is considered a treatment in patients with preserved liver function.

Option B: Focular nodular hyperplasia is a benign condition with an unknown etiology. It is usually seen in middle-aged women. It doesn't have any malignant potential and therefore there is no need for treatment or follow-up after confirming the diagnosis.

Option D: Hemangiomas are the most common liver lesions and they can rupture. Diagnosis is incidental and surgical resection is needed if the patient is significantly symptomatic or there is uncertainty in diagnosis.

Hepatic adenoma on CT scan is shown below.

 

Hepatocellular carcinoma on CT scan is shown below:

 

Liver hemangioma on CT scan is shown below:

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: The drug most useful in a patient with hepatic encephalopathy is:
questions.solution:
Lactulose is used to treat hepatic encephalopathy.

  • Lactulose is a laxative that acts by getting converted to short chain fatty acid in the colon.
  • These fatty acids result in decrease in pH of intestinal juice.
  • At this low pH, ammonia becomes ionized and thus cannot be absorbed.

questions.text: A teenager presents with fever, malaise, skin rash and hepatomegaly. He is diagnosed with a rickettsial infection and the vector implicated in the disease is shown below. The vector can transmit all of the following diseases except:
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a louse. It can transmit all diseases except endemic typhus. The vector for endemic typhus is rat flea. 

The table below shows diseases transmitted by the louse, and the causative agent:

Disease transmitted by louse   Causative agent
Epidemic typhus Rickettssia prowazeki
Relapsing fever Borrelia recurrentis
Trench fever Bartonella quintana
Pediculosis Infestation with the louse

Rickettsial infections are classified based on clinical features and epidemiology as follows:

Group

Zoonotic disease

 Vector
Typhus group  

Epidemic typhus

 Louse

Murine typhus

Flea

Scrub typhus

 Mite
Spotted fever group  

Indian tick typhus

Tick

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 Tick

Rickettsialpox

 Mite
Others 

Q fever 

 -
Trench fever Louse

Rickettsial infections present with fever, malaise, headache, prostration, hepatosplenomegaly and a skin rash. Q fever does not have skin lesions. Tetracycline is the drug of choice for all rickettsial infections. 

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: The appearance of fibers in the histological image below is commonly seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Rosenthal fibers, which are commonly associated with pilocytic astrocytoma.

A Rosenthal fiber is a thick, elongated, worm-like, or "corkscrew" eosinophilic bundle that is found on H&E staining of the brain in the presence of long-standing gliosis, occasional tumors, and some metabolic disorders. It is usually associated with pilocytic astrocytoma (more common) or Alexander's disease (a rare leukodystrophy).

Pilocytic astrocytoma:

  • Pilocytic astrocytoma or juvenile pilocytic astrocytoma or cystic cerebellar astrocytoma is a brain tumor that occurs more often in children and young adults (in the first 20 years of life).
  • These tumors are usually slow-growing and benign. The neoplasms are associated with the formation of a single (or multiple) cyst(s) and can become very large.
  • Diagnosis can be made on the basis of brain MRI findings. Surgery is usually the treatment of choice. Total resection is often possible.

questions.text: Which of the following hormone uses IP3-DAG (phospholipase c) 2nd messenger system?
questions.solution:
Angiontensin II uses IP3-DAG (phospholipase c) 2nd messenger system. 

Other hormones using IP3-DAG (phospholipase c) 2nd messenger system are as follows:

  • Acetyl choline (Muscarinic)
  • Angiotensin II
  • ADH (V1 receptor)
  • Catecholamines α1 receptor
  • Cholecystokinin
  • Gastrin
  • GnRH, GHRH,TRH
  • Oxytocin
  • Substance P

IP3-DAG mechanism:

  • Hormone binds to a GPCR and via a Gq protein activates Phospholipase C.
  • Phospholipase liberates Diacylglycerol (DAG) and Inositol triphosphate (IP3) from membrane lipids.
  • IP3 mobilises Ca2+ from the endoplasmic reticulum.
  • Together, Ca2+ and DAG activate protein kinase C that phosphorylates proteins and causes specific physiologic actions. 

 

 

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Action of Hormones

Types of hormone receptors
Hormones that bind to intracellular receptors
Cytoplasmic receptors Glucocorticoids
Mineralocorticoids
Androgens
  Vitamin D
Nuclear receptors Thyroid hormones
Vitamins A
Hormones that bind to cell surface receptors
1. G-protein coupled receptors (GPCR)
Gs: stimulation of second messenger cAMP ACTH, CRH
TSH, GHRH
FSH, LH, hCG
Vasopressin (V2 receptors)
Catecholamines (β receptors)
Somatostatin
Glucagon
Secretin
Parathyroid hormone
Gi: inhibition of second messenger cAMP Catecholamines (ɑ2 receptors)
Acetylcholine (M2, M4)
Somatostatin

Gq: second messenger is phospholipase C or cGMP

 Phospholipase C (IP3 DAG pathway):
GnRH, GHRH, TRH
Catecholamines (ɑ1 receptors)
Vasopressin (V1 receptor)
Gastrin
Cholecystokinin
Oxytocin
Acetylcholine (M1, M3, M5)
cGMP:
Atrial natriuretic peptide
Nitric oxide
2. Tyrosine kinase receptors
Through the JAK-STAT (non-receptor tyrosine kinase) or MAP kinase (receptor tyrosine kinase) pathway  Growth factors like IGF, VEGF, FGF, PDGF
Growth hormone
Erythropoietin
Insulin
Prolactin


Notes:
1. Even though the cytoplasmic receptors are present in the cytoplasm, once the hormone-receptor complex is formed it moves to the nucleus for its actions.

2. Vitamin D is a cytoplasmic receptor. All intracellular receptors are inherently nuclear receptors as they bind and get activated at the nucleus as mentioned above but they have two sites of primary action- cytoplasm and nucleus. 

3. While receptor tyrosine kinases have intrinsic tyrosine kinase activity, non-receptor tyrosine kinases have an external tyrosine kinase component that interacts with the receptor as and when required.

questions.text: Obsessive compulsive personality is included in personality disorder cluster ____________
questions.solution:
Obsessive compulsive personality is included in personality disorder cluster C.

Obsessive compulsive personality disorder is characterized by a pervasive pattern of preoccupation with orderliness, perfectionism, and mental and interpersonal control, at the expense of flexibility, openness, and efficiency.

Note: Obsessive compulsive personality disorder and obsessive compulsive disorder are 2 separate entities.

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of:
questions.solution:
Nysten’s rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis.

Rigor mortis is also known as cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening. It refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. Both voluntary and involuntary muscles are involved. In India, it begins 1-2 hours following death.

Nysten's rule describes the order of appearance of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. It first appears in the myocardium, which becomes rigid in an hour. The order of appearance of rigor mortis is:

Myocardium> eyelids > neck and lower jaw > face> muscles of chest > upper limb> abdomen > lower limb > fingers and toes (proximo-distal progression)

It passes off in the same order of its appearance.

Medicolegal importance:

  • Sign of death
  • Helps in estimating the time of death, but is not reliable
  • Indicates the position of the body at the time of death

Conditions that simulate rigor mortis include heat stiffening, cold stiffening, and cadaveric spasm.

Related Pearl: Difference between Cadaveric Rigidity (Rigor mortis) and Cadaveric Spasm (Instantaneous rigor)

Trait Cadaveric rigidity Cadaveric spasm
Production Freezing and exposure to a temperature above 650C will produce rigor Cannot be produced by any method after death
Mechanism Reduction of ATP Not clear
Predisposing factors Nil Sudden death, excitement, fear, etc
Time of onset 1 – 2 hours after death Instantaneous
Muscles involved All muscles – both voluntary and involuntary Single group of voluntary muscles
Muscle stiffening Not marked: can be overcome by moderate force Marked: Great force is required to overcome
Molecular death Occurs Doesn't occur
Body heat Cold Warm
Electrical stimuli Muscles do not respond Muscles respond
Muscular reaction Acidic Alkaline
Medicolegal importance Indicates the time of death Indicates manner of death

questions.text: The true statement regarding the clinical condition seen in the image shown below?

choices.text: It is caused by adenovirus 3, 4, and 7
It is a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus
It belongs to 3rd stage of McCallan trachoma staging
Oral tetracycline is the drug of choice.

questions.solution:
The above image identified as the cicatrizing stage of trachoma belongs to the 3rd stage of McCallan trachoma staging.

Regarding other options:

  • Pharyngoconjunctival fever is caused by adenovirus 3, 4 and 7.
  • Mucus fishing syndrome is a chronic papillary reaction due to repetitive manual removal of mucus.
  • Oral azithromycin is the drug of choice in trachoma.

The four stages of trachoma according to McCallan are as follows:

Stage 1: Incipient 

  • Immature follicles are present, but clinical symptoms are not obvious.

Stage 2: Established

  • Typical trachomatous lesions without scarring.

Stage 3: Cicatrising

  • Scarring along with active infection.

Stage 4: Healed

  • Only scarring, the disease is either cured or quiet.

Related Pearl: WHO classification of trachoma (FISTO)

WHO grading of trachoma

  • TF = trachomatous inflammation (follicular): five or more follicles (>0.5 mm) on the superior tarsal conjunctiva.
  • TI = trachomatous inflammation (intense): diffuse involvement of the tarsal conjunctiva, obscuring 50% or more of the normal deep tarsal vessels; papillae are present
  • TS = trachomatous conjunctival scarring: easily visible fibrous white tarsal bands
  • TT = trachomatous trichiasis: at least one lash touching the globe
  • CO = corneal opacity sufficient to blur details of at least part of the pupillary margin

Related Pearl: WHO Programme to Control Trachoma: SAFE Strategy

  • S—Surgery: Trichiasis and entropion correction surgery → 3° prevention.
  • A—Antibiotics: Oral azithromycin, topical 1% tetracycline, topical 1% azithromycin → 2° prevention
  • F—Facial hygiene → 1° prevention.
  • E—Environmental cleanliness → primordial prevention

The strategy depends on the prevalence of trachoma follicle in children (aged 1–9 yrs)

  • >10% → Mass antibiotic treatment at the community level and FE measures
  • 5 to 10% → Targeted antibiotic treatment (affected families) and FE measures
  • < 5% → FE measures

questions.text: Serologic test results from a hepatitis patient reveal: anti-HBc positive with low titres of IgM, HBsAg positive, HBe Ag negative,  and anti-HBs negative. The correct interpretation of the patient’s status is

choices.text: Hepatitis B virus chronic carrier state

questions.solution:
The serological test of this patient indicates chronic carrier state of hepatitis B.

HbsAg is positive only when the patient has acute infection or a chronic carrier and cannot be seen during window period.

Replicative activity (infectivity) is determined with level of HBeAg or HBV DNA.

Anti HbsAg is positive only during recovery or after vaccination.

Note: In contrast to the high titers of IgM-specific anti- HBc observed in acute disease, low titers of IgM anti-HBc are found in the sera of most chronic HBsAg carriers. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

 

 Clinical Phases HBsAg Anti-HBs HBeAg Anti-HBe Anti-HBc HBV DNA
Acute HBV - Early-phase, high infectivity

Acute HBV -Window phase

-

-

Chronic HBV, high infectivity + - + - IgG +++

Chronic HBV, low infectivity

 + - - + IgG +

HBV infection in the recent past

 - + - - IgG -

HBV infection in the remote past

 - - - +/- IgG -

Post-vaccination

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in her right wrist. On examination, there is tenderness on the tip of the radial styloid, and Finkelstein's test is positive. This condition results from inflammation of which synovial sheath?

choices.text: Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis
Abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis longus
Abductor pollicis brevis and extensor digiti minimi
Extensor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis

questions.solution:
The above condition described is likely De Quervain's tenosynovitis an inflammatory disorder that occurs due to inflammation of abductor pollicis longus and extensor pollicis brevis.

Finkelstein's test (ulnar deviation of a closed fist) is used for diagnosing De Quervain's Tenosynovitis.

In the given image, the arrow indicates the location of pain when the test is positive.

questions.text: The Model for End-Stage Liver Disease (MELD) score cut off suggestive of significant mortality in alcoholic hepatitis is _____
questions.solution:
MELD score which is 21 or more is also associated with significant mortality in alcoholic hepatitis.

  • The presence of ascites, variceal hemorrhage, deep encephalopathy, or hepatorenal syndrome predicts a dismal prognosis.
  • The pathologic stage of the injury can be helpful in predicting prognosis

Related Pearl: Revised Model for End-stage liver disease (MELD) scoring system: MELD 3.0

MELD 3.0 score has the following components (Mnemonic F BASIC)

  • Female sex
  • Bilirubin
  • Albumin
  • Serum sodium (mEq/L)
  • INR (International Normalized ratio)
  • Creatinine

Uses:

  • Predict short-term prognosis in patients undergoing transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) insertion
  • Assess and prioritize patients awaiting liver transplantation
  • Assess prognosis in cirrhosis

questions.text: Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is seen in____________
questions.solution:
Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is seen in pelvic inflammatory disease.

Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome is a perihepatitis which occurs in the setting of pelvic inflammatory disease ( PID ).

It occurs in approximately 10 percent of women with acute PID.

Gonococcal salpingits / chlamydial infection → transperitoneal / vascular spread → inflammation of the liver capsule and peritoneal surfaces of the anterior right upper quadrant.

Characterized by right upper quadrant abdominal pain with a pleuritic component, sometimes referred to the right shoulder.

The image below represents the Violin-string adhesions of chronic Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.

questions.text: The AMAN variant of the Guillian Barre syndrome differs from the AIDP, in that, in the former the complement deposition along with IgG antibodies occurs at:
questions.solution:
• In AMAN (Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy), the pattern is different in that complement is deposited along with IgG at the nodes of Ranvier along large motor axons.
  • In AIDP (Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy), an early step in the initiation of tissue damage appears to be complement deposition along the outer surface of the Schwann cell.
  • Activation of complement initiates a characteristic vesicular disintegration of the myelin sheath and also leads to the recruitment of activated macrophages, which participate in damage to myelin and axons.

questions.text: Not a use of the device shown in the image:

choices.text: Medical Termination of Pregnancy - Check Curettage

questions.solution:
The image shows uterine curette with sharp and blunt ends.

It is not used in uterine length measurements.
Uterine length measurements are done with uterine sounds.

questions.text: Methimazole acts by __________.

choices.text: Inhibition of deiodinase type 1 and type 2

questions.solution:
Methimazole is an anti-thyroid drug that acts by inhibition of thyroid peroxidase. It interferes with the oxidation of iodide ion and iodotyrosyl residues resulting in decreased formation of active hormones.

Mechanism of action of anti-thyroid drugs:

  • Drugs inhibiting hormone synthesis
    • Propylthiouracil
    • Methimazole
  • Drugs Inhibiting iodide trapping
    • Thiocyanates
    • Perchlorates
    • Nitrates
  • Drugs inhibiting hormone release
    • Iodine
    • Sodium iodide
    • Potassium iodide
    • Organic iodide
  • Drugs that destroy thyroid tissue
    • Radioactive iodine

Note: Iodides of sodium and potassium and Lugol's iodine act by inhibiting thyroid hormone release. Hence, they are also called thyroid constipating agents. They are the fastest acting agents.

questions.text: The obstetric ultrasound finding of a twin peak sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is Dichorionic diamniotic twins.

The twin peak sign (also known as the lambda (λ) sign) is a triangular appearance of the chorion insinuating between the layers of the inter twin membrane. It is seen in dichorionic diamniotic twin pregnancy. It is best seen in the first trimester (between 10-14 weeks).

The T sign is formed at the point at which the amnions meet the placenta. Twins are separated only by a membrane created by the juxtaposed amnion of each twin. Sonographic image of the “T” sign in a monochorionic diamniotic gestation at 30 weeks.

Related Pearl: Important radiological signs in OBG

Sign
Significance
Bagel sign
Gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring.
USG sign in tubal ectopic.
Ball Sign
X-ray shows a crumpled up spine of the fetus.
Radiological sign of intrauterine fetal death.
Banana Sign
Abnormal anterior curvature of the cerebellum due to the associated Arnold-Chiari malformation.
USG sign in open spina bifida.
Double decidual sac Sign
Two concentric echogenic rings separated by a hyperechoic space.
Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.
Lambda Sign
The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.
USG sign seen in di-chorionic pregnancies.
‘T’ Sign
USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.
Bunch of grapes sign
USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.
Butterfly sign
Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.
Cloverleaf skull
Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Universal Eye Speculum is ______
questions.solution:
Image A shows the Universal Eye Speculum. It is used to separate the eyelids for good exposure during eye surgeries.  It is called a universal eye speculum because it can be used for both, the right and left sides. It has open blades and two limbs with a spring mechanism and a screw to adjust the limbs. It is useful during intraocular surgery such as cataract surgery, glaucoma surgery and keratoplasty. Some Extraocular surgery like squint surgery, and pterygium surgery.

Image B shows Corneal Scissors. Usually used during corneal transplants and in corneal trephination.

Image C shows Vanna’s Scissors. Used to cut fine suture, anterior capsule and to perform iridotomy.

Image D shows Muller’s Retractor. It is a self-retaining lacrimal wound retractor used in surgeries of the lacrimal sac.

questions.text: Sagittal section of brain is given below. Labelled white matter fibers represent which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image represents Association fibres which connect cortical regions within the same cerebral hemisphere.

Main white matter tracts in CNS can be classified into three types:

Projection fibres: Project from higher to lower centres or vice versa in CNS.

  • Corona radiata
  • Internal capsule
  • Fimbria

Association fibers: Connect cortical regions within same cerebral hemispheres

  • Uncinate fasciculus
  • Cingulum
  • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
  • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
  • Fornix
  • Arcuate fasciculus

Commisural fibres: Transverse fibres that interconnect similar regions in both hemispheres of CNS

  • Corpus callosum
  • Hippocampal commissure
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure

Related Pearl: White matter tracts of the brain

Commissural fibers: connect corresponding regions of two hemispheres.

They include

  • Corpus callosum
  • Anterior and posterior commissure
  • Habenular commissure
  • Hippocampal commissure of fornix

Association fibers: connect various cortical regions within the same hemisphere.

They are classified as 

  • Short association fibers: lie immediately under the cortex and connect adjacent gyri. Eg- arcuate fasciculus
  • Long association fibers:
    • Uncinate fasciculus
    • Cingulum
    • Superior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Inferior longitudinal fasciculus
    • Fronto-occipital fasciculus
    • Fornix (except hippocampal commissure of fornix)

Projection fibers: fibers passing to and from the brainstem to the cerebral cortex. 

  • Internal capsule
  • Corona radiata

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Sibson’s fascia is incorrect?

choices.text: Attached to the inner border of first rib.
Attached to transverse process of C7 vertebra
Thoracic nerve passes through its anterior border
Subclavian artery passes above the fascia

questions.solution: The first thoracic nerve escapes through a foramen present at the posterior border (not anterior) of sibson’s fascia.

questions.text: What is the second bone to ossify in the human body?
questions.solution:
The mandible is the second bone to ossify in the human body. The primary ossification center appears by the 7th week of Intrauterine life.

Part of the mandible between mental and mandibular foramina ossifies in membrane from mesenchymal sheath of Meckel’s cartilage (first arch cartilage).

Part of the mandible medial to mental foramen ossifies directly from Meckel’s cartilage (endochondral ossification).

Note: Clavicle is the first bone to ossify.

questions.text: Identify the congenital anomaly shown in the MRI image ______
questions.solution:
The MRI image shows absence of gyri and sulci suggestive of Lissencephaly.

Lissencephaly represents a group of disorders caused by defective neuronal migration in the period between the 8th and 14thgestational weeks, resulting in the lack of development of gyri and sulci.

Option c: Schizencephaly is the presence of unilateral or bilateral clefts within the cerebral hemispheres due to an abnormality of morphogenesis.

Option b: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon and inadequate induction of forebrain structures.

questions.text: In a rice processing factory, paddy is soaked in hot water.  After this, the water is drained and the paddy is steamed and dried. Which of the following statements is false about the above process?

choices.text: This method is used for partial cooking of rice
It makes the rice grains resistant to insects
Vitamins and minerals are driven into endosperm during this process

questions.solution:
The procedure mentioned above is parboiling. It hardens the rice grains.

Parboiling is the process of partial cooking of rice in steam. It is done by the hot soaking process that was initially developed by the Central Food Technological Research Institute (CFTRI), Mysore.

The advantages of parboiling are:

  • Preserves nutritive quality by driving the vitamins and minerals into the endosperm.
  • Hardens the grains and makes them insect resistant.

questions.text: Chromosome number of a complete mole is
questions.solution:
Karyotype seen in a complete mole is 46XX or 46 XY

Related Pearl: Complete vs. Partial Mole

Hydatidiform mole is a benign abnormal condition of the placenta characterized by partial degenerative or proliferative changes of the chorionic villi. Though benign, it has malignant potential. It is commonly seen in pregnancies of extreme reproductive age groups - teenage and women above 35 years of age. A previous history of molar pregnancy is also a strong risk factor for recurrence of this condition.

Molar pregnancy is of 2 types - complete mole and partial mole.

Feature Partial mole Complete mole
Karyotype 69 XYY or 69 XXY 46 XX or 46 XY
Diagnosis Missed abortion Molar gestation
Uterus size Small for date Large for date
Theca-lutein cysts Rare 25–30% of cases
Initial hCG levels <1 lakh mIU/ml >1 lakh mIU/ml
Medical complications Rare Uncommon
Rate of subsequent GTN 1–5% 15–20%
Embryo-fetus  Often present Absent
Amnion, fetal erythrocytes Often present Absent
Villous edema  Focal Widespread
Trophoblastic proliferation Focal, slight to moderate Slight to severe
Trophoblast atypia Mild Marked
p57KIP2 immunostaining Positive Negative

questions.text: Drug of choice for trichomoniasis is
questions.solution:
Metronidazole is the drug of choice for trichomoniasis.

Metronidazole 2g single dose is the drug of choice. If failure occurs, it can be repeated in 4-6 weeks. Tinidazole is more expensive, has a longer half-life than metronidazole, causes fewer gastrointestinal symptoms, and may be useful in treating trichomoniasis that fails to respond to metronidazole. (option B)

Albendazole and mebendazole are anthelmintics and are not indicated for trichomoniasis (options c and d).

questions.text: Salivary gland tumor with a propensity for perineural invasion:
questions.solution:
Adenoid cystic carcinoma has a propensity for perineural invasion and indolent growth pattern.

  • It is the second most common malignant tumor of the parotid gland.
  • The histological types are tubular, cribriform, and solid.
  • The tubular type has the best prognosis and solid has the worst.
  • Treatment is the removal of the gross tumor with radiation therapy for microscopic disease.

Related Pearl: Important points regarding salivary gland tumors

  • Most common neoplasm of the salivary gland: Pleomorphic adenoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common benign tumor of the salivary gland in children: Hemangioma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the salivary gland in children: Mucoepidermoid carcinoma
  • Most common malignant tumor of the minor salivary glands: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Most common gland affected by pleomorphic adenomas: Parotid gland
  • Tumor of the salivary gland with perineural invasion: Adenoid cystic carcinoma
  • Tumor that shows a hot spot in 99mTc scan: Warthin’s tumor

questions.text: All the following conditions present with secondary hemochromatosis except:
questions.solution:
Haemophilia does not present with secondary haemochromatosis.

The conditions presenting with secondary iron overload are:

  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Thalassemia
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda
  • Hereditary aceruloplasminemia

Secondary iron overload with deposition in parenchymal cells occurs in chronic disorders of erythropoiesis, as iron absorption is increased in these conditions. Moreover, these patients require blood transfusions and are frequently treated inappropriately with iron.

Hemophilia presents with mucosal bleeding which usually does not require blood transfusions. Furthermore, iron metabolism is normal in hemophilia. Therefore, secondary hemochromatosis is not seen in hemophilia.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text: Equal and simultaneous innervation to a pair of yoke muscles is explained by __________
questions.solution:
Equal and simultaneous innervation to a pair of yoke muscles is explained by the Hering's law of equal innervation.

 Hering's law of equal innervation

Whenever an impulse for the performance of an eye movement is sent out, corresponding yoke muscles of each eye receive equal innervations to contract or to relax. This is the law of equal innervations proposed by Hering.

  • Eg: During levoversion, the right medial rectus and left lateral rectus receives an equal and simultaneous flow of innervations.

Sherrington's law of reciprocal innervation (Option A):

It states that during the initiation of an eye movement, increased innervation to an extraocular muscle is accompanied by simultaneous inhibition (a reciprocal decrease in innervation) of the direct antagonist of the contracting muscle of the same eye.

  • Eg: During levoversion, An increased innervational flow to the right medial and left lateral rectus, accompanied by decreased flow of innervations to right lateral rectus and left medial rectus  

Donders' law (Option C):

It states that for anyone gaze direction, the eye always assumes the same unique orientation in 3 dimensions. The orientation is always the same irrespective of where the eye came from. 

  • For example, the orientation of the eye when looking up and right is the same when the eye reached this position by first rotating right and then up or first up and then right.

Listing's Law (Option D):

It is the specific realization of the more general 'Donders' law', which states that for any one gaze direction the eye's 3D spatial orientation is unique and independent of how the eye reached that gaze direction (previous gaze directions / eye orientations / temporal movements).

questions.text: The commonest form of postpartum traumatic neuritis is
questions.solution:
The commonest form of obstetric palsy encountered in puerperium is foot drop.

Postpartum traumatic neuritis is also known as obstetric palsy. Usually unilateral and appears shortly after delivery or during the first day postpartum or so. Due to stretching of the lumbosacral trunk by the prolapsed intervertebral disk between L5 and S1.

Neurological examination reveals a lower motor neuron type of lesion with flaccidity and wasting of the muscles in areas supplied by the femoral nerve or lumbosacral plexus. Sensory loss is often present.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. Probable diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment is suggestive of central serous retinopathy.

Central serous retinopathy

  • Refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region.
  • Pathogenesis: Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Clinical features:

  • Retinal detachment: Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy 
    • Circular ring reflex present
    •  Foveal reflex absent
  • FFA 
    •  Enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

Treatment: 

  • Treatment not required, usually self-limiting but often recurrent
  • Steroids are contraindicated.

questions.text: An IQ of 45 comes under _________
questions.solution:
IQ of 45 comes under moderate MR.

DSM IV (Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders) criteria for mental retardation was based on IQ scores:

  • Intelligent quotient (IQ) = Mental age/Chronological age × 100
  • Normal IQ – 90 – 110
  • Mental subnormality – 70 - 90
Type of mental retardation IQ score
Mild 50 – 69
Moderate 35 – 49
Severe 20 – 34
Profound <20

Changes in DSM 5:

  • Word “Mental retardation” has been replaced by “Intellectual disability”.
  • Intellectual Disability (Intellectual Developmental Disorder) is a disorder with onset during the developmental period that includes both intellectual and adaptive functioning deficits in conceptual, social, and practical domains.
  • Severity levels are now classified by adaptive rather than intellectual function or IQ scores.
Criteria DSM-IV-TR/Ed.gov.nl.ca DSM-5
Name (Mental Retardation) COGNITIVE DISORDER Intellectual Disabilities
A: Intellectual function

Significantly subaverge intellectual functioning

IQ≤ 70

 Deficits (reasoning, problem-solving, planning, abstract thinking, etc) confirmed by clinical assessment and individual standardized testing (IQ: 70±5) - intellectual profile
B: Adaptive function Deficits in ≥ 2 areas Deficits in adaptive function result in failure to meet socio-cultural standards (e.g., lack of judgment) and related to intellectual impairments
C: Age at onset Before age 18 During the developmental period
Severity Based on IQ Based on the adaptive function

questions.text: Tonsillectomy can be  performed in:

choices.text: Child with an impaired palatal function

questions.solution:
Diphtheria and streptococcal carriers are relative indications for tonsillectomy

Contraindications for tonsillectomy:

Three general categories of contraindications exist and they are:

  1. Velopharyngeal,
  2. Hematologic
  3. Infectious.
  4. Miscellaneous

1. Velopharyngeal

  • Overt cleft palate
  • Submucous cleft palate
  • Impaired palatal function

2. Hematologic

  • Hemoglobin level less than 10 g%.
  • Bleeding disorders, e.g. leukemia, purpura, aplastic anemia or hemophilia.

3. Infectious

  • Presence of acute infection in the upper respiratory tract, even acute tonsillitis. Bleeding is more in the presence of acute infection.
  • At the time of an epidemic of polio.

4. Miscellaneous

  • Children under 3 years of age. They are poor surgical risks.
  • Uncontrolled systemic disease, e.g. diabetes, cardiac disease, hypertension or asthma.
  • Tonsillectomy is avoided during the period of menses.

questions.text: Which glucose transporter is present in erythrocytes?
questions.solution:
GLUT 1 is the glucose transporter present in erythrocytes. 

It mediates basal glucose uptake. GLUT 1 is also the major glucose transporter in the brain and placenta and is widely distributed.

GLUT 1
Brain, RBC, Placenta, kidney, colon Basal glucose uptake
GLUT 2
Liver, pancreatic beta cell, small intestine, kidney Rapid uptake/release of glucose. Low affinity and high km
GLUT 3
Neurons, kidney, placenta High affinity for glucose
GLUT 4
Heart, skeletal muscle, adipose tissue Insulin-dependent glucose uptake
GLUT 5
Small intestine, testis, sperm Fructose transporter
GLUT 8
Blastocyst, testis, brain Insulin-dependent glucose uptake in blastocyst. Transports glucose to Mature spermatozoa.
GLUT 9
Liver, kidney Urate transporter

questions.text: Which is the best metabolic function of the lung?

choices.text: Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II

questions.solution:
Conversion of angiotensin I to angiotensin II is the most significant metabolic function of the lungs.

This is mediated by angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE), located on the surface of endothelial cells in the pulmonary capillaries.

  • Synthesized and used in the lungs
    • Surfactant
  • Synthesized or stored and released into the blood
    • Prostaglandins
    • Histamine
    • Kallikrein
  • Partially removed from the blood
    • Prostaglandins
    • Bradykinin
    • Adenine nucleotides
    • Serotonin
    • Norepinephrine
    • Acetylcholine
  • Activated in the lungs
    • Angiotensin I → Angiotensin II

questions.text: Dicrotic notch is caused by _________
questions.solution:
Dicrotic notch is caused by closing of aortic valve.

The dicrotic notch, a small oscillation in the falling phase of the pulse wave caused by vibrations set up when the aortic valve shuts.
